review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.review: The Corsair Nightsword RGB is in my opinion the best mouse ever. The material and feel of the mouse is comfortable and from my experience, reduces sweat. The customizable weight makes it the experience of the mouse even better, if you download the corsair icue app on your pc, you can customize the DPI, buttons, and colors on the mouse. The 18,000 DPI sensor is more than enough range of sensitivity tuning. The mouse also has a “sniper” button which can also be fine tuned. Over all I love this mouse and recommend it to anyone who wants a quality mouse for all around use.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2021
review.title: Pretty painful for beginners
review.review: Edit: still dealing with customer service via snail mail basically, one response a day and I’m pretty sure it’s different people because I get asked the same questions. Going to likely and painfully return this horrible product especially after hearing this happen to others.Edit: this product is the most frustrating experience, nothing lights up properly and customer service told me I had to play email tag because their “tech support” doesn’t cover troubleshooting this and the people that do only answer by email. Sometimes 2 fans light up, other times just one but never all 3 and nothing else in the kit has ever lit up as intended. Stay away.This product comes in great packaging and you really feel like you got value for money especially when you tally up the individual items.It’s also not the cheapest, but I wanted to get something higher quality being my first time and all, but this wasn’t quite the case.To begin I learned the pipes were called something that’s just a fancy word for acrylic, and I learned very fast that it’s not very forgiving and easy to mess up. Couple that with the types of adapters you get which pretty much commit you to hardline tubing and you are stuck either with attempting to use them (and in my case immediately messing up a tube despite watching videos prior,) or investing a lot more money to get better tubes or different adapters, but it doesn’t end there…It comes with a squeeze container for filling the pump which broke off inside just from using, that was 2 hours of draining and playing rubik’s cube trying to get out, not fun. But it doesn’t end there either…The pump is awkward as heck, if you have it all plugged in the thing doesn’t operate at full power when filling and you are stuck trying to figure out why the tubes aren’t filling, why does it gotta be like that?The directions aren’t the best, and this process was very painful, I got coolant all over my motherboard and cards despite my best intent to cover everything which yes, is part to user error but I also feel the acrylic isn’t the best use and I wish there were more options from Corsair like being able to buy a kit with soft tubing. Knowing what I do now I may have opted for a cheaper kit and gotten soft line tubing to save the headache and for more flexibility.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2021
review.title: Great product!
review.review: This build turned out way better than I expected! I did purchase some extra 90 degree fittings just in case I needed them and with my case being an itx I definitely needed them.i changed the rad to a 240 since the 360 was not able to fit in my case. As far as temps, I have a ryzen 5 3600 with an aorus 3090 wb card. Temps for my gpu never got over 70 and my cpu was the same. I do think the fans included with this are ment for a bigger case. My overall build went smooth and I had more than enough tubing(had 3 sticks left so only used half of what was included). Definitely a good buy if your a beginner like me!Update: I was getting high temps on my cpu. And by high it was 83c after playing 1 game of warzone. I re-seated and reapplied thermal paste to the cpu plate and still no change. After trying for a second time to re-seat it I decided to remover the washer on the mounting screws that the instruction say to put on. (I included a pic of the instructions.) After removing those washer I immediately saw a changed. Played a few games and my cpu temp stayed in the high 60s.

review.title: 2 modes are great in this mouse.
review.review: The pros - this mouse has a pretty good battery life, it can be plugged in or wireless and the wireless charging is a nice feature. Corsairs software is top notch and you can adjust the settings on the fly and even set up profiles for what apps you have running. Indicator lights work well and it has enough buttons to do normal FPS gaming and surfing options.The con, and this is unfortunately a fairly large one, I get a hair of lag when its wireless, meaning wireless mode is not ideal for FPS gaming, or really any gaming. So I frequently operate it wirelessly when I'm just surfing the net and stuff but if I'm going to play I plug it in.This might be my setup creating an issue, my tower does sit 4 feet from the mouse, the drawers for the desk are between the mouse and its receiver so these are all things that could be the cause and that I'll try and tweak down the road but it is something I am experiencing so figured fair warning to anyone else who may have a similar set up.

review.title: Great mouse, did research before buying
review.review: I did my research directly on Razer's website to find the mouse that fit my needs best. I was having issues with my previous Razer mouse, only to find that my mousepad was the cause. I actually put away my Mamba Wireless for this mouse because I prefer the soft cord and typically don't gravitate toward wireless for gaming. If you are looking for a wireless mouse, I would recommend the Mamba wireless. For wired, any of Razer's Speedflex models, including this one. I ultimately chose this one and buying here for price and dpi, as I typically game at 9,000 dpi, but like to change that a bit for different games/gameplay types.Overall, would buy again and recommend as a wired mouse. The pink is a nice color to spice up my rig.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Lost Connections, bad lag, poor performance
review.review: I had been looking at this mouse for a while and finally convinced myself to buy one.I was very excited for the new mouse.My somewhat new computer has the RGB fans and lighting, so I was excited to add to my setup with this mouse and mouse dock.Add to this the fact that this is a Razer product (supposedly top tier), I thought I was getting something good.I bought this mouse, received it two days latter, returned it the next day.I let the mouse fully charge before using (per the instructions).Once it was fully charged I started using it for the last part of my work day.I was presenting on a Teams meeting and twice in the hour meeting it lost connection.Luckily I still had my other mouse connected so I was able to use it the second time to finish the meeting.Several other times through the remaining part of the day/evening the mouse would lose connection with the computer, usually requiring me to turn it off then back on again for it to start working.Other times it would lag behind very bad and I would have to wait for it to catch up to what I was trying to do.If this is "hyperspeed" technology, I would hate to see how a normal speed mouse works from Razer.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming, it is horrible.Finally, I tried to customize the buttons on the mouse through Razer Synapse.I would set the buttons, save the setup, and if I left Razer Synapse open, the buttons would work with no issues.As soon as I closed the Razer application, it is as if the mouse would reset to factory defaults and loose all the settings I had just saved.I tried this multiple times with the same results.I even checked other sites for instructions on how to customize the mouse settings to make sure I was not missing a step, no luck.So, in addition to the loss of connection, and horrible lagging; if I were to keep them mouse I would have to open Razer Synapse every morning, setup the mouse again how I wanted it to be, then leave the application open all day just to make sure it worked as designed.I am new to Razer products like this but not new to computers.I have been working in the IS field for over a decade, and I know how to use, and troubleshoot issues with these devices.This mouse just is not a good mouse and not worth the money at all.Please don't waste your money on this overpriced, underperforming mouse.
product.title: Razer Viper Ultimate Hyperspeed Lightest Wireless Gaming Mouse & RGB Charging Dock: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - 20K DPI ...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.title: I’m never getting a different mouse ever!
review.review: The Corsair Nightsword RGB is in my opinion the best mouse ever. The material and feel of the mouse is comfortable and from my experience, reduces sweat. The customizable weight makes it the experience of the mouse even better, if you download the corsair icue app on your pc, you can customize the DPI, buttons, and colors on the mouse. The 18,000 DPI sensor is more than enough range of sensitivity tuning. The mouse also has a “sniper” button which can also be fine tuned. Over all I love this mouse and recommend it to anyone who wants a quality mouse for all around use.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Mouse is lagging all the time
review.review: I ordered this mouse because I wanted to switch to wireless mouse experience. I really like this mouse, nice and comfortable design and it fits perfectely in my hand with my claw grip.The only thing that keeps me back to give it 5 stars is the wireless modes. when I switch to 2.4GHz Slipstream wireless mode I get so much lags every 5 seconds which is awful for gaming, you just can't play games like this. When I switch to Bluetooth mode the amount of lags decrease but not completely and you can't controll the RGB lightning when using Bluetooth mode.I have to use the wired mode for smooth experience.UPDATE: I connected the 2.4GHz Slipstream receiver to the front panel and I have 0 lags, also can't notice any lags in bluetooth mode anymore.Advice: Don't connect the Slipstream receiver to the back of your PC and you won't get any lags.

review.title: A major step back from the G602...
review.review: I have had multiple G602s over the years and it is easily the best wireless mouse I have ever used.One of my mine finally died, and I ordered a G604 as a replacement thinking it would be equivalent at the least. Sadly, I was very wrong. The G604 doesn't improve on the G602 in any way, and clearly took a major step back in terms of quality / quality control. The left mouse button squeaks loudly when used and often sticks in the engaged position when clicked. The scroll wheel is also infinitely worse (though I rarely use it anyway). I'm not mad, I'm just disappointed.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: The mouse is fine, but the mandatory G HUB sofware is awful
review.review: So Logitech decided to discontinue their software for various devices and consolidate them into on grand app to rule them all: G HUB. Not a bad strategy, but the execution was terrible.The mouse itself is pretty good, but there is no point extolling its virtues, since you shouldn't buy it anyway. In fact, you should not buy any Logitech wireless produce until they've fixed G HUB. Or eradicated it, hired a new engineering team, and written something better to replace it. Or, you know, just reverted to the LGS app that their older mice used that worked just fine for years.There are many reviews detailing G HUB's failings, so I won't list all of them here. I'll add my latest experience to the pile:I got the mouse and installed G HUB several months ago on a system with Windows 8.1. Today, I used the in-app button to upgrade to the latest version. But it turns out the latest version is only compatible with Windows 10. So it tried to upgrade itself and hung forever instead, showing me the cutesy animation that Logitech's engineering department apparently spent their time on instead of doing QA. I didn't even get the courtesy of an error message.As a programmer myself, I can tell you that's an inexcusable, novice, facepalm-grade error. An auto-updater should *always* perform proper version and requirements checks.Anyway, I headed to Logitech's site to find an installer for the earlier Windows 8 compatible version. I knew it existed, since just an hour before it was up and running on my system. But no luck, they now offer Windows 10 or Mac only. So then off to reddit, where quickly I found the hidden link to the older Win7 and Win8 versions. Pay no mind to the "There are no Downloads for this Version" message! It's there, or at least it was today, though it may be gone by the time you need it.That installer then failed because it was confused by the current, corrupt installation. So I spent some time ripping that one out by the roots from multiple file system and registry locations. After pausing for a moment to say goodbye to the mouse settings/macros I spent time writing, now all gone, I was able to reinstall it.The whole affair reminded me of this bit from the HHGTTG:“But the plans were on display…”“On display? I eventually had to go down to the cellar to find them.”“That’s the display department.”“With a flashlight.”“Ah, well, the lights had probably gone.”“So had the stairs.”“But look, you found the notice, didn’t you?”“Yes,” said Arthur, “yes I did. It was on display in the bottom of a locked filing cabinet stuck in a disused lavatory with a sign on the door saying ‘Beware of the Leopard.”
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Can't Recommend
review.review: This mouse has really been a disappointment.Battery life is nowhere near what I was expecting. I replace batteries in my M510 maybe every 8 month's. That mouse is used 8 hours a day for work. Since I got this in July I have had to replace the batteries three times already (almost monthly).Functionally, this mouse would be terrible for any type of FPS. Half the time the first click I make doesn't register and I have to click again. I haven't experienced the double clicks that others have reported, but they may only be a matter of time. The two main buttons overhang the front of the mouse, so if you bump it into anything while moving it, you end up with random clicks.And last but definitely not least, the G-Hub software is absolute garbage. The interface is terrible and difficult to use. Nothing is where you expect it be and you have to click thru different screens to do basic things like remap buttons. It is buggy as hell, locking up when trying to update, requiring uninstalling and reinstalling it to get it to work. Half the time the profiles you get put in and saved don't activate when they should. For G-Hub alone I would say to stay away from any Logitech product that uses it.
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Excellent physical design, absolutely unusable due to GHub.
review.review: I had my previous Logitech gaming mouse for almost 10-years before it gave up on life. So I went for this G604.It feels great in my hand, cradles my thumb perfectly and the buttons are all accessible for my tiny lady hands. Excellent design!But... The Ghub software? Randomly drops profiles so none of the programmed buttons work. Just randomly. It makes the mouse totally unusable. I will be in the middle of a project I rely on macro'd buttons to do for work? Mouse decides to stop working. I will be gaming and try to hit a macro? Bam! Dead!Trying to find a way to load the profile onboard is obtuse. This mouse is harder to program than units with more buttons were 10-years ago.Thing is, I trusted Logitech enough to throw out the package so I cannot even return this failure of a device. Ghub will spend hours trying to update and fail to, which leads to uninstalling and reinstalling just to use the %^&%^ mouse to do basic ^&%&^ mouse things. I have never had this kind of issue with Logitech devices and I have been a loyal customer for decades.Looks like I will be dropping $300 to buy a new copy of the same Logitech gaming mouse I got 10-years ago, because I know that it will survive being used for 16-hours a day for close to 10-years and remain a viable, reliable option until USB technology is completely phased out of PCs.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2021
review.title: Corsair please use some better switches
review.review: As others have mentioned my previous Corsair Scimitar had issues with the left mouse button giving phantom double clicks after about a year of use. I figured I was just unlucky and grabbed another because I really like the design of the mouse and how it feels in my hand. However, I am already having issues with this mouse giving the double click issue as well, this time with the right mouse button. I've had this one for even less time than the previous. For something that costs 80 dollars this really isn't acceptable and I will be switching to a different brand for my next one.Also, iCue is the worst software package I have ever used, and is basically required to get any sort of functionality out of the mmo buttons on the side.The Logitech mmo mouse (G600) while not looking nearly as attractive lasted me for about 5 years before I finally gave it to a friend after picking up my first Scimitar. He's still using that mouse. It also comes in at half the price and has a "better" software setup. Not that Logi's is amazing either, but it's far better than iCue. Personally, I will probably pick up another of these because I'd rather have something that lasts than something that looks nice and fails in such a short time period.https://www.amazon.com/Logitech-Gaming-Backlit-Programmable-Buttons/dp/B0086UK7IQ/

review.title: 2 week review
review.review: Been using this after my Dark Core wouldn't stop double clicking and reduced to having a 3 hour battery life. First things first, I've charged this thing like twice in these two weeks and I'm at 65% still... Totally amazed by that part, not sure if the software's just wrong but I haven't had it drop to 10% according to it. This is great for me as I'm usually playing something or scrolling through sites for about 5 hours a day at least. Next the dpi settings are perfect out of the box for me, I usually run 800-1200 and this hits the all the spots well when I need to speed up as well. The wireless communication is a lot better than my previous mouse as well, no random sputters or lags. Also love the ergonomics on it, feels great for my longer fingers and claw grip. Will be sure to update the more I use and the more I find out about it but at the moment 5/5!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Cooling well annoying to install, hmm temp sensors
review.review: Amazon gets 0pts for making uploading photos difficult (must select camera access to even upload selected photos in gallery)…Anyway thought they would help - in my situation I wanted front mount and I was doing push-pull.I appreciated the extra hardware to get 3 more fans in, but then I had issues getting the pump/head to CPU.I have a fat gfx card in there and I scooted the mount and entire mourning to the mount, up as much as I could to create slack, but the tubes are just too tight for this or similar config.Pictured is only way they would reach and even then there is strain in tubes.Cooled well and drives fans well.Probably 10C better than my push thru 240mm exhaust solution.For price, and considering it includes commander thing, I was disappointed.I had a slightly different commander ($100 or something) with temp sensors to drive fans in previous config.Now I have to choose this one to drive pump and CPU fans without temp sensors or inputs, and include other one if I want temp sensors for other fans.Too much space…Corsair is trying to build whole config solution it would be great if all components were thought out a bit better - I was expecting the “commander” to be at least equiv to one I had, instead of correcting duplication…

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: I hope you have big hands.
review.review: This mouse is definitely *not* for people who have hands on the smaller side of average. I don't have tiny hands by any means, but this mouse is extremely awkward for me to use without accidentally hitting the first row of keys on the side. My hand simply doesn't wrap around enough of the bulk of this thing to get a good grip on only the non-button portions of the mouse. This leads to firing off skills or macros that I absolutely do not intend to use yet while just moving the mouse around; I've had to disable the first row of keys entirely to avoid this.Another problem the size presents is that it won't consistently hold down the LMB if I want to click and drag; it'll often let go prematurely because my fingertips apparently don't reach far enough forward to get the leverage it needs to keep the sensors in contact.Years ago, I had a Naga that had plates you could swap out to adjust the size appropriate to your needs, but they apparently don't make them anymore, and are going with a "one (large) size fits all" approach. This is a major shame, because it's excluding a fairly significant portion of the gaming population.If you have big ol' hands, then I bet this mouse would work great for you. It's lightweight (almost too lightweight) and pretty responsive.

review.title: The only premium wireless mmo mouse. needs some competition
review.review: The only MMO mouse that is wireless, from a name brand company.Features: comes with PTFE mouse feet which is very generous and not common, usually you buy these aftermarket.fairly light considering all the hardware on it. another big plus.comes with 3 side plates. one with 12 buttons, one with 2, and one with I think 6? very cool and convenient, and easy to swap out.no perceivable latency, however I originally bought this mouse used. it would lose connection for several seconds, which is unusable for gaming and just annoying in any other application, especially at this price.I returned it and bought a new one, which has the same issue but only loses connectivity very briefly, enough for me to just ignore. I dont play shooters or 1st person games with it so whatever.the razer software has automatic profile switching. you can set up specific keybinds for any program (even ones that arent games) and when you switch to a different program the keybinds automatically swap. this is insanely useful for video editing, music production, MMOs, all kinds of things.battery life is great. naturally, the lights suck a lot of it up but you should turn them off if you want it to last long.I like the ergonomics a lot, I think it feels great in my hand. it's meant to be held with your fingers laid on it and your palm mostly lifted off of it. it feels very comfortable but I'd like it slightly lighter for easier movement.if it werent for the disconnection this would be 5/5 stars. it has zero ccompetition, is feature packed and is good at what it does.

review.title: Extremely ergonomic mouse
review.review: I've been looking for a well shaped mouse for a long time, I've tried the Razer Basilisk, Razer Viper, Logitech g900, Topre mouse, and a no-brand cheap gaming mouse with "speed holes" in it (actually one of the best I've used). None have fit my hold style like this does, and its manly due to the pinky rest attachment which makes it fantastic to grip.The software is decent, takes a bit of time to upload changes to the mouse but not a big deal since its unlikely to constantly change those settings once set to ones liking.I was worried the weight wouldn't be to my liking (I prefer the lightest mice) but it really doesn't feel as heavy as it sounds.Excellent on either desk top or on a mouse pad, I find it rare when a mouse has feet that feel nice without a mouse pad.The negatives are:-Barrel scroll wheel is bit difficult to reach but this may just be due to my strange hold style.-Main scroll wheel sometimes doesnt register a scroll, this is also an issue on razer and logitech mice I've used (why do high end mice seem to have scroll wheels that cant detect correctly on each scroll?).

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: Underwhelming
review.review: I purchased the 8+ White. At the time of purchase, it was a little under $90 USD. TL;DR: sub-par build quality, poor ergonomics, and weird design decisions.Let's start with the good:I'm a sucker for weird computer peripherals, and this definitely delivers in that regard. The customization is nice -- being able to swap out palm rests, adjusting the angle of the thumb rest, or modifying the weight is cool. There's a lot that can be done to make it fit your hand, and I respect that.I found the software to be adequate as well. Windows only for the software, though any edits you make are saved to the mouse directly so it'll work on Linux or Mac. (But keep in mind for Mac, there aren't any bindings in the software for CMD, if you have any intention of using this for complex Mac-specific macros. This doesn't affect my score since this is advertised as Windows-only, which is fair.)It's easy-ish to open up. Just threes screws and a bit of finesse. Repairability seems feasible.Unfortunately, there isn't much else I can say about it that's good besides it's a functioning mouse.Here are a handful of my issues with the device:- Poor build quality.One of the first things I noticed after opening and inspecting the mouse was that one of the plastic top panels was loose. It's not that it was screwed in wrong or anything (I opened the mouse up to check), but rather that the plastic just wasn't molded to properly fit. It's not a huge deal, but there's a noticeable gap about the size of my fingernail that sits between the top panel with the "RAT 8+" logo and the black frame underneath.Basically every button on the mouse has some crazy wobble to it, especially the right mouse button and middle DPI switch on mine. I shimmed some of the empty space with small bits of paper to reduce the wobble, which worked. Although if you want to do this for the DPI switch, you'll have to open up the mouse.Another gripe: Out of the box, I couldn't get the adjustment tool to work on any of the thumb rest adjustments. They were super tight, to the point of where I needed a screwdriver to loosen them. Maybe just an issue on my unit, but keep in mind it might be helpful to have a small hex allen wrench on hand.- Bad ergonomics.I understand this is subjective, so I'm not factoring this too heavily into my score. But despite all the customizability, my hand always had a tendency to feel sore after using it for long periods of time, no matter how many configurations I tried. It's probably okay for shorter gaming sessions, but if you're also using this for productivity, you might have comfort issues. My hands are slim and maybe small-medium in size, for reference.- Weird design decisions.On the thumb rest, there's a screw hole right behind the sniper button where your thumb will likely naturally rest. At first thought, no issue. But after only like a month of using this mouse, everything around that screw hole is covered in grime. I wash my hands just as much as the next guy, so bear in mind this area might need some extra attention when cleaning.Another weird one is the pinky rest attachment, which I wanted to love. Unfortunately, it has an issue where it didn't actually make physical contact with the desk, instead hovering like 2mm above it. Sounds reasonable: less contact, less friction when gaming, right? Well -- with the size and weight of the pinky rest, the reality of the situation is that even the slightest bit of unbalanced pressure from your hand means your mouse is now lopsided and leaning to the right. It's super easy to run into this unintentionally, and it makes the whole thing just feel poorly thought out and engineered. A quick fix: find an old mouse you're not using, peel off one of the smaller skates from the bottom, and then stick that onto the pinky rest's skate. That should close the gap and reduce the tendency to tilt to the right. It'll introduce more drag, but you're probably not going to be using the pinky rest for gaming anyways because of how huge it is.Finally, I want to mention the weight of this mouse. It's heavy. I don't know the exact numbers, but I was only able to get this to a comfortable weight by removing all of the included weights, as well as the spring + adjustment tool under the palm rest. If you want a light mouse for gaming, this isn't it.Other thoughts, that don't reflect my rating:- I really don't know what to use the horizontal scroll wheel for. I mean, sure, horizontal scrolling -- but I do that so rarely it feels overkill to have a separate wheel dedicated to it. I used the software to bind page up/down to the wheel to try it out as a super-fast scrolling solution, like some knock-off Logitech frictionless scroll. It was adequate. Maybe other people will find more use for it than me.- This mouse loves its decals. It's a bit of a detractor for me. I honestly think this thing would look a lot nicer with maybe just a single Mad Catz logo somewhere. The palm rests are extra weird, they have this " 0 -- 5 -- 10 -- 15 -- 20" ruler-like thing printed on but it's totally non-functional and looks weird. It'd look better blank.- My cursor had a tendency to "jump" around sometimes. I think the sensor might have been calibrated weirdly. There's an option to do this in the software. Not sure if mine was defective, but it didn't bother me enough to try to recalibrate it while I was using the mouse. Seemed to only happen just after the mouse was lifted + set back down.- I'm no longer using this mouse. I managed to replace the broken scroll encoder on my Swiftpoint Z, and I'm going back to that as my daily driver.
product.title: Mad Catz The Authentic R.A.T. Pro S3 Optical Gaming Mouse

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2021
review.title: Wish it had more lights
review.review: It has pretty much everything you would expect a good gaming mouse should have, it's just that if I'm gonna spend $180 on a mouse, it better look impressive. I'm totally willing to pay that kind of money for a seemingly unnecessary mouse as long as aesthetics are worth it but with this little RGB lights that don't look nearly as bright as the cover photo if does feel rather disappointing. Cool design but unless you're always in a bright room, you can't really appreciate nearly 200 dollars worth of a computer mouse. Also holding it feels rather uncomfortable on the left side (thumb side). Wish there were no bottons there so I can press the side of it more securely. Bottom line, great mouse but not worth 200 dollars unless they add more lighting for those sweet aesthetics so many of us are willing to pay for.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2021
review.title: A Good Mouse, Surprisingly Works Well
review.review: I didn't expect much from this mouse being wireless and all, but it surprised me.The most important thing here is that it feels very similar to my older RAT8, same shape, same size, only unlike the RAT8 which comes with some weird silicon coating or a gloss coating, the DWS comes with a nice matte plastic that feels really nice -- some say it feels like cheap plastic, it really does not. Really good feel. And it looks really nice in person too, love the Silver & Black. The other difference is the side trigger, better placement and a larger button and bit more flat so it feels much more comfortable reaching your thumb over to press.The Wireless options are good. Bluetooth and 2.4G connections are good. It seems the 2.4G connection is much smoother however, sometimes the Bluetooth connection will stutter after turning it off and back on. So far I haven't experienced any significant lag or issues with 2.4G as I historically did with older tech, but it's not 100% perfect as I do see a hiccup here or there. Nothing I'd really call a deal breaker.I run on a 144Hz gaming monitor and the mouse movements are smoother than other wireless mice, but not as smooth as my wired RAT8. I would say the smooth mouse movements on the DWS are about 85% of my wired RAT8, which means for gaming I would notice a slight drop in smoothness, but honestly, unless you're staring at the mouse cursor directly as you move it left and right real fast, it isn't very noticeable.The clicking feels good, but a bit more stiff than the RAT8 (likely because it's new). The only thing I don't like is how the mouse feels when scrolling down, it's has much harder rolling-ticks down than scrolling up, and sometimes it feels like it's missing some of these scrolls, so when browsing web pages, it'll scroll, stall for half a second and scroll again. I wonder if this one mouse is somewhat messed up with this one issue -- then again my RAT8 will also do this from time to time — but not as much.Overall I really like this mouse. It has an excellent style, excellent feel, and the wireless experience is smooth for being wireless.It also works good with my KVM between my Mac, PC and Linux Box: One Mouse to Rule Them All.
product.title: Mad Catz The Authentic R.A.T. Pro S3 Optical Gaming Mouse

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: After 1 Year, the battery gave up on me.
review.review: I got this mice roughly a Year and 3 months ago.It's a great device for gaming and also for normal use, as it is very comfortable to use and it has a lot of good feeling buttons which are a pleasure to use and a must have for some games.The mice is a bit heavier than other gaming mices but not by much.My only problem with the G900 is that after using it for over a year, the battery or some other component inside the mice stopped working from night to day. This makes it so that I can still use the device without a problem, as long as it is connected to the charging cable.The G HUB app says I'm up to date, I've reinstalled drivers, and it also says that I have 100% battery, but when I disconnect the device from the charging cable, it instantly shuts off and doesn't show any lights, just like if I had pressed on the off button.I don't find anyone with the same issue as me on the internet, only very similar situations where an update would make the mice not connect properly and would not move the cursor, but the lights would still work. I've uninstalled everything from Logitech and had no sucess.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2021
review.title: HEAR ME OUT FIRST
review.review: I purchased this product (March 14,2020) at the start of the Corona Pandemic. (Take note of this)I have medium size hands and its the most comfortable mouse up to date, there is a discomfort feeling at the bottom of my thumb where the mouse has a small "hedge" after 7+ hours of using the mouse. Apart from everything else I love the mouse from the button location and length to the infinite spinning wheel or manual wheel even to the customization of the color and DPI.Now you're thinking, why would this product have 2 stars? Well simply put, I have pets and one of my munchkins is known for biting wires, so it would be logical to invest in a Bluetooth mouse for this and apart from gaming as well. The problem I have with this mouse is that the Bluetooth is completely miss for me! I cannot say the same for others. Now I figured it may have been a lemon or so and I contacted support through Logitech on JULY of 2020, and from all the steps I've taken to ensure it was a lemon product, I received a confirmation that I would have a replacement, due to Corona I did not receive an email from them when they would eventually be in stock. Fast forward to Late January of 2021 I decided that my mouse needed to be replaced ASAP. I NEED my Bluetooth connectivity so I had a chat with the same representative from the start and I wanted to compromise with something of the same value or greater, which I was more than happy to pay and they decided to send me a Logitech G903 which IS NOT THE SAME VERSION BUT A NEWER MODEL. And So I was happy with this compromise, I as well couldn't return the defected one which is understandable to a degree, but that didn't stop me from wanting to know the problem of the continuous Bluetooth disconnection. A few weeks pass and I receive the newer mouse in a white box which wasn't the same as a new box; though the representative didn't say if it was new or not so I didn't care at the end of the day. There wasn't visible use of the mouse (no fingerprints, plastic still protecting the bottom, all parts included) after a week of Bluetooth use the problems persisted.-Using Bluetooth will make the mouse turn on and off which makes the cursor reappear in a new spot(this was annoying when I would play videogames and the constant sounds going on and off as well)-The battery wasn't accurate as well, I would have to charge it for an hour or more to see it fully charge and have the Bluetooth fail on me again. I would figure Problem 1 and 2 went hand in hand.-Yes I did try both mice on different Laptops/PC's and still had the same problem.-Yes I've done everything in my power to test the adapter as well, from different ports to disabling NVIDIA settings etc.Now you're thinking I'm not considering buying this mouse. I couldn't agree more, BUT I did love Logitech's customer support, and this Logitech G900/G903 will not steer me away from their other mice I will consider buying in the future. As of now I'm stuck with two defected devices and back to my old two button, 1996 ball movement mouse.
product.title: Logitech G900 Chaos Spectrum Professional Grade Wired/Wireless Gaming Mouse, Ambidextrous Mouse

review.title: Logitech mice are going downhill
review.review: I have been buying Logitech mice for over 10 years. While I'd had problems in the past, this mouse has taken the cake. The battery had a pretty disappointing life from the beginning, and problems have gradually accumulated over the years.First the scroll wheel broke - switching into "infinite scroll" mode no longer works unless you turn the mouse upside down to press the button, and even then it clicks loudly and stops scrolling quickly.More recently, I've started to have the left mouse button click twice when I only press it once. Looking around online, this seems to be a problem with cheap D2F switches used in these models. This was absolutely NOT worth the $104 dollars I paid for it with tax, and I would highly recommend that everyone consider companies other than Logitech for their mice.

review.title: A fantastic value but NOT easily serviceable.
review.review: These are such a good value for a D5 pump/Res combo with RGB and included horizontal and vertical mounting brackets. However they made it so incredibly difficult to disassemble and clean it that I just can't recommend it. If you are getting into custom water cooling you should know that maintenance and cleaning is part of it and the design of this unit is absolutely not conducive to that. It's built like they don't want the end user taking it apart.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: 2021 Review – CORSAIR is simply Beautiful
review.review: First, I never show my enthusiast build – because it’s like restoring an old muscle car = a masterpiece and constant work in progress. The expense and headache never end (7 years now). The exception to the rule = Corsair’s XD7 water loop system. I must come out of the shadows with this thing.If you are on a budget = stop reading right now… go to the Financial Aid office and ask for money to support your bad computer habit (cuz you are in trouble dude).Even if this ‘work of art’ fails tomorrow, I will enjoy this moment. I give THANOS credit to the engineering and designers of this pump. It makes perfect sense and saves a lot of space in an EATX case (or perhaps smaller).Along with this unit – the picture shows the Corsair XC7 RGB (CPU cold plate) and the Corsair XG7 RGB (GPU water block / cold plate). And I never thought I would be staring at my own …. for three days without blinking my eyes. (see photo)Tech Specs:> The XG7 (Rev B) is a perfect fit for my EVGA 2080 XC – which is a reference card (meaning NVIDIA gives the reference and EVGA slaps two fans and a shroud over the …..) If your card is bigger than a reference size (10.5 inches long) – then you will likely shed tears finding the correct block (sorry). The problem for many is thickness (like capacitors and extra cooling junk).> The XC7 is a perfect fit for my Intel socket LGA 1200 processor (or any other); Corsair gives you the back plate and spring-loaded screws which can be mounted to where they don’t flop around on install.Advice:Remember: this is just a water pump with pretty lights and outrageous plumbing. The rest is up to you and extensive research. I had to watch several YOUTUBE videos that didn’t teach me nothing about setting up a custom loop (good for reference only or nothing at all). Takes a bit of time…But I know one rule = buy two of everything you can’t find at WALMART or BESTBUY. I needed (12) compression fittings (which come 4 to a box). I needed (2) 90-degree fittings. I did the calculations before I started. Surprisingly, the Corsair hose and coolant (1000 ml) was enough to do the entire build (can’t waste nothing testing).Hope this helps…

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: Loud, unreliable, and poorly made product
review.review: I have used Corsair products for a long time, so I was expecting a quality item like the peripherals I trust. However, this cooler was an extreme let-down to the point where I won't let any Corsair AIO coolers near my rig again. Here's the skinny:- The install was very frustrating. The radiator I received had holes that were very poorly tapped, with a large amount of metal shavings obstructing the threads. It was so bad that even the right sized Philips bit would torque right out of the head rather than threading it in, I nearly punctured the radiator just trying to thread in the screws thanks to this.- The cooler isn't that effective when it does work, the laughably poorly designed fans cavitate something awful all the time. This means it's annoyingly loud at idle and completely deafening under any load.- The software is AWFUL. I have a lot of experience with iCue; It's a great program for tuning the functionality of non-mission-critical PC components. Its reliability is spotty at best though, it tends to crash every once in a while when it's in the background tray. The buggy software combined with the complete necessity of the AIO pump running is a recipe for disaster.- To further elaborate, this cooler needs to plug into a USB header on the mobo to work, and the computer considers it a USB device after you boot up. But then every time iCue crashes, the software control of the AIO fails too, meaning the pump will briefly shut off. The USB connect also means every other USB connected device will also be disconnected from the computer, meaning it starts to overheat and you can't do anything to stop it short of yanking the power cord.- The fix for the above issue is to *wait for it* update the firmware through iCue. To do this, you click a button in the software and it does its thing. Except, it actually doesn't, it just shuts off the AIO completely while waiting for a response that will never come and you get to watch your CPU rapidly cook itself alive. I saw my core temp soar to 105 C before I pulled the plug. Looking online, this is clearly a common issue and the only solution is to contact Corsair support and wait for them to bail you out.I had the foresight to save my old cooler to re-install in case this went bad, and boy did it ever.Corsair, if you're reading this, I'm really disappointed with this cooler and my half-baked CPU is too.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - Corsair iCUE H100i RGB Pro XT, 240mm Radiator

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.title: Refurbished with a loose screw jammed in the scroll wheel
review.review: The mouse arrived with something loose rattling inside, which turned out to be a loose screw underneath the scroll wheel. It'll get jammed in the scrollwheel while scrolling. There's no space to remove the screw without disassembling the mouse, which can't be done without removing the adhesive sliding pads on the bottom.The mouse design and comfort is okay; seems to get a little warm, and I'm not sure if it's just from my palm, or heat from the LEDs inside. I had planned on disabling the LEDs, but I'm now finding out that the corsair rgb control drivers (called iCUE) are 700 megabytes.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2020
review.title: Great mouse, as advertised
review.review: Was a bit wary going in buying a renewed product, but there was no need. Mouse and 3 grip attachments came safely packaged in great condition. People have complained about the iCUE software, but I don't find it too difficult so long as you do a little bit of research to help yourself out. One important note on that; you can change both the "hardware actions/lighting" settings (the default behavior of the lights and programmable buttons when iCUE is NOT running, and have to be saved to the mouse when changed) and the regular "actions/lighting" settings (those that take over when iCUE is running, and you can set up different profiles to switch between). The nice thing is you can customize the mouse to your liking and have those settings saved without having iCUE running, or if you need the mouse to be able to adapt to different programs/games etc... you can leave iCUE running and it'll take care of it without needing to re-open the settings and adjust each time.When it comes to the mouse itself, I'm enjoying it so far. Mouse wheel has nice texture and is very responsive, and the two side buttons are in a great spot depending on your grip; and if you prefer one over the other depending on your grip you can easily customize them. On that, it's worth noting; the two side buttons default to serving as the "back" and "forward" features when navigating the internet which is a nice feature, but you can easily change it if you like. The two buttons in front of the mouse wheel are labelled as the DPI buttons and their default function changes between different DPI levels; however you can also remap these buttons in the same way.The lighting customization is a bit tricky to figure out only because of how many options there are. I'm content with just 1 or 2 solid lights, but the combinations are extensive. Also of note is that the 5 lit bars on the top indicate the DPI profiles you can switch between, and the lighting settings for them is separate in the DPI section of iCUE. The one common complaint I've seen noted is that the lights tend to get warm, but I've found that turning the brightness of the lighting down in the general iCUE settings has prevented this issue so far for me.I have generally larger hands and the mouse fits me reasonably well. I used to use a wrist rest for my mouse but, again depending on the grip, I have found the mouse just as, if not more, comfortable to use without the wrist rest. I don't really have a "go-to" grip so to speak, but so far I'd say I've favored a fingertip grip thus far, and is just as comfortable with a full palm grip; the mouse has a very ergonomic shape if this is what you favor, I find it very comfortable.Very important but also quite silly, there is plastic over all the pads on the bottom of the mouse and the bottom of the largest grip attachment... but the plastic is so thin and subtle that I didn't notice them at first. Once one of them started to roll up on the bottom and I then peeled them all off the mouse felt much smoother.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Great Comfortable Mouse But Doesn't Last
review.review: I'm about to purchase my 4th of this mouse after only having it for 6 months and only really giving it 2 months of intensive use.The first thing to go is always the scroll wheel (6 months - 1 year). I'm a heavy scroll-wheeler. The grip on the scroll wheel eventually detaches from the actual wheel that actually registers the action. It starts to loosen slowly at first, so scrolls seem delayed or slow or just somehow off, until they stop working entirely. In the past I've also had left click stop working after about 1 year of intensive use. That's always a nightmare because who keeps a spare mouse lying around?I would look for a more reliable mouse but Corsair got the ergonomics so perfect on this one that I'm hesitant to start buying random mouses until I find another one at this level, while also hoping that that different one will last longer than 6 months.So instead here I am ordering my 4th one. Pick up your game Corsair! I'm willing to pay double this price if it means a mouse that lasts at least 2 years.

The LED runs surprisingly hot, as well. Hot enough you could use it as a hand warmer in cold winter months.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2021
review.title: OK... Meeses are subjective...
review.review: Whether a mouse costs $10 or $200, is rated 1 Stars or 5 Stars is entirely determined by user preference and perceived ergonomics of said mouse.I have run the gambit of pointing devices including trackballs cheap and expensive.When my beloved Mad Catz Pro, The Authentic R.A.T mouse finally died after years of hard toiling and when the mourning period of its death was over I considered another brand. I had used Corsair products before and was very satisfied was their quality and in my mouse search found this little "gem" the CorsairGlaive PRO.I guess at 67 years old I need a more conservative-looking mouse instead of one that looks at home on a Klingon battlecruiser. Not saying the Glaive PRO is a "grandpa" mouse as it delivers great performance and is easy on the pocketbook. Durability will be the big unknown in this purchase as I have never owned a Corsair mouse. So far it is proving to be a very good value. Though not a Mad Catz with an assortment of accessories including customizable weights to get that ultimate "gamer" feel the Corsair Glaive PRO doesn't cost $200+ either which is enough to make any Grandpa smile. It does have three thumb rest pieces that attach securely magnetically, however. Your comfort will be entirely determined by how "happy" your hand feels using it, no two people are exactly the same.The Glaive is very comfortable as I use the larger (wider) thumb rest and the software offered at Corsair's website works admirably.Arthritis in my fingers frequently causes me to press the right button with my middle finger as my index presses the left button inadvertently this affliction of advancing years is mediated with the Corsair Glaive's rounded drop off at the front. I still miss the metal body construction of the Mad Catz (it was built like a tank) and will for some time to come but it's a minor adjustment as the Corsair Glaive is filling in quite nicely.
product.title: Corsair Glaive PRO - RGB Gaming Mouse - Comfortable & Ergonomic - 18,000 DPI Optical Sensor - Black & MM800 Polaris Mouse ...

Die 2. lieferung einen Kabelschaden hatte (siehe Fotos) habe ich bei der dritten Lieferung lediglich ein Fingergrip teil welches schlecht verarbeitet wurde gehabt. Amazonhat alle Kosten übernommen und ich habe die Garantie völlig ausschöpfen können wenn etwas nicht gepasst hat. Alles in einem ist es ne echt geile Maus ;) eben ein Ergonomisches Massenprodukt, MIT menschlichen Fehlern, welche aber sofort wahrgenommen und ausgetauscht werden. 4 Sterne.

review.review_data: Reviewed in France on July 30, 2021
review.title: Originale et précise
review.review: Les souris Corsair, rarement déçu. La Glaive RGB Pro est vachement bien pour un prix correcte. Le capteur est hyper réactif, le corps de la souris (version alu) est solide, sa craque pas, c'est bien ajusté. Le revetement doux est agréable, la molette large et silencieuse, et semble bien robuste. RGBPas trop invasif mais bien présent qui donne un look très sympa. Possibilité d'ajuster le repose pouce selon 3 pièces amovibles, bien pratique. Le cable est tressé et assez rigide, sans plus. La prise en main est bonne et polyvalente. Usage jeu ou Web, vous serez à l'aise. La taille est bonne pour une main plutôt 19/20 cm(perso), mais les plus grandes mains y trouveront leur bonheur aussi. Du matos sans fioritures mais qui est à l'aise partout. Une bien bonne surprise que cette Glaive !

review.review_data: Reviewed in Germany on July 24, 2021
review.title: Grundsätzlich gute Maus, jedoch mit ein paar Problemen
review.review: Nachdem meine refurbished Razer Naga Trinity nach 2 1/2 Jahren begannt manchmal einfach die Klicks auf der linken Maustaste nicht mehr zu akzeptieren, hatte ich mich nach einer neuen Maus für zuhause umgeschaut. Mir ging es hierum, dass ich anfangen wollte von jedem Hersteller die Peripheriegeräte zu testen, weil ich eigentlich immer nur Razer oder Logitech hatte. Mein Arbeitskollege empfohl mir Corsair.TL:DRPros:- gutes Preis-Leistungsverhältnis- modular wechselbare Daumenablagen- gutes Gewicht und gute Größe (für manche vllt etwas zu leicht)Cons:- Mausrad wirkt nicht wirklich hochwertig- DPI-Knöpfe zu leicht auslösbar- wird sehr schnell heiß, wenn die LEDs an sind (nur über Software ausschaltbar)Ich habe sie für 70€ erworben und für diesen Preis finde ich die Qualität grundlegend gut, die Glaive fühlt sich gut an, ist weder zu schwer noch zu leicht für mich (andere würden sagen, dass sie zu leicht ist) und bietet durch die auswechselbaren Module an der linken Seite der Maus auch ein gutes Gefühl für den Daumen. Die Knöpfe der Maus selber fühlen sich gut an, jedoch sind die DPI-Knöpfe zu leicht zu drücken, weshalb manchmal schon simples streichen über sie, diese auslöst. Der zweite eher unschöne Teil der Maus ist, dass wenn die LEDs auf angeschaltet sind, dass diese Maus sehr schnell warm wird und man dann schwitzige Hände bekommt.Alles in allem jedoch eine gute Maus!

review.title: First Thoughts
review.review: I've been using a G702 for many years now, and the switches were starting to go, so it was time to upgrade. Well, seeing reviews and knowing some people using this I decided to get it, so I got it and I can say that it's nice, but I like the G702 a lot better.My biggest grip, and this is what seems to be just on the one I got, but the textured covering over the weights is dragging on the mouse pad, which means that the skatez on this mouse are too short. It's an easy fix to just go out and buy new skatez, but, for a new product, I should have to just yet.Other things I am not a fan of is this mouse is good for smaller hands, I feel. Also, the definition between the buttons are not very defined, and I feel you can easily click the wrong button. If the mouse was a little wider, I think it would be a bit more comfortable.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2021
review.title: Didn't expect would be that good
review.review: This is the kind of product you are not sure you really need until you get it and wonder how you could manage to live without it. With all the not so good reviews, especially about the screen, I hesitated for a long time before to buy it but when I got some money as a gift from a aunt I decided to try it.First of all, the device looks very good quality and it sticks very well to my K95. The buttons and widgets are easy to setup with iCUE and you can configure them as you like (color, size, background image, etc.). You can only set 6 buttons per screen but you can set as many screens as you want and it's easy to switch between them by swiping with your finger. I switched from a two monitors setup to a single 32" one a year ago and I was missing very much to be able to monitor my temperatures while gaming without having to run some overlay programs. Turns out that thing does it wonderfully well.Unlike some other people said I didn't notice any increase of CPU usage after I connected it (but maybe it's because my Ryzen 5900x just doesn't feel it).About the screen, it's true that if you look at it from an angle you don't see anything anymore but... this thing is not supposed to be looked at from a 45 degree angle. It is supposed to be watched when you are in front of your keyboard and when you do that it's amazingly clear and bright. My only negative point is that the touch functionality when you press a button is not always super reactive but I realize that it works fine if you aim more toward the bottom of the screen instead of the top. In that way it works just fine.Overall, it's an expansive device but for me it worth it. Really awesome gadget to have in your setup.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - Corsair iCUE NEXUS Companion Touch Screen – 5” Diagonal Screen – 6 Programmable Virtual Macro Buttons – Liv...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2021
review.title: Corsair doesn't disappoint.
review.review: Knew what I was getting into with this one. I've been gaming with Corsair products for about 2 years now. Thr only exception being my mouse I finally kicked the Logitech G602 that I've been using for 5+ yrs. The wire is high quality braided like all of their other devices. The software is simple and user friendly. The weights and software customization are incredible I like a heavy mouse and super low DPI for shooters with a high polling rate and this m65 is perfect. Just the right amount of buttons for the type of gaming I do.If you are a WOW or DOTA player you may find this lacking but this mouse is for FPS and other shooters. The sniper button is INCREDIBLY useful. I though of it more as a gimmick at first but no it makes such a huge difference in the fine aiming for high zoom weapons or vehicles.As far as ergonomics I have fairly large hands and it fits great. The thumb rest keeps your hand on the mouse and off the pad to make for smooth movement and less drag and the ability to change the weight is more valuable than I first assumed.I picked this up on sale and I think the price point is very fair for what you are getting. If you are on the fence, go for it! That said I love Corsair, I run the K70, Void wireless Pro and now the M65 none of which have ever let me down.

review.title: 2 modes are great in this mouse.
review.review: The pros - this mouse has a pretty good battery life, it can be plugged in or wireless and the wireless charging is a nice feature. Corsairs software is top notch and you can adjust the settings on the fly and even set up profiles for what apps you have running. Indicator lights work well and it has enough buttons to do normal FPS gaming and surfing options.The con, and this is unfortunately a fairly large one, I get a hair of lag when its wireless, meaning wireless mode is not ideal for FPS gaming, or really any gaming. So I frequently operate it wirelessly when I'm just surfing the net and stuff but if I'm going to play I plug it in.This might be my setup creating an issue, my tower does sit 4 feet from the mouse, the drawers for the desk are between the mouse and its receiver so these are all things that could be the cause and that I'll try and tweak down the road but it is something I am experiencing so figured fair warning to anyone else who may have a similar set up.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review.title: Overall, A Great Mouse
review.review: The mouse itself gets 3 stars. Ergonomics are pretty good, but I find myself sometimes accidentally tapping the thumb buttons or the adjustment buttons under the mouse wheel. The mouse wheel developed a squeak after a month or two. The LEDs are obnoxious, unless you turn them down or off. Which you can do, but that brings us to the software.You must install the Razer apps in order to configure the mouse. You must register to Razer's site and log on via the app. Sometimes, the app forgets your login for some reason (I assume after an update), and you have to log in again. But the updates are the real problem. There are many, many software updates. When there's a new update, every time you log in to your computer, even after waking it of sleep, the big neon green Razer Central screen jumps out at you to tell you that there are app updates. "Fine", you think, "I'll just disable auto updates"'. There's even an option to do so in the settings. The problem? It. Doesn't. Work. It will keep on pestering you every single time they release some update, which happens every week or two. And what's worse, every update requires a reboot. If you don't reboot? It will keep pestering you. Disable the Razer services? The big Razer logo on the mouse will glow a bright, neon green. I've seen discussions on the forums about what firewall ports to disable in order to prevent Razer's apps from phoning home, but that's really way more trouble than I'm willing to go through for a mouse.Simply the worst experience with software I can remember in a very long time. The mouse itself is okay, but just not worth the hassle. I'm looking for something better - and NOT by Razer.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2021
review.title: Corsair please use some better switches
review.review: As others have mentioned my previous Corsair Scimitar had issues with the left mouse button giving phantom double clicks after about a year of use. I figured I was just unlucky and grabbed another because I really like the design of the mouse and how it feels in my hand. However, I am already having issues with this mouse giving the double click issue as well, this time with the right mouse button. I've had this one for even less time than the previous. For something that costs 80 dollars this really isn't acceptable and I will be switching to a different brand for my next one.Also, iCue is the worst software package I have ever used, and is basically required to get any sort of functionality out of the mmo buttons on the side.The Logitech mmo mouse (G600) while not looking nearly as attractive lasted me for about 5 years before I finally gave it to a friend after picking up my first Scimitar. He's still using that mouse. It also comes in at half the price and has a "better" software setup. Not that Logi's is amazing either, but it's far better than iCue. Personally, I will probably pick up another of these because I'd rather have something that lasts than something that looks nice and fails in such a short time period.https://www.amazon.com/Logitech-Gaming-Backlit-Programmable-Buttons/dp/B0086UK7IQ/

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2021
review.title: Trash
review.review: I can't believe I have to write something bad about a new mouse. I've had a sharkoon mouse since 2014 and now it hurts my fingers to click. So I bought this crosair mouse. I didn't buy it because I'm left handed. I got it because of the two right side buttons. I'm not sure why gaming mouses don't have right side buttons. So basically I got this mouse for the buttons.I play 3 different action MMORPGs with action combat, using mouse clicks for skills.The left side buttons are so faulty and trash. There's friction between my finger and the mouse skills popping off when I click.This mouse was not designed for gaming... The left side buttons are too far forward and flimsy. It does not feel like I'm pressing a button, more like reaching for something unsecured and difficult to push.The clickers need to pressed rather than lightly touched. I find this to be harder to deal with ... Think about slamming your hand flat on a table, this is what it feels like to press the clickers.Something more annoying than the buttons is the failure to load. Sharkoon always loads, crosair does not.I have had to restart computer, unplug and replug, even loaded the ique software. Why? Because the mouse DOES NOT COME ON.. A few times it shut off completely. Unable to scroll and lost cursor...Do you know how ANNOYING this is?I like to have a mouse with right side buttons... But honestly my old sharkoon is waaay better!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Mouse is lagging all the time
review.review: I ordered this mouse because I wanted to switch to wireless mouse experience. I really like this mouse, nice and comfortable design and it fits perfectely in my hand with my claw grip.The only thing that keeps me back to give it 5 stars is the wireless modes. when I switch to 2.4GHz Slipstream wireless mode I get so much lags every 5 seconds which is awful for gaming, you just can't play games like this. When I switch to Bluetooth mode the amount of lags decrease but not completely and you can't controll the RGB lightning when using Bluetooth mode.I have to use the wired mode for smooth experience.UPDATE: I connected the 2.4GHz Slipstream receiver to the front panel and I have 0 lags, also can't notice any lags in bluetooth mode anymore.Advice: Don't connect the Slipstream receiver to the back of your PC and you won't get any lags.

review.title: Great mouse at first, but structurally weak
review.review: I've owned two Corsair Harpoons in the last couple of years. Both lasted under six months.I've given a rating of two stars, although four to five would be fair if it wasn't for the poor durability.There seems to be an inherent structural flaw. Both of them cracked on the left mouse button, near the scroll wheel. With the first a chunk of plastic broke off a couple of weeks after the crack appeared, and the second looks like it's heading the same way.Edit: I've upped the score to a three, which is maybe a little more fair, given that these are pretty cheap for a gaming mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: TERRIBLE. Scroll Wheel WILL Start to Squeak and Fail After 3 Months.
review.review: For the first few months, it was good. Everything worked as it should. The cord was not a problem and extended long enough to reach my tower. I enjoyed having two buttons on the side for gaming purposes. The mouse fits nicely in your hand. The scroll wheel and the design light up a pretty white hue. Aesthetically pleasing and matches my white set-up.BUT. After 3 months, just this past September, the scroll wheel started to make this OBNOXIOUS screeching sound every time I scrolled. I didn't realize how much I scroll until this started to happen. It was ear aching and I looked up how to fix it, saw that MANY others with this mouse had a similar problem, and the fix requires you to dissemble the whole thing to oil it. I am not savvy with that so I left it alone in hopes that it would just go away with time.Well the squeaking has reduced but now everytime I attempt to scroll, it causes my window to jitter and scroll back the OPPOSITE way. So here I am battling with my mouse to scroll smoothly for just a couple inches. It's the most frustrating thing I've experienced with a mouse and I've finally given up and am purchasing a different one. I never had a mouse that couldn't even last a single year... this is a poor product in my opinion.

review.title: Don't Get Too Excited....
review.review: If you think you're gonna be crushin' with this mouse, think again. The ergonomics of this mouse has you holding it downward to hold on to it. The thumb/side buttons are SOOOOO close, you'll eventually hit both when your intentions are to only hit one, thusly accidently using that feature if you've mapped anything to them. It's very, very lightweight which didn't instill confidence in playing a character for which you had to keep moving. Yes, I am spoiled by my OLD Logitech G302 and after using this Razer DeatchAdder Essenetial for the past 2 weeks, it's going back.*IF* you're starting out and looking for a DECENT Gaming Mouse, then this might be for you, considering the price, but I've lost far too many battles because of the side/thumb buttons being too close together.

It's an easy fix to just go out and buy new skatez, but, for a new product, I should have to just yet.Other things I am not a fan of is this mouse is good for smaller hands, I feel. review.title: Cool RGB mouse, don't care about other features though
review.review: First of all the RGB on this mouse is slick.I has the DeathAdder Chroma (which was old, and the RGB didn't work with Synapse 3), but I loved the feel of it.This mouse had that similar feel, I actually may like this mouse's feel more than the DeathAdder and I'm happy with my decision for this mouse over the DeathAdder 2.I normally stick with what is familiar, and glad I broke out of my comfort zone.It glides easily across my desk and the DPI adjustable thing which I rarely ever use is still nice to have in case I ever need it.I do like you can reprogram the buttons (and those thumb buttons I have surprisingly found good uses for).One thing I'll say is the right mouse button sometimes gets accidentally pressed.Could be my long Diablo 3 constant clicking that my hand just hits the mouse button on accident frequently, but resting my hand on the mouse I don't feel it should be that easy that accidentally clicking occurs.So would have been 5 star, but subtracted half a star for those weird accidental mouse clicks.Subtracted another half only because it's not wireless for this price!

review.title: Left-Click Stopped Working After A Few Months
review.review: I purchased this mouse for light gaming and typical web browsing. Within 6 months, I noticed the left-click was not holding down correctly. Physically it felt fine, but it was basically unplayable in games. I tried every solution and the problem only got worse over time so I figured it was a hardware problem rather than a software issue. I took great care of the mouse and used it VERY lightly yet it still gave out quickly. Not to mention the Razer Synapse program is terrible. Unfortunately for me, the company that sold me the product through Amazon, "TECHLOBBY", is not an authorized seller of Razer products so the 2 year manufacturers warranty did NOT cover this issue. On Razer's website, Amazon is an authorized seller of Razer products but many of the companies that sell through Amazon are not so it is very misleading. This mouse is no longer manufactured by Razer so don't even bother buying it. For $50, this mouse became useless after a few months of light use, DO NOT RECOMEND.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.
product.title: Corsair Nightsword RGB - Comfort Performance Tunable FPS/MOBA Optical Ergonomic Gaming Mouse with Backlit RGB LED, 18000 D...
