review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Good mouse, no doubt about it, but beware if you have larger hands
review.review: First of all I'll preface by saying that I'm unsure if the issue of my assigned keybinds resetting was an issue of ICUE software or if it's an issue with Windows 11. Either way, it's something to be noted that there's the possibility of your ICUE software resetting or scrambling your assigned keybinds when you reboot your PC. This issue won't affect the score I gave it since I can't pinpoint the exact cause of it.What will affect it however, is it's size. For a gaming mouse, the form factor is surprisingly small. I wear a medium/large size glove and this mouse was exceptionally uncomfortable if you're using it for it's defining feature: the programmable buttons on the left. In my natural mouse grip, my thumb rests on the frontmost row of buttons, making 123/456 the easiest to access. The 789 row just behind it is a bit uncomfortable to reach. The 10/11/12 row is very difficult without shifting my hand back on the mouse or curling my thumb too far inward, which is unnatural for me personally and made using the mouse significantly more difficult than I had previously expected. And yes, this is with the number buttons slid as far to the front as I could with the adjustment screw.Additionally, the buttons themselves are very small and feature very little textural difference to help distinguish them besides some very light texturing on alternating rows. Pressing multiple buttons or pressing the wrong button is very common, more common than I would like. Between the buttons being small, being hard to distinguish one from the other, and having larger hands make utilizing the full potential of this mouse extremely difficult.Finally, the left and right clickers are very light. The weight of my middle finger alone is enough to cause the right clicker to go off.My verdict is that the mouse is potentially very good, especially if your hands are on the smaller side. Gamers with larger hands might find this mouse uncomfortable to use if you prefer to choke up on the mouse like I do. I wouldn't *not* recommend it, but I would definitely keep the size of the mouse itself and the buttons in mind when making the recommendation.
product.title: Corsair Scimitar RGB Elite, MOBA/MMO Gaming Mouse, Black, Backlit RGB LED, 18000 DPI, Optical

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Great moust until it craps out
review.review: So I loved this mouse when it got it back in April 2020. However it has been a year and a half since I purchased this mouse and I am having multiple hardware issues. The scroll wheel when scrolling down will some times just start scrolling up and vice versa when scrolling down. This wasn't horrible and I could work around this. However, less than 3 days later the left mouse button started failing to work. I have to now click the left mouse button 3 to 4 times to get it to register much like my Razer started doing before I purchased this mouse. If i blow under the left mouse button it starts working again for a few minutes but once the static charge builds back up, it starts failing again. For this price I feel like the mouse should at least last a few years. I would say take you money and get a logitech and safe yourself the headache.
product.title: Corsair Scimitar RGB Elite, MOBA/MMO Gaming Mouse, Black, Backlit RGB LED, 18000 DPI, Optical

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: Serious software problems
review.review: As others have mentioned, this mouse has serious software issues. It's a shame because I used it successfully for a little over a month and it was a great mouse, but the software issues have started to manifest, and now the mouse does not appear within the software at all (as shown in screenshot). Not only does this mean that all of the buttons no longer programmable, but also all of the customization that I had is lost as well. This effectively turns this mouse into a high-DPI two-button mouse. Customer support has basically been useless to solve this problem, and I'm not expecting resolution so I'll have to find something else. I do hope they eventually solve these issues, because it really is great hardware, but at least as of October 2021 it's not yet resolved. (And just to be clear - I'm a software developer myself with a lot of experience in driver development, so I do not believe this is simply user error, especially given the number of other people encountering these problems.)
product.title: Corsair Scimitar RGB Elite, MOBA/MMO Gaming Mouse, Black, Backlit RGB LED, 18000 DPI, Optical

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review.title: LMB issue on day one -- disappointment
review.review: The left mouse button seems to be a common failing point with these mice. I ordered this mouse to replace a failing mouse I currently own. Day one I notice something is off with the left click of the mouse. There is a noticeable difference between left and right click sound and tactile feedback back while clicking. Right clicking provides a nice click sound and feel, while, left clicking is "soft" and sometimes I can't even tell when I am clicking. Sometimes it didn't even register a click. It is almost like they are using different switches.I returned it after one day. $80 for a mouse that doesn't have consistency on day one is not worth it and I wouldn't trust it to last years to come. I would have given it 1 star except I have other Corsair products that I love and have had for years without any issue.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2021
review.title: Trash
review.review: I can't believe I have to write something bad about a new mouse. I've had a sharkoon mouse since 2014 and now it hurts my fingers to click. So I bought this crosair mouse. I didn't buy it because I'm left handed. I got it because of the two right side buttons. I'm not sure why gaming mouses don't have right side buttons. So basically I got this mouse for the buttons.I play 3 different action MMORPGs with action combat, using mouse clicks for skills.The left side buttons are so faulty and trash. There's friction between my finger and the mouse skills popping off when I click.This mouse was not designed for gaming... The left side buttons are too far forward and flimsy. It does not feel like I'm pressing a button, more like reaching for something unsecured and difficult to push.The clickers need to pressed rather than lightly touched. I find this to be harder to deal with ... Think about slamming your hand flat on a table, this is what it feels like to press the clickers.Something more annoying than the buttons is the failure to load. Sharkoon always loads, crosair does not.I have had to restart computer, unplug and replug, even loaded the ique software. Why? Because the mouse DOES NOT COME ON.. A few times it shut off completely. Unable to scroll and lost cursor...Do you know how ANNOYING this is?I like to have a mouse with right side buttons... But honestly my old sharkoon is waaay better!

review.title: There is a bug with the Sabre that causes the cursor to jump to the corner of the screen.
review.review: I purchased the 10k dpi sabre twice recently because I loved the ergonomics of my older sabre, but there's an issue with the new 10k's where my mouse cursor periodically skips to the corner of my screen, typically the bottom left, which makes gaming with it very frustrating. At first I thought it might be an issue with my particular mouse so I bought a second one and it also had the same problem. I also tried both of them on 3 different computers with different mouse pads and still had the issue every time.

review.title: Buen ratón, muy sencillo y preciso

Ahí ya cada uno lo que le convenga.El ratón en si es sencillo, tiene un tacto muy agradable y los botones sorprenden por lo precisos que son. Yo no lo uso para jugar, pero creo que se podría usar sin problema.Las lucecitas que tiene a mi no me molestan, pero es una moda un poco absurda, en mi opinión. En este caso es agradable, no molesta, aunque si no la llevase tampoco sería una tragedia.Tiene solo dos botones laterales que puedes configurar con la aplicación, pero yo apenas los uso por lo que no puedo comentar nada.Por último destacar la rueda, que si bien no es libre, para mi tiene un tacto muy agradable y rueda genial.La durabilidad, veremos, pero pinta bien.Yo le doy 5* y repetiria la compra al mismo precio.

review.title: Two buttons broke within 18 months of purchase

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2021
review.title: Corsair doesn't disappoint.
review.review: Knew what I was getting into with this one. I've been gaming with Corsair products for about 2 years now. Thr only exception being my mouse I finally kicked the Logitech G602 that I've been using for 5+ yrs. The wire is high quality braided like all of their other devices. The software is simple and user friendly. The weights and software customization are incredible I like a heavy mouse and super low DPI for shooters with a high polling rate and this m65 is perfect. Just the right amount of buttons for the type of gaming I do.If you are a WOW or DOTA player you may find this lacking but this mouse is for FPS and other shooters. The sniper button is INCREDIBLY useful. I though of it more as a gimmick at first but no it makes such a huge difference in the fine aiming for high zoom weapons or vehicles.As far as ergonomics I have fairly large hands and it fits great. The thumb rest keeps your hand on the mouse and off the pad to make for smooth movement and less drag and the ability to change the weight is more valuable than I first assumed.I picked this up on sale and I think the price point is very fair for what you are getting. If you are on the fence, go for it! That said I love Corsair, I run the K70, Void wireless Pro and now the M65 none of which have ever let me down.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review.title: Overall, A Great Mouse
review.review: The mouse itself gets 3 stars. Ergonomics are pretty good, but I find myself sometimes accidentally tapping the thumb buttons or the adjustment buttons under the mouse wheel. The mouse wheel developed a squeak after a month or two. The LEDs are obnoxious, unless you turn them down or off. Which you can do, but that brings us to the software.You must install the Razer apps in order to configure the mouse. You must register to Razer's site and log on via the app. Sometimes, the app forgets your login for some reason (I assume after an update), and you have to log in again. But the updates are the real problem. There are many, many software updates. When there's a new update, every time you log in to your computer, even after waking it of sleep, the big neon green Razer Central screen jumps out at you to tell you that there are app updates. "Fine", you think, "I'll just disable auto updates"'. There's even an option to do so in the settings. The problem? It. Doesn't. Work. It will keep on pestering you every single time they release some update, which happens every week or two. And what's worse, every update requires a reboot. If you don't reboot? It will keep pestering you. Disable the Razer services? The big Razer logo on the mouse will glow a bright, neon green. I've seen discussions on the forums about what firewall ports to disable in order to prevent Razer's apps from phoning home, but that's really way more trouble than I'm willing to go through for a mouse.Simply the worst experience with software I can remember in a very long time. The mouse itself is okay, but just not worth the hassle. I'm looking for something better - and NOT by Razer.
product.title: Corsair M65 PRO RGB Optical FPS Gaming Mouse (12000 DPI Optical Sensor, Adjustable Weights, 8 Programmable Buttons, 3-Zone...

review.title: Decent Mouse - but software issues and slightly lighter than I hoped.
review.review: After bouncing around from brand to brand - I picked this one up from Corsair - so I could reduce the amount of software needed on my machine to configure it (my case is Corsair as well).This mouse feels pretty good - and reasonably fits my larger-than-normal bear paws.It has replaceable thumb rest blocks - providing one with a wing, a thick one, and a slightly thinner one.The blocks are held on by magnets.Overall - my biggest issue with this is that the Corsair Cue software seems to stop responding randomly - fixed by reboots.When it stops responding, the mouse buttons on-board to load higher/lower DPI settings stops responding, and the custom settings that I have also stop working and a default profile seems to take over.This can be ridiculously frustrating when it happens mid-game.

Was unhappy with it but now I have a broken mouse that only works like a generic oem mouse. This mouse replaced a $10 7 button gaming mouse that lasted much longer. There was a time Corsair meant quality, clearly that time has passed.

NOTHING WILL FIX IT. I looked around different boards and it seems many people have had this issue and there is no solution.I feel like I bought a piece of trash that is now useless. Would not recommend buying. I have always had Logitech mice and am going back to them. review.title: Broke after a year and a half of frequent use. Poor drivers.
review.review: I frequently (6-8 hrs of the day) use these for computer use without the mic, and for games. The right side no longer works after a year and a half. I believe it has something to do with the volume. Drivers are pretty bad. It would "break" my discord audio and I would have to reset my audio devices a few times a day on occasion. Especially bad when using Overwatch's comm system at the same time. Updated the drivers and seemed to have less issues in the last month. Still the occasional issue from it.Surround sound honestly just makes the majority of sounds tinny, I didn't find a major benefit in this feature, even in a competitive setting. Not a bad headset overall, okay sound quality, doesn't slide off you head if you cough. Drivers really made the experience frustrating. Will be purchasing a different brand in the future because of this.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Good, But Could Be Better
review.review: I upgraded to this from the Corsair HS35 because I wanted a wireless headset so that I wouldn't have to remove the headset and miss out on stuff every time I had to step away.The order arrived completely intact and without incident the day after I placed my order.I tested it out immediately, and I have been using it consistently for about a week now.It definitely serves its intended purpose (to give me a wireless option).The range on it is pretty good.I am able to walk all around the ground floor of my house and even walk outside my front door to pickup deliveries and still maintain connection.However, sometimes the connection is spotty, regardless of how far away I am from my computer, including sometimes if I am sitting right in front of it.I notice that sometimes, as I am walking away from the computer, if I move to fast, it takes time for it to catch up, so it's kind of in-and-out.But whenever I have such connection issues, usually if I power it down, remove the dongle from the USB port, re-insert it, and turn the headphones back on, the connection issues disappear.Some other things that I dislike about this:1.Size:it is adjustable, but even at its smallest, it is still a little loose on my head (for reference, my hat size is 7 1/2, although that doesn't exactly translate to a headset).While the HS35 fits perfectly, because these are a little loose, the band doesn't sit on top of my head, so my ears are really the only thing supporting it, and pretty often I can feel it slipping down on my ears, so I have to adjust it.2.When I did some testing, the recordings I did with this mic were not as clear and crisp as the ones I did with the HS35 mic.The speakers, however, seem to be pretty comparable.Other than the freedom of a wireless headset, one thing that I did like about this is that it comes with it's own windscreen, which is pretty important to me because there is a lot of background noise in the room where I use it.The windscreen does a good job filtering out the background noise.And because it comes with one, it is a perfect fit.The HS35 did not come with one, so I had to by some separately (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01EJ0N5FS/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1), which do not fit perfectly, and fall off frequently.Overall, I am pleased with Corsair HS70.For the price, you will not find a better wireless headset.Overall, I like the HS35 better, but the freedom that the wireless HS70 provides is definitely enough to make it my primary headset for the time being.I am giving it 4 stars, but it's probably more like a 3.5.I went back and forth between 3 and 4, but in the end, I felt 3 was a little too harsh.So, yes.Four stars, but really more like a 3.5.
product.title: Corsair HS70 Pro Wireless Gaming Headset - 7.1 Surround Sound Headphones for PC, MacOS, PS5, PS4 - Discord Certified - 50m...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: GREAT Headset => CHEAP Quality Materials
review.review: I bought my first pair of these headsets back in early January of this year. Before the end-of-January, I had to send them back cut to a component failure. As shown in the pictures, they use a plastic cover piece to secure the headphones and hold them in place with metal screws going into plastic parts. As you adjust the headphones to your head (my wife & son share these) you are constantly re-adjusting to a comfortable fit. This is the problem. I just had my second pair fail, due to the same issue. Only this time around we were "on guard", to be extremely careful when adjusting. They failed on me today as I was on a TEAMS Chat conference call. The headset works fantastic. The features are great. Adjustable sound, mute, removable boom mike. All great and work fantastically. BUT, one of the most important components in the build is made from very thin, cheap, plastic. If they would spend just a little more money and use aluminum this problem would be cured. I will never buy another one of their products again. I am going to buy Brand-X or Y or anyone, who puts a little more quality into their product.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2021
review.title: Great potential with fatal flaws
review.review: I'm extremely disappointed in these headphones. I purchased them to replace another gaming headset thinking they might be more durable and because they offered some great features (wireless, surround sound, etc.). But there are some major issues that I can only imagine are due to firmware, which is currently at version 0.01: sound cuts out inexplicably, whether the headphones are connected by wire or wirelessly; voice announcements ("Mic on", "Mic off", etc.) occur arbitrarily; battery life is very poor; and charging seems to work only when the headphones are plugged in (wired) and powered on. The fact that firmware hasn't been updated from what is basically an alpha version indicates that Corsair created these headphones and then abandoned them, which unfortunately renders a potentially great headset almost useless.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2021
review.title: Too Complicated, and a waste of time and money.
review.review: The person that is writing this is actually a 12 year old who needed a headset for his pc. And this headset is a waste of time & money. First of all, It's actually a little heavy, which I was okay with, the bluetooth connection was fine but the audio is terrible. It doesn't even cancel any noise, the audio is hard to hear and breaks up sometimes, and the mic. The mic is flexible, which sounds good, but the mic doesn't even work itself. I wouldn't call it "Discord Certified" either because you get no audio at all. You can't hear anything or speak anything. The audio is bad, the comfort was ok, but overall it's the worst headset I have ever used. Total waste of money and I would have rather used wired ones that were too small for me. To whoever tends to buy this, don't. It's complicated and I would just buy from Razer.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Overall a headset for the value you are paying for!
review.review: I have been using it for a few days with Dolby Atmos enabled and overall, the sound on these things are quite nice with a equalized sound to it, if you get these make sure you download Dolby Access for the full experience on PC (I know more software you have to install along with Icue but Its worth trust me). But without it the sound eq settings were alright, but with the bass boost setting it somehow kills sound all together making it really quiet. So the EQ Settings are a bit buggy but I recommend Dynamic if you are just using base settings with out Atmos.Comfort is decent, I have a big head and at first it seemed like a tight fit so you defiantly will know it is there but to me it doesn't feel like it is pressing down to hard. The Cups feel really comfy and also fit nice around my fat ears! So overall not bad just gotta get use to it.Value, it seems spot on for the price but if you can get it on sale at some point it would honestly be a steal and if I find anything wrong with it or something I find that is bad later on about the product I will edit this review!
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Best microphone available on wireless headsets!
review.review: I've pretty much settled on this headset after countless reviews (namely, Hardware Canucks, few others). All of them had one undeniable thing in common - the microphone tests were outstanding! Absolutely no compression - clear, crisp voice recording.As the world moves more and more towards remote work and zooms/online presentations - having a good wireless microphone becomes very important. And the HS80 delivers it!All the other niceties one would expect from a quality Corsair product are there - very sturdy build, huge ear cups, very comfortable headrest with the adjustable strap - no pressure on the ears at all! Plus, I've spent some time playing with the Dolby Atmos software in Windows 10, switching between enhanced Movie and Music modes - and this actually helps a lot to experience surround sound like never before. Really impressive!Overall, definitely recommend these headphones for people looking for a great microphone and not at all obnoxious-looking "gaming" headset (where you can turn off the RGB logo in the software).
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2021
review.title: Amazing Sound Quality-Not so good battery life
review.review: The sound quality in these is absolutely amazing. The surround sound is unbelievable. Footsteps, gunshots and even just listening to music is an immersive experience. The battery life is more than cut in half if you plan to use the rgb functionality of these though. I find myself needing to plug them in after only a few hours.The iCue hub works effortlessly with these and the equalizer settings are almost limitless. The reverb setting makes your voice come across super clear with virtually no delay.Aside from the battery life, these are a 5/5 all day long. But the long charging cable gets it up to about a 4.5.
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2021
review.title: Average sound quality, quiet mic, not that comfortable
review.review: I bought into all the YouTube reviews hyping this headset. Bought a pair to see for myself and they didn’t meet expectations. Maybe it was due to all the reviews. The material and aesthetics are good and feel premium, but there were too many downsides for me to keep them.Out of the box sound quality is pretty average at best, with weak bass. Note, I never messed with the EQ settings so it's possible this can be fixed with some tweaking. Games might sound fine and if you don’t care about really good sound quality for anything else.Mic quality is actually really solid, but unfortunately really quiet. I’m sure you can increase it with some software, but Corsair should really fix that on their end. The red LED when the mic is in the mute position can get pretty distracting if on a video conference as there is no way to turn it off.For me, it wasn't super comfortable, although you can probably still wear them for long sessions without issues. I have a medium to large head and the strap is enough for me. It feels a bit too heavy and the clamping force is on the strong side.The on/off button has some issues. At times, it seems like the button doesn't register and you have to press and hold a couple of times on the right position. I even got a replacement thinking it was just that headset, but it had the same issue. I could have lived with it, if not for all the other issues.If you really just need a wireless headset with a good mic and are fine with everything else, this could work for you. I really wanted to like them, but for $150, I personally don’t think it’s worth it with all the downsides. If it was priced around $100, I might have kept them.
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2021
review.title: Very impressive!
review.review: If I’m being honest, the reviews almost had me running the other direction. I decided to take a leap and give them a shot anyway, and I’m glad I did! I’m a bit of an audiophile and usually rely on a dedicated amp/usb mic/audiophile cans for my gaming needs, but I wanted something wireless that I could also use on my ps5. I’ve tried many other headsets some of which included Jbl Quantum 800s, Steelseries Arctis 7ps, Audeze Penrose, and Beoplay Portals. Although, all of those are good headsets in their own right, something about them that caused me to lose interest and ultimately either return or even sell them for a loss. Generally it was either comfort, connection issues, low volume on console, or poor quality mic that was the leading culprit.Now the HS80s at $150 do everything right while managing to do nothing offensively wrong. They aren’t perfect by any means but what they manage to do at that price point is sound fantastic, have a stable connection, are extremely comfortable, and have the best wireless mic I have ever used. They also work seamlessly on PS5 and get so loud that no person using them would need to go higher than 60%.The only fault I can give these are due to software alone. For people that have used ICUE you already know the issues, but for people that haven’t, it can be particular and require some finesse to get everything working right. One issue I have is every time I turn them on they default to 8 channel audio regardless of them being set to stereo in ICUE. It’s not a huge deal you just go into your sound settings on windows and change it to 2 channel 24 bit 48khz and they sound amazing after that. If you forget you will be instantly made aware of your mistake when your audio sounds like your inside a fish bowl.
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review.title: Audio disconnect, not comfortable
review.review: I bought this pairs of headphone based on the tech reviewer from YouTube. I had high hope for this but so far I’m very disappointed.The bad:- audio disconnect frequently when gaming- wearing this with eyeglasses doesn’t feel comfortable- limited adjustment on headbandThe good:- mic quality is seriously goodI’ve thrown away the package so I couldn’t return it. And I really regret it
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2021
review.title: Narrow earcups and very quiet microphone
review.review: TLDR the audio is great with light tuning in the EQ and the microphone QUALITY is amazing, but the overall mic volume is too low for me, even with Windows settings maxed out, and the earcups are a tad narrow causing some constant light pressure along the back of my ear, especially if walking around.If the microphone volume was acceptable I could have lived with the earcups.The audio quality out of the box wasn't the best, the mids are a bit too strong and muddle the highs.Messing with the eq and raising the highs gave an amazing sound which is among the best in headsets at this price range, from my experience. The sound is a little richer and cleaner than what I get from my Arctis 7s.The cloth earcups do mean you miss a bit of the bass, but I didn't find the experience lacking since the mids were stronger and helped fill the gap.This headset doesn't offer any 3d audio or surround sound simulations.The microphone was probably the best and worst thing about this headset at the same time.For a wireless headset, the quality of this microphone is ASTOUNDING.I've used a Blue Yeti and AT2020USB as desk microphones in the past and on a purely quality review, this microphone is right there with them for anything but the purest audiophile.Where the microphone suffers is the volume.I'm unsure if my model was defective (due to other concerns below I didn't choose to replace to see and instead did a refund), but even with every mic setting I could find in Windows and the Corsair software maxed out, my friend had to set me to 200% in discord compared to my Arctis 1s or 7s at a normal 100%.If you plan to also use this as a work headset as well, the volume might not be great for zoom or teams calls.I did not test to see how much this microphone could be boosted in OBS capture for streaming.The fit of the headband support is great and the inside adjustments are good if slightly limited, but the earcups were a bit too narrow for me.The memory foam compresses nicely, but when work there was a mild constant pressure against the back of my ears.For normal sitting and gaming it was fine, but since it is wireless, getting up and walking around made it was noticeable for any tiny movements of the headset.Apart from the ears, the overall clamp and fit was perfect though - my Arctis 7 which uses a similar elastic strap system was always too loose for my head and slipped around heavily when walking or bending, but this never seemed at risk of sliding off.
product.title: CORSAIR HS80 RGB Wireless Premium Gaming Headset with Spatial Audio - Works with Mac, PC, PS5, PS4 - Carbon

review.title: Good for the Price
review.review: This product is not the best you can buy but for the price you definitely get the bang for your buck with these. Sound quality is good, pairing was relatively easy, mic quality very good. It does disconnect sometimes and the sound quality is not the best but with Dolby Atmos it is very good. Once I connected these to my computer and updated the firmware the disconnects seem to happen less often. I wish the pairing and on/off buttons were not the same button, it makes things a little confusing at first. I like the build quality and they are a lot more comfortable for my head than my OG Astro A50s. For sound quality I should have gone with the new Atros but I didn't want to spend too much money. Overall these are good.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2021
review.title: Some limitations on PC
review.review: I bought these to use with a PC and an Xbox wireless adapter which is where my rating comes from.Sound quality and mic quality seemed good.Comfort was great.I loved how these felt while I was wearing them.The earpads were thick and soft.Also, the thing I really liked about this headset when used with the wireless adapter is Windows 10 will recognize when you turn the headset on and change your speaker output to headphones and will switch it back to speakers when you turn the headset off again.This is not something easy to do with any other headset.However, when using this headset on a PC the volume of the headset resets every time you power cycle them.So, every single time you go to use it you have to adjust the volume.Also, the microphone monitoring (sidetone) turns back on if you have previously turned it off every time you power cycle the headset.These two issues are really annoying.There should be a memory setting to keep the volume and mic monitoring where you have it set.I understand mic monitoring can be a useful tool but I do not want to hear myself and my environment coming though my headphones.I am using them to chat in games occasionally and not to stream from or talk into for hours so I just don't want the mic monitoring active and it is annoying turning it off every time I use the headset.I am guessing these are not issues when using the headset on an Xbox but I am using it for PC which is supposed to be a supported use case.The 7.1 surround is even PC exclusive.Also, there is no equalizer settings or anything else you can change when using these on PC.Some of Corsair's cheaper headsets have equalizer settings you can change on PC in the icue software.The only thing you can do on PC with these is update the firmware.It is possible a future firmware could address these issues but I kind of doubt it as I am not sure they are even considered bugs.The reason I believe this is because the volume wheel on these is like an infinite wheel where there is no start or stop point.You can just turn it forever which means some sort of software or programming needs to keep track of where the volume is at rather than the position of the volume wheel like on other headsets.Anyway, there were some nice thing about this headset.The automatic speaker/headset switching is really nice in Windows.I wish all wireless headsets could do that but I believe it is because you are using the Xbox wireless adapter that makes it possible with these.Unfortunately, for the way I want to use a headset the volume and mic monitoring issues are not something I can live with.I would give this a 3.5 out of 5 if I could.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Super comfortable, great sound quality, relatively easy to set up.
review.review: I'm so glad I decided to just shell out the extra money for a good headset. Steelseries engine has preset equalizers. one is Flat, one is Voice, they sound like shit, as expected. but man, when you set the equalizer to Music? shiiiiiiiiiiit. these things sound incredible when you have some spotify blasting. just out of the box they sound good. but downloading the engine and trying different presets is nice.they're also super comfortable. the velcro makes it weird trying to find the right fit but it only takes 2 minutes of fidgeting around to find it. if that. the earpads are crazy soft and squishy, they feel great. I wear glasses too. no problem. they might feel weird at first, you just have to find the right fit with the velcro. they sit on your head and around your ears so seamlessly.the mic is basically what you would expect from a headset. it doesn't sound incredible but it's good for what you pay for. it's better than most i've heard.has a volume scroll wheel on the left ear to raise or lower your volume. very nice.its great,buy it.

review.review: I purchased this headset with a big leap of faith, and I've not been disappointed. I used to go through a new wired headset every year, and because of that, I decided to give this a try despite the vastly increased price point. To begin with, the sound quality of this headset is phenomenal and easily the same as the wired headsets that I've had in the past. Further, the headset is incredibly comfortable and I've sometimes forgotten that I've still got it on when I take a break after a long gaming session. Truly a product that I would recommend to friends and family if you can afford it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Mediocre pricey headset
review.review: I picked these up to replace a broken pair of Turtle beach Stealth 520s.The 520s were cheap <$100 and did the job as intended.Honestly I would prefer to go back with them,and not this Artis 7 headset.My biggest gripe is that I cannot use the headset to control Chat and Audio separately,You need to use the PlayStation console to do this,and its annoying as Heck!That feature alone makes the cheaper Turtle beach headset dominate these things.Another point of contention is how long you need to push the power button down to turn them on..Literally 4 Mississippi's before they beep and power up.The instructions say that you need to hold the power button down for 5 seconds to pair it,beware.... it has gone into that mode rather then turn on a few times.Sound quality is passable but not exceptional or worth noting and at this price point its disappointing.Positives..They fit better then the Stealth 520sbut are actually abit heavier,will need to see how they sit on the long term.Battery life so far is good on par with my old set,microphone is overly complicated and cannot be removed from the headset.Not a big deal,but worth noting.Summary...Mediocre pricey headset..They do nothing outstanding,and controlling audio is super annoying with these.Sound quality is good but not great,Noise cancelling is non existent.I use for gaming,would not recommend these for any audiophiles.Wired headsets on the cheap end perform better.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Newer Version is TRASH; Don't Buy
review.review: The first legitimate headset I ever bought for PC gaming was the HyperX Cloud II (back in ~2015). Even when the mic stopped working properly, I bought mic replacements and continued using the headset because it was great. However, my headset finally began breaking and I've lost audio in one ear. Rather than try something new, I opted to continue with the tried and true Cloud II.The new headset is definitely a newer version of the Cloud II and it is utter TRASH. The audio is terrible and the noise-cancelling is bad in the sense that I can't hear myself talking enough and it actually makes it difficult to speak. The mic is also a downgrade from its original version. The USB dongle you can plug into has removed the backlight and I initially thought it was broken/inoperable before I realized they removed the light. Personal preference, but an annoying change.There are much better headsets out there; choose something else. I'm terribly disappointed in how the Cloud II has changed since the first time I purchased it.

review.title: Absolutely lovely
review.review: I use this product for work and play sometimes over 17 hours a day with minimal discomfort.The only issues I'm having are with the cord liking to wrap and twist on itself and needing to be unwound frequently lest it start to fray the cables.Sound quality is absolutely perfect for knowing exactly where my enemies in COD are... Usually right behind me about to slash my throat.And I've had several people on discord ask me what microphone I'm using as the sound quality is crisp and clear.I even use the microphone to record messages for the phone line at work with exceeding quality.Will probably buy the wireless version next time, but I will be using this line going forward so long as it reminds available.
product.title: SteelSeries Arctis Pro Wireless Gaming Headset - Lossless High Fidelity Wireless + Bluetooth for PS5/PS4 and PC - Black

They are super comfortable. Build quality seems exceptional. I definitely would recommend to anyone looking for a quality headset at a reasonable price. Kudos Steel Series. 💪

review.title: Perfect sound

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Mid-Range Quality
review.review: Don't get me wrong, this is a good headset and works great, but it's not incredible. If you're looking for a good headset that'll get the job done and is comfortable, this is a good option. Mic quality is meh, but is so much better than an earbud set mic. I wear glasses with wide frames and it wasn't very comfortable at first, but I got used to it after a couple weeks. Audio playback quality is pretty good and they don't let much outside sound in which is a plus. Good headset, gave it four stars because there are better options for a higher price, but it's still completely worth it.
product.title: Razer BlackShark V2 X Gaming Headset: 7.1 Surround Sound - 50mm Drivers - Memory Foam Cushion - PC

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Good, but...
review.review: This is a fantastic headset for gaming, or just listening to music. However the range is terrible. If I have to leave the room for anything, I start having issues about 20 feet away. I have other wireless headsets that still function while I'm downstairs getting stuff out of my vehicle in the driveway. I mostly use this for gaming so it's not that big of a deal to me, but for the price, you should get more range than that, especially since it comes with its own plug in transmitter.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: My second pair and I already have issues with them
review.review: I had these headphones back in 2019 and the left side gave out randomly a few months back. I thought it was a one-off thing, so I got another pair. Nope. This seems to be an issue with Razer headsets. My second pair and OUT OF THE BOX the left side is a bit more faint than the right side. The volume dial is the culprit. When I fidget with the volume dial, the sound is fine again and comes out of both sides equally. But if it even moves just slightly, the sound on the left side where the wire is fades out a noticeable bit.I feel like I should give up on these headphones. They were part of my everyday peripheral set up but even 5 minutes out of the box, there’s issues…

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - Corsair Nightsword RGB - Comfort Performance Tunable FPS/MOBA Optical Ergonomic Gaming Mouse with Backlit R...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: I’m never getting a different mouse ever!
review.review: The Corsair Nightsword RGB is in my opinion the best mouse ever. The material and feel of the mouse is comfortable and from my experience, reduces sweat. The customizable weight makes it the experience of the mouse even better, if you download the corsair icue app on your pc, you can customize the DPI, buttons, and colors on the mouse. The 18,000 DPI sensor is more than enough range of sensitivity tuning. The mouse also has a “sniper” button which can also be fine tuned. Over all I love this mouse and recommend it to anyone who wants a quality mouse for all around use.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: Nice mouse, but there's an issue!
review.review: It's a very nice mouse, it's very smooth and ergonomic and has the fastest reaction time I've seen so far from affordable gaming mice. There's only one issue... the area around the Corsair logo has begun to peel.I purchased it in June, so I haven't had it for long. It doesn't effect the functionality of the mouse, but it looks/feels weird with part where the black stuff peeling getting sticky. Overall I really like this mouse; and intend to re-purchase the same one as a replacement when I have the money.

review.title: Decent Size and higher end performance
review.review: I’ve always preferred Corsair for my gaming products after having my Corsair Sabre die on me I figured it was time to get a new mouse, I got the Corsair Sabre pro at first but after realizing that icue v4 was so bad I returned it immediately. I bought this as replacement as this is still working with icue v3 and honestly it’s such a perfect mouse for me.Definitely a con is if ur used to a heavy mouse this will feel cheap because it’s so lightweight. The only draw back is I have been having trouble with the software that goes with it.. I have both corsair mouse and keyboard and from time to time the software will shut off and from time to time it will change from one default setting to another.. I actually had to delete all profiles so It would stay the same while gaming.

review.title: First Thoughts
review.review: I've been using a G702 for many years now, and the switches were starting to go, so it was time to upgrade. Well, seeing reviews and knowing some people using this I decided to get it, so I got it and I can say that it's nice, but I like the G702 a lot better.My biggest grip, and this is what seems to be just on the one I got, but the textured covering over the weights is dragging on the mouse pad, which means that the skatez on this mouse are too short. It's an easy fix to just go out and buy new skatez, but, for a new product, I should have to just yet.Other things I am not a fan of is this mouse is good for smaller hands, I feel. Also, the definition between the buttons are not very defined, and I feel you can easily click the wrong button. If the mouse was a little wider, I think it would be a bit more comfortable.

I have a half-palm grip, half claw grip with my palm resting on the back and my fingers curved. I used this mouse for about 20 minutes before my wrist started hurting so badly that i HAD to grab my broken one because it was so uncomfortable. ITS F***NG HEAVY. Like... kind of insanely so. If youre like me, save your time, buy something else. Something wired.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: 2 modes are great in this mouse.
review.review: The pros - this mouse has a pretty good battery life, it can be plugged in or wireless and the wireless charging is a nice feature. Corsairs software is top notch and you can adjust the settings on the fly and even set up profiles for what apps you have running. Indicator lights work well and it has enough buttons to do normal FPS gaming and surfing options.The con, and this is unfortunately a fairly large one, I get a hair of lag when its wireless, meaning wireless mode is not ideal for FPS gaming, or really any gaming. So I frequently operate it wirelessly when I'm just surfing the net and stuff but if I'm going to play I plug it in.This might be my setup creating an issue, my tower does sit 4 feet from the mouse, the drawers for the desk are between the mouse and its receiver so these are all things that could be the cause and that I'll try and tweak down the road but it is something I am experiencing so figured fair warning to anyone else who may have a similar set up.

This mouse is a little small for my XL-glove-sized hands, but I use it all day and haven't cramped up yet.. The back-lighted Corsair logo is pretty cool too. Recommended.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Mouse is lagging all the time
review.review: I ordered this mouse because I wanted to switch to wireless mouse experience. I really like this mouse, nice and comfortable design and it fits perfectely in my hand with my claw grip.The only thing that keeps me back to give it 5 stars is the wireless modes. when I switch to 2.4GHz Slipstream wireless mode I get so much lags every 5 seconds which is awful for gaming, you just can't play games like this. When I switch to Bluetooth mode the amount of lags decrease but not completely and you can't controll the RGB lightning when using Bluetooth mode.I have to use the wired mode for smooth experience.UPDATE: I connected the 2.4GHz Slipstream receiver to the front panel and I have 0 lags, also can't notice any lags in bluetooth mode anymore.Advice: Don't connect the Slipstream receiver to the back of your PC and you won't get any lags.
product.title: Corsair Harpoon RGB Wireless - Wireless Rechargeable Gaming Mouse with SLIPSTREAM Technology - 10,000 DPI Optical Sensor

review.title: Two buttons broke within 18 months of purchase
review.review: First, the middle click died, around 6 months in.This would've been a dealbreaker (I use middle click a lot in my job) but the sniper button on the side was easily rebound for the same purpose.Now, about 18 months in, the left click has been double-clicking more and more often.Not consistently, but maybe 1 in 10 clicks get sent twice.It's enough that I can't use this for anything important.Feels nice in my hand, though.The internals might be shoddy, but the externals are nice.If I could learn to trust this brand again, I'd get another Corsair mouse.That'll take some word of mouth from trusted friends, though, because for now I'm sworn off.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2021
review.title: Corsair doesn't disappoint.
review.review: Knew what I was getting into with this one. I've been gaming with Corsair products for about 2 years now. Thr only exception being my mouse I finally kicked the Logitech G602 that I've been using for 5+ yrs. The wire is high quality braided like all of their other devices. The software is simple and user friendly. The weights and software customization are incredible I like a heavy mouse and super low DPI for shooters with a high polling rate and this m65 is perfect. Just the right amount of buttons for the type of gaming I do.If you are a WOW or DOTA player you may find this lacking but this mouse is for FPS and other shooters. The sniper button is INCREDIBLY useful. I though of it more as a gimmick at first but no it makes such a huge difference in the fine aiming for high zoom weapons or vehicles.As far as ergonomics I have fairly large hands and it fits great. The thumb rest keeps your hand on the mouse and off the pad to make for smooth movement and less drag and the ability to change the weight is more valuable than I first assumed.I picked this up on sale and I think the price point is very fair for what you are getting. If you are on the fence, go for it! That said I love Corsair, I run the K70, Void wireless Pro and now the M65 none of which have ever let me down.
product.title: Corsair M65 RGB Elite – Wired FPS and MOBA Gaming Mouse – Adjustable Weight and Balance – Durable Aluminum Frame – 18,000 ...

Sadly, I was very wrong. The G604 doesn't improve on the G602 in any way, and clearly took a major step back in terms of quality / quality control. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: The mouse is fine, but the mandatory G HUB sofware is awful
review.review: So Logitech decided to discontinue their software for various devices and consolidate them into on grand app to rule them all: G HUB. Not a bad strategy, but the execution was terrible.The mouse itself is pretty good, but there is no point extolling its virtues, since you shouldn't buy it anyway. In fact, you should not buy any Logitech wireless produce until they've fixed G HUB. Or eradicated it, hired a new engineering team, and written something better to replace it. Or, you know, just reverted to the LGS app that their older mice used that worked just fine for years.There are many reviews detailing G HUB's failings, so I won't list all of them here. I'll add my latest experience to the pile:I got the mouse and installed G HUB several months ago on a system with Windows 8.1. Today, I used the in-app button to upgrade to the latest version. But it turns out the latest version is only compatible with Windows 10. So it tried to upgrade itself and hung forever instead, showing me the cutesy animation that Logitech's engineering department apparently spent their time on instead of doing QA. I didn't even get the courtesy of an error message.As a programmer myself, I can tell you that's an inexcusable, novice, facepalm-grade error. An auto-updater should *always* perform proper version and requirements checks.Anyway, I headed to Logitech's site to find an installer for the earlier Windows 8 compatible version. I knew it existed, since just an hour before it was up and running on my system. But no luck, they now offer Windows 10 or Mac only. So then off to reddit, where quickly I found the hidden link to the older Win7 and Win8 versions. Pay no mind to the "There are no Downloads for this Version" message! It's there, or at least it was today, though it may be gone by the time you need it.That installer then failed because it was confused by the current, corrupt installation. So I spent some time ripping that one out by the roots from multiple file system and registry locations. After pausing for a moment to say goodbye to the mouse settings/macros I spent time writing, now all gone, I was able to reinstall it.The whole affair reminded me of this bit from the HHGTTG:“But the plans were on display…”“On display? I eventually had to go down to the cellar to find them.”“That’s the display department.”“With a flashlight.”“Ah, well, the lights had probably gone.”“So had the stairs.”“But look, you found the notice, didn’t you?”“Yes,” said Arthur, “yes I did. It was on display in the bottom of a locked filing cabinet stuck in a disused lavatory with a sign on the door saying ‘Beware of the Leopard.”
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Can't Recommend
review.review: This mouse has really been a disappointment.Battery life is nowhere near what I was expecting. I replace batteries in my M510 maybe every 8 month's. That mouse is used 8 hours a day for work. Since I got this in July I have had to replace the batteries three times already (almost monthly).Functionally, this mouse would be terrible for any type of FPS. Half the time the first click I make doesn't register and I have to click again. I haven't experienced the double clicks that others have reported, but they may only be a matter of time. The two main buttons overhang the front of the mouse, so if you bump it into anything while moving it, you end up with random clicks.And last but definitely not least, the G-Hub software is absolute garbage. The interface is terrible and difficult to use. Nothing is where you expect it be and you have to click thru different screens to do basic things like remap buttons. It is buggy as hell, locking up when trying to update, requiring uninstalling and reinstalling it to get it to work. Half the time the profiles you get put in and saved don't activate when they should. For G-Hub alone I would say to stay away from any Logitech product that uses it.
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Excellent physical design, absolutely unusable due to GHub.
review.review: I had my previous Logitech gaming mouse for almost 10-years before it gave up on life. So I went for this G604.It feels great in my hand, cradles my thumb perfectly and the buttons are all accessible for my tiny lady hands. Excellent design!But... The Ghub software? Randomly drops profiles so none of the programmed buttons work. Just randomly. It makes the mouse totally unusable. I will be in the middle of a project I rely on macro'd buttons to do for work? Mouse decides to stop working. I will be gaming and try to hit a macro? Bam! Dead!Trying to find a way to load the profile onboard is obtuse. This mouse is harder to program than units with more buttons were 10-years ago.Thing is, I trusted Logitech enough to throw out the package so I cannot even return this failure of a device. Ghub will spend hours trying to update and fail to, which leads to uninstalling and reinstalling just to use the %^&%^ mouse to do basic ^&%&^ mouse things. I have never had this kind of issue with Logitech devices and I have been a loyal customer for decades.Looks like I will be dropping $300 to buy a new copy of the same Logitech gaming mouse I got 10-years ago, because I know that it will survive being used for 16-hours a day for close to 10-years and remain a viable, reliable option until USB technology is completely phased out of PCs.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Good mouse, no doubt about it, but beware if you have larger hands
review.review: First of all I'll preface by saying that I'm unsure if the issue of my assigned keybinds resetting was an issue of ICUE software or if it's an issue with Windows 11. Either way, it's something to be noted that there's the possibility of your ICUE software resetting or scrambling your assigned keybinds when you reboot your PC. This issue won't affect the score I gave it since I can't pinpoint the exact cause of it.What will affect it however, is it's size. For a gaming mouse, the form factor is surprisingly small. I wear a medium/large size glove and this mouse was exceptionally uncomfortable if you're using it for it's defining feature: the programmable buttons on the left. In my natural mouse grip, my thumb rests on the frontmost row of buttons, making 123/456 the easiest to access. The 789 row just behind it is a bit uncomfortable to reach. The 10/11/12 row is very difficult without shifting my hand back on the mouse or curling my thumb too far inward, which is unnatural for me personally and made using the mouse significantly more difficult than I had previously expected. And yes, this is with the number buttons slid as far to the front as I could with the adjustment screw.Additionally, the buttons themselves are very small and feature very little textural difference to help distinguish them besides some very light texturing on alternating rows. Pressing multiple buttons or pressing the wrong button is very common, more common than I would like. Between the buttons being small, being hard to distinguish one from the other, and having larger hands make utilizing the full potential of this mouse extremely difficult.Finally, the left and right clickers are very light. The weight of my middle finger alone is enough to cause the right clicker to go off.My verdict is that the mouse is potentially very good, especially if your hands are on the smaller side. Gamers with larger hands might find this mouse uncomfortable to use if you prefer to choke up on the mouse like I do. I wouldn't *not* recommend it, but I would definitely keep the size of the mouse itself and the buttons in mind when making the recommendation.
product.title: Corsair Scimitar RGB Elite, MOBA/MMO Gaming Mouse, Black, Backlit RGB LED, 18000 DPI, Optical

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Great moust until it craps out
review.review: So I loved this mouse when it got it back in April 2020. However it has been a year and a half since I purchased this mouse and I am having multiple hardware issues. The scroll wheel when scrolling down will some times just start scrolling up and vice versa when scrolling down. This wasn't horrible and I could work around this. However, less than 3 days later the left mouse button started failing to work. I have to now click the left mouse button 3 to 4 times to get it to register much like my Razer started doing before I purchased this mouse. If i blow under the left mouse button it starts working again for a few minutes but once the static charge builds back up, it starts failing again. For this price I feel like the mouse should at least last a few years. I would say take you money and get a logitech and safe yourself the headache.
product.title: Corsair Scimitar RGB Elite, MOBA/MMO Gaming Mouse, Black, Backlit RGB LED, 18000 DPI, Optical

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: Serious software problems
review.review: As others have mentioned, this mouse has serious software issues. It's a shame because I used it successfully for a little over a month and it was a great mouse, but the software issues have started to manifest, and now the mouse does not appear within the software at all (as shown in screenshot). Not only does this mean that all of the buttons no longer programmable, but also all of the customization that I had is lost as well. This effectively turns this mouse into a high-DPI two-button mouse. Customer support has basically been useless to solve this problem, and I'm not expecting resolution so I'll have to find something else. I do hope they eventually solve these issues, because it really is great hardware, but at least as of October 2021 it's not yet resolved. (And just to be clear - I'm a software developer myself with a lot of experience in driver development, so I do not believe this is simply user error, especially given the number of other people encountering these problems.)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review.title: LMB issue on day one -- disappointment
review.review: The left mouse button seems to be a common failing point with these mice. I ordered this mouse to replace a failing mouse I currently own. Day one I notice something is off with the left click of the mouse. There is a noticeable difference between left and right click sound and tactile feedback back while clicking. Right clicking provides a nice click sound and feel, while, left clicking is "soft" and sometimes I can't even tell when I am clicking. Sometimes it didn't even register a click. It is almost like they are using different switches.I returned it after one day. $80 for a mouse that doesn't have consistency on day one is not worth it and I wouldn't trust it to last years to come. I would have given it 1 star except I have other Corsair products that I love and have had for years without any issue.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2021
review.title: Didn't expect would be that good
review.review: This is the kind of product you are not sure you really need until you get it and wonder how you could manage to live without it. With all the not so good reviews, especially about the screen, I hesitated for a long time before to buy it but when I got some money as a gift from a aunt I decided to try it.First of all, the device looks very good quality and it sticks very well to my K95. The buttons and widgets are easy to setup with iCUE and you can configure them as you like (color, size, background image, etc.). You can only set 6 buttons per screen but you can set as many screens as you want and it's easy to switch between them by swiping with your finger. I switched from a two monitors setup to a single 32" one a year ago and I was missing very much to be able to monitor my temperatures while gaming without having to run some overlay programs. Turns out that thing does it wonderfully well.Unlike some other people said I didn't notice any increase of CPU usage after I connected it (but maybe it's because my Ryzen 5900x just doesn't feel it).About the screen, it's true that if you look at it from an angle you don't see anything anymore but... this thing is not supposed to be looked at from a 45 degree angle. It is supposed to be watched when you are in front of your keyboard and when you do that it's amazingly clear and bright. My only negative point is that the touch functionality when you press a button is not always super reactive but I realize that it works fine if you aim more toward the bottom of the screen instead of the top. In that way it works just fine.Overall, it's an expansive device but for me it worth it. Really awesome gadget to have in your setup.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - Corsair iCUE NEXUS Companion Touch Screen – 5” Diagonal Screen – 6 Programmable Virtual Macro Buttons – Liv...

review.title: Cool RGB mouse, don't care about other features though
review.review: First of all the RGB on this mouse is slick.I has the DeathAdder Chroma (which was old, and the RGB didn't work with Synapse 3), but I loved the feel of it.This mouse had that similar feel, I actually may like this mouse's feel more than the DeathAdder and I'm happy with my decision for this mouse over the DeathAdder 2.I normally stick with what is familiar, and glad I broke out of my comfort zone.It glides easily across my desk and the DPI adjustable thing which I rarely ever use is still nice to have in case I ever need it.I do like you can reprogram the buttons (and those thumb buttons I have surprisingly found good uses for).One thing I'll say is the right mouse button sometimes gets accidentally pressed.Could be my long Diablo 3 constant clicking that my hand just hits the mouse button on accident frequently, but resting my hand on the mouse I don't feel it should be that easy that accidentally clicking occurs.So would have been 5 star, but subtracted half a star for those weird accidental mouse clicks.Subtracted another half only because it's not wireless for this price!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: Left-Click Stopped Working After A Few Months
review.review: I purchased this mouse for light gaming and typical web browsing. Within 6 months, I noticed the left-click was not holding down correctly. Physically it felt fine, but it was basically unplayable in games. I tried every solution and the problem only got worse over time so I figured it was a hardware problem rather than a software issue. I took great care of the mouse and used it VERY lightly yet it still gave out quickly. Not to mention the Razer Synapse program is terrible. Unfortunately for me, the company that sold me the product through Amazon, "TECHLOBBY", is not an authorized seller of Razer products so the 2 year manufacturers warranty did NOT cover this issue. On Razer's website, Amazon is an authorized seller of Razer products but many of the companies that sell through Amazon are not so it is very misleading. This mouse is no longer manufactured by Razer so don't even bother buying it. For $50, this mouse became useless after a few months of light use, DO NOT RECOMEND.

review.title: 2 week review
review.review: Been using this after my Dark Core wouldn't stop double clicking and reduced to having a 3 hour battery life. First things first, I've charged this thing like twice in these two weeks and I'm at 65% still... Totally amazed by that part, not sure if the software's just wrong but I haven't had it drop to 10% according to it. This is great for me as I'm usually playing something or scrolling through sites for about 5 hours a day at least. Next the dpi settings are perfect out of the box for me, I usually run 800-1200 and this hits the all the spots well when I need to speed up as well. The wireless communication is a lot better than my previous mouse as well, no random sputters or lags. Also love the ergonomics on it, feels great for my longer fingers and claw grip. Will be sure to update the more I use and the more I find out about it but at the moment 5/5!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: Nice, but not perfect.
review.review: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum XT Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Backlit RGB LED, Cherry MX RGB Blue, Black.I bought this keyboard to replace a similar G. Skill keyboard that had long since broken. This new keyboard works pretty much as advertised and looks pretty darn cool!Pros:Solidly builtCherry MX RGB options ( I choose Blue as I prefer a "clicky" keyboard.)PBT double-shot keycap set (It is nice to know that the graphics will not rub off with these keycaps.)Cons:PBT double-shot keycap set-(the graphic layout of the number keycaps 1!, 2@, 3#, 4$, etc., looks much more cluttered/congested than the traditional visual layout. Also, the abbreviated keycaps PSC, SLK, BRK, etc., puts my brain on pause every time I look at those keys. Finally, the tactile bumps on the F and J keys are way too subtle for my sense of touch.)Integrated USB Port (I don't need or want it, nor do I want the resulting increase in the diameter of the keyboard cord.)No large L-shaped Enter key.Yeah, I still miss that!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Very nice keyboard - exceeded expectations
review.review: Not a keyboard snob here, usually buy cheap ones.Have owned expensive keyboards in past and theydidn't seem to give good value for cost.Was skeptical about buying this keyboard as its expensive.First impressions were it was constructed well and I really like the feel of the optical switches.Although sometimes I think I'm just resting my fingers on the keys and then I look and see its typing.Very sensitive which has its good side and down side.Able to type very fast but just have to be a little careful.But really like the feel of the switches.Thought I'd like mechanical switches better but these are working very good.RGB is excellent very pleased.Have this keyboard paired with 011D XL pc case with glass panels and lots of rgb so this keyboard works so well sitting next to it.Everything on iCue with commander pro.Running older version of iCue to be able to use older profiles.The newer version iCue had nothing but problems.Dont really used the built in profiles.Haven't saved my profiles onto my keyboard, I dont plan of traveling with keyboard.Really become big fan of multimedia keys it surprises me.I try to use dial but its just ok.Like the usb at the back.Cable is kind of big.Wrist rest is very comfortable.Overall fit and finish is very good.Final thoughts is this is a very nice keyboard although expensive.If you wait the prices seem to fluctuate a good amount.I just waited until I saw a good price to buy and saved a good amount that makes this keyboard a much better value.
product.title: Corsair K100 RGB Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - Cherry MX Speed RGB Silver Keyswitches - AXON Hyper-Processing Technology fo...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: Great for a pricey gaming keyboard, not the best for customer support and software
review.review: First off, the keyboard is great and responsive for gaming.The keys feel great, the actuation point is fantastic for quick inputs while gaming, and the macro keys (G#) are helpful too even if just starting/stopping OBS or muting yourself in Discord.However, the software and Corsair side of it are not the best.The software can be very temperamental.Color zones and macros can be difficult to get into, and some only work if iCue is running in the backgroundAnd when it is running in the background, it can act buggy or hod resources if there's a waiting firmware or update.Finally the Optical version of the keyboard is entirely proprietary.If a switch stops working, or something happens that Corsair deems user defect, then they won't RMA it, and since it's proprietary, there's no way to get it repaired or the switch replaced as Corsair doesn't offer paid repair or replacement switches.They recommend buying a new $200 keyboard.Bottom-line is that there are better keyboards for price, and definitely better support for the price and effort as well.But if you do get it, it's a very friendly keyboard.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2021
review.title: Perfect replacement for my Logitech G610
review.review: I had a Logitech keyboard last. This is not a knock against them, as every other product of theirs I've bought (which is many) has served me well, but the G610 was failing earlier than expected. So I needed a new keyboard.Every Corsair product I've ever bought significantly exceeded my expectations. This naturally causes my expectations to rise still further, and this keyboard still beat them. The Cherry Speed switches are quieter than what my last keyboard had, which I love. The required pressing force and travel to actuate them are quite light, which is great for extended use to prevent finger fatigue. Just make sure you're able to only hit the keys you want to press. Accidental actuation is possible.It's noticeably narrower than my G610. I've reclaimed about 3 inches of width on my desk. The spacebar is textured for some reason, but it's fine with me. So is the removable wrist rest, which makes a little more sense. There are 3 brightness settings, plus off. The brightest should be easily visible unless you're standing in direct sunlight at midday. The dimmest won't be irritating in a darkened room.It has a USB pass-through, which requires plugging in a second cable. This is optional and the keyboard will work just fine with only the one cable plugged in (make sure it's the right one; they are labeled). It comes with several replacement keys, and a tool to help replace keys.I did not want to spend $200 on their newest flagship board. I think this was wise; I could not imagine the additional cost being worth it, when this board is so good.
product.title: Corsair K70 RGB MK.2 SE Mechanical RAPIDFIRE Gaming Keyboard - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - PBT Double-Shot Keycaps...

The only real difference on this one is the shortened keyboard press response distance, and perhaps the backlighting options.Corsair does a decent job on their products. I just wish they made some stuff in the USA! We want to buy USA made products Corsair! Start delivering on that demand and you'll sell even more things than before! We seek out USA made things!

She does not mind the noise the keyboard makes when she types so we are going to keep the keyboard.I on the other hand hate the sound the keyboard makes. It sounds tinny, I can hear the springs make a noise when the key reaches the top once the key is released. I want to either spray WD-40 or use Vaseline on the keys to stop the sound the keys make. The keyboard just sounds cheap. The only thing I can think of is that games do not hear the noise this keyboard makes is because they either have the sound up on their speakers or they are wearing headphones.Would I buy this keyboard again? The answer is NO.
