review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2021
review.title: Didn't expect would be that good
review.review: This is the kind of product you are not sure you really need until you get it and wonder how you could manage to live without it. With all the not so good reviews, especially about the screen, I hesitated for a long time before to buy it but when I got some money as a gift from a aunt I decided to try it.First of all, the device looks very good quality and it sticks very well to my K95. The buttons and widgets are easy to setup with iCUE and you can configure them as you like (color, size, background image, etc.). You can only set 6 buttons per screen but you can set as many screens as you want and it's easy to switch between them by swiping with your finger. I switched from a two monitors setup to a single 32" one a year ago and I was missing very much to be able to monitor my temperatures while gaming without having to run some overlay programs. Turns out that thing does it wonderfully well.Unlike some other people said I didn't notice any increase of CPU usage after I connected it (but maybe it's because my Ryzen 5900x just doesn't feel it).About the screen, it's true that if you look at it from an angle you don't see anything anymore but... this thing is not supposed to be looked at from a 45 degree angle. It is supposed to be watched when you are in front of your keyboard and when you do that it's amazingly clear and bright. My only negative point is that the touch functionality when you press a button is not always super reactive but I realize that it works fine if you aim more toward the bottom of the screen instead of the top. In that way it works just fine.Overall, it's an expansive device but for me it worth it. Really awesome gadget to have in your setup.
product.title: Corsair iCUE Nexus Companion Touch Screen – 5” Diagonal Screen – 6 Programmable Virtual Macro Buttons + K100 RGB Optical-M...

I have a brand new I9 11 gen CPU with RTX 3080 GPU and my computer cannot recognize this device. It did once, and worked for a second... I was able to see it on icue and set up my apps thinking everything was finally working right. After I set everything up, I swiped on it once and it completely froze and never worked again. Ive tried just about everything with it, from switching USBs to looking for updated software, nothing works. Absolutely great idea, giant waste of money.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Great initially, but not built to last
review.review: I bought this keyboard in November of 2018. I am a casual gamer, and I really enjoyed the bright colors and the Cherry MX Speed keys. I have never had a keyboard with dedicated macro keys before, and the keyboard itself seemed quite sturdy.Fast-forward to today, and I am having some annoying difficulties with this keyboard that others have noted in the reviews. It does not happen every time, but often when I try to type an "A" it ends up writing "AA" or "AAA". It does not happen every time I press the button either, which only makes it more annoying. As another reviewer noted, this seems to be due to using WASD keys more than the others.In addition, I find that the spacebar is difficult to use in some games. Unless I perfectly hit it in the middle on every press, it will over time begin to slope downward to the left (when my left hand is on WASD my thumb naturally falls just left of the center of the spacebar). This eventually results in the spacebar not registering all of my presses until I press down on the right side and get it back to level.Lastly, switching between users on my computer often causes the keyboard software to glitch and refuse to work until I unplug the USB and plug it back in.None of these issues seem like major concerns, but I bought this keyboard thinking that it would last longer than 3 years. I guess Corsair just does not build them to last.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Ok at first, but the keys break quickly
review.review: I really like this keyboard at first, I was a little concerned with how loud the keys were and if they would be disruptive on a conference call, but people said they couldn’t really hear them. My major problem with this keyboard is the keys start to break.The plastic that makes up the cross pattern that connects the key to the keyboard seems to be very weak. Within about 2 months or so of owning it, the left side control key broke. To Corsairs credit they sent me a replacement key very quickly, but a few months after that the right control key started to come loose.What I have noticed is it is the keys that are around the edge of the keyboard that have the issue. What I believe it to be is it is the keys that you aren’t pressing at a straight up and down, it is the keys that you are reaching over to with your pinky fingers that are really the problem. I have a feeling overtime they would all start to break down, but the ones that are getting more pressure at an angle are just breaking first.Long story short, I replacing this and going back to my trusted Logitech keyboard because, while their customer service was great, I can’t be waiting for replacement keys every couple months.If this is primarily used for gaming and not a combination of day-to-day and gaming I would say it will last you a while, but if you’re thinking about getting this for your day-to-day I wouldn’t recommend it.
product.title: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 6x Programmable Macro Keys - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Fast...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: So fragile that arrived damaged 2 times
review.review: This item may work well if it can be received undamaged, but I will never know.First box arrived, double boxed but no padding between inner and outer box, with several of the keys popped off and loose in the box.Amazon promptly replaced it with the same item packaged the same way and with many of the keys popped off.This time, I thought that maybe the keys are designed to be able to be removed easily for cleaning and maintenance and attempted to snap them back into place.This was successful with all but 2 of the keys, which could not be snapped back into place without them being tilted at an odd angle, despite several attempts to do so.Feels good in terms of weight and seems like a solid build except for the keys, has good features, and was recommended by a trusted computer sales person.The deal breaker is that this is a keyboard without keys that can actually be attached and aligned properly.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review.title: Great keyboard for gaming, few annoyances nothing major
review.review: I've used this keyboard for about a year. first off it has been great and I do recommend it. I use it for intense MMO gaming and it provides everything I require. It is a bit loud but expected for this type of keyboard. the keys off to the left to create macros. I've never created any before this and use the Icue system it was realitivly easy to figure out but there was a slight learning curve through guess and check but got everything working the way i wanted. Lightning is great and customizable. easy to switch it up or just cut it off.Now for the errors. seems to be few. Had to uninstall and reinstall the icue system because it got corrupted two times during my use somehow. Had a few issues reinstalling and getting everything working the 2nd time.The biggest annoyance (at least its something small) is the volume buttons on top right to mute, lower or raise the volume will just stop working. ill restart icue but that wont work. The only way to fix this is either A: restarting the computer sometimes fixes it. B: Go to settings in Icue and force update the firmware. even though you are currently on that firmware you have to force update it so it starts working again. While this is a rather simple fix. I've had this issue for over a year and it still hasn't been fixed but is a known issue (i found it by googling forums)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Who designed these key faces??!
review.review: I used a K70 with brown switches for a few years before it finally kicked the bucket during a move and I decided to throw down some real cash on a new one. While I like the low-profile approach to this keyboard, whoever decided to not only NOT illuminate the shift characters but also flip their position on the key faces is an absolute imbecile and should not have any say on designing a keyboard in this price range. That kind of design decision is something I expect out of the junk keyboards I get when purchasing refurbished computers for my company...not an $185 gaming keyboard.All that said, outside the lighting and stupid character layout decision, the rest of the keyboard works quite nicely. I have a little bit of a "springy" sound on my "s" key that's been there since day-1 but otherwise no hardware issues to speak of.Software wise, it's really annoying to have to use G-hub constantly if you want this keyboard to be really functional. I say that because without G-hub running the keyboard defaults to a pattern where it flashes all the colors in a big wave which gets incredibly distracting in your peripherals. If you turn off lighting entirely the same idiot that designed these key faces decided to do dark grey on black. It doesn't impact myself as I've spent 8hr+ a day on a keyboard for 15yrs now but if you don't know how to memory type you're going to be up the creek without G-hub running and you're really going to hate finding those rare shift characters.If you're someone just starting out coding this keyboard is especially not for you, you're basically going to be chicken pecking like your dad because you can't see a thing.
product.title: Logitech G915 TKL Tenkeyless Lightspeed Wireless RGB Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Low Profile Switch Options, LIGHTSYNC RG...

review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. But this maybe a con for someone else.I have seen this issue on many other reviews and I have the same major issue. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. As of today (10/4/21) I am sending the first unit back and am receiving the new unit this week.I will update this review with my experience going forward with the replacement.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Key spam, broken keys, RMA issues.
review.review: Honestly this board has been a bigger headache than what it was worth. The purpose was to get a nice full sized board with silent linear switches to replace another small board I was using.The first problem to occur was a constant key spam issue. Support was helpful and RMA'd the unit. The process was archaic and a pain to complete. Requiring RMA numbers all over the box, and a paper trail explaining the issue and why RMA was the resolution. FedEx was way more helpful with the shipping process and getting everything sorted out.Took a week or two to get a new board from Hong Kong which wasn't too slow for the distance. The replacement board immediately had an issue with the Numpad 8 key being chipped on the inside probably from a manufacturing issue. Razer's solution is to replace the entire board for a singular keycap. This is pretty unfortunate and I will just be picking up a custom set of caps. Anyone else looking for this board just be warned if there are any problems expect to be out of a board for a week or two. Also bring your own caps because the ones provided are cheap.
product.title: Razer BlackWidow V3 Pro Mechanical Wireless Gaming Keyboard: Green Mechanical Switches - Tactile & Clicky - Chroma RGB Lig...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Horrible battery life, bad connections
review.review: I was excited to receive this keyboard.I had been watching it for a while and finally decided to buy it.It is not cheap, and being a Razer product, I was expecting something really good.Instead, I am returning the keyboard due to really poor performance.After I received the keyboard I immediately removed it from the packaging and plugged it in so it would charge.Once fully charged, I kept the keyboard plugged in via the supplied USB cable to do the setup and customization.I did not want to drain the battery at all during this processes.Once everything was setup, I "Synced" the keyboard to the computer using the supplied 2.4 GHz Hyperspeed Dongle.Once all setup was complete, I disconnected the USB cable so I could use it wirelessly.My first issue with the keyboard is how loud it is.I did my research on this keyboard before buying it and selected the Yellow keys - "silent and linear".I fully understand mechanical keys are not perfectly silent, but this is the loudest keyboard I have ever used, and I have been in the technology field for a long time, so I have used some old mechanical keyboards.This is the least of my issues with the keyboard, as this could possibly be ignored, but it was an issue, so I wanted to make sure to get it out there that this is a LOUD keyboard.My second issue was the connection.This keyboard would lose connection at times when using the "Hyperspeed" connection.I would have to patiently wait a while for it to connect again, or turn the keyboard off and back on again.Please note, the computer is only about 3 feet away from the keyboard with nothing obstructing the signal between the two items.I decided to try the Bluetooth connection...no luck.My computer has no problem detecting other Bluetooth devices, no matter what the device is, the age, or the brand.However, my computer could never "find" this keyboard.I even tried making sure it was the only Bluetooth device in the area turned on, and it still never found it.So, my only course of action was to plug the "wireless" keyboard in with the supplied USB cable to ensure I would not lose connection with the computer.My third issue.Not sure how to describe this, but it would randomly do things.After having the wireless keyboard plugged in as a wired keyboard (if you can't tell I am frustrated about this, I am), I would be typing and it would randomly open the start menu or task manager.Other times it would just randomly throw up a string of letters that I didn't type.I am not sure how this happened, and only happened a few times before I decided to box this up and start the return process, but it was weird and random.I have never seen that before with.My final issue, and perhaps the most important was the battery life.As I indicated earlier I let the keyboard fully charge before using, and I kept it plugged in while doing the initial setup.I had the keyboard unplugged and working as a wireless keyboard for maybe a little over an hour before reconnecting to become a wired keyboard.Of course, during that time I had the lights going and was using it as a normal keyboard (not gaming, just internet and email) and of course fighting the connection issues.When I pugged the keyboard back in and went back into the Razer Synapse application, I noticed the battery charge had dropped to 76%.WHAT?!?!?!In just over an hour the battery was drained 24%?This is ridiculous.The keyboard I was replacing (and now using for this review) is a wireless backlit keyboard that only needs to be charged once every few months.This keyboard would not even make it through a full day using it as designed with lights active.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming as it would surely die before the game is finished.So my options now were to either leave the keyboard plugged in, which defeats the purpose of buying a wireless keyboard (and deal with the weird random letters and opening of other applications); or turning the light effects off to save battery life, which defeats the purpose of buying an expensive RGB keyboard.Either way, I would not get what I paid a lot of money for.So, I am returning the keyboard.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: Stopped Connecting to Anything After Just 2 Months of Use
review.review: I got this keyboard to replace a Huntsman optical that overall was doing great, but I had an issue with the volume knob (which I use quite regularly) and for me it wasn't the best tying experience for working and gaming. I needed a keyboard that was a little more clicky as I was accidentally hitting other keys with the very short travel of the Huntsman optical. I also wanted wireless so I could pair my work laptop via bluetooth and either connect via a cable or dongle with my personal computer.The Blackwidow V3 Pro at first was amazing. Connected quickly and reliably, the typing experience was much better for my work, the volume knob worked great unlike my Huntsman optical, and the RGB matched perfectly with my other peripherals, and I was in heaven.Then the 2-3 key presses started happening. This wasn't something I noticed with a lot of reviews when I purchased this, but looking back this is a huge problem with this keyboard. This is very problematic depending on what type of game you're playing or if you're pulling double duty and using this keyboard for work. Constantly editing emails or documents was getting very old.I also ran into connection issues after just a month. At first it was just not connecting to bluetooth as quickly, but then if I was using the 2.4Ghz dongle on my personal rig during a game, it would just cut out. It was 3 feet away and within perfect line of sight. Then it got so bad I had to just start plugging it in to game because of random disconnects. It also started randomly flashing the lights.Then today it just stopped connecting to anything. Won't connect to bluetooth, the 2.4ghz dongle or a wired connection. It won't pair with anything new but I was able to reset it and then update the firmware. Then it registers with Synapse if I have it plugged in, but it is still not usable at all. No key presses will register. Also if I press keys while it's connected via the USB cord, it will do random colors like rainbow wave, or do green pulse from where I push the key. The keyboard is entirely useless now after just 2 months.Do not buy this keyboard, or if you do, get a warranty. This is the 2nd Razer keyboard in a row that's had problem. I've typically loved the feel of Razer products, but $500 of peripherals that have either had issues or bit the dust in 2 years is too much. Buyer beware.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2021
review.title: Terrible Light Blead and color representation. There are so many better options for your keyboard!
review.review: This BEST part of Corsair's newest generation of keyboards is they now use a standard bottom row. This means that you can put almost any keycap set you want on your fancy new keyboard and really make it your own one of a kind keyboard. You are no longer beholden to Corsair's proprietary first party keycap sets. Which is a good thing because these Corsair key caps kind of suck.I've posted some pictures of my K65 keyboard to show what I mean. You can see that the light bleed on these keycaps is just terrible. The red keys in the picture are corsair and the white and blue keycaps are from a third party (drop, I think). On the red switches the entire area around the lettering glows meaning that they are thin in that area. The white switches the only theletter lights up more without the bleed. This is especially true with higher brightness levels and colors closer to white. On the red keycaps when the RGB is set to pure white the color comes through as a deeper pink. The same could be said of the blue third party caps, but it's not nearly as bad.On the upside these keycaps feel good and will fit just about any keyboard, but you can spend the same money and get a much better keycap from places like Drop, Ducky, HyperX or just about anywhere else.Do yourself a favor- look elsewhere.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2021
review.title: Pretty painful for beginners
review.review: Edit: still dealing with customer service via snail mail basically, one response a day and I’m pretty sure it’s different people because I get asked the same questions. Going to likely and painfully return this horrible product especially after hearing this happen to others.Edit: this product is the most frustrating experience, nothing lights up properly and customer service told me I had to play email tag because their “tech support” doesn’t cover troubleshooting this and the people that do only answer by email. Sometimes 2 fans light up, other times just one but never all 3 and nothing else in the kit has ever lit up as intended. Stay away.This product comes in great packaging and you really feel like you got value for money especially when you tally up the individual items.It’s also not the cheapest, but I wanted to get something higher quality being my first time and all, but this wasn’t quite the case.To begin I learned the pipes were called something that’s just a fancy word for acrylic, and I learned very fast that it’s not very forgiving and easy to mess up. Couple that with the types of adapters you get which pretty much commit you to hardline tubing and you are stuck either with attempting to use them (and in my case immediately messing up a tube despite watching videos prior,) or investing a lot more money to get better tubes or different adapters, but it doesn’t end there…It comes with a squeeze container for filling the pump which broke off inside just from using, that was 2 hours of draining and playing rubik’s cube trying to get out, not fun. But it doesn’t end there either…The pump is awkward as heck, if you have it all plugged in the thing doesn’t operate at full power when filling and you are stuck trying to figure out why the tubes aren’t filling, why does it gotta be like that?The directions aren’t the best, and this process was very painful, I got coolant all over my motherboard and cards despite my best intent to cover everything which yes, is part to user error but I also feel the acrylic isn’t the best use and I wish there were more options from Corsair like being able to buy a kit with soft tubing. Knowing what I do now I may have opted for a cheaper kit and gotten soft line tubing to save the headache and for more flexibility.

I re-seated and reapplied thermal paste to the cpu plate and still no change. After trying for a second time to re-seat it I decided to remover the washer on the mounting screws that the instruction say to put on. (I included a pic of the instructions.) After removing those washer I immediately saw a changed. Played a few games and my cpu temp stayed in the high 60s.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2019
review.title: Amazing Product for Couch Gamers
review.review: I was really looking forward to gaming from the couch with the new lap board and overall this is a very comfortable solution!The board is perfectly sized for most setups, however you may find it doesn't work well with certain couch setups (like mine).The quality of the lap board is superb, the mouse pad is replaceable (adhesive) so it’s surface is not perfect, however it is a 9/10 as far how smooth the surface came.The keyboard is extremely responsive, I did not notice any latency - and it is very bright. The mechanical switches are of very high quality and seem like they will last for quite awhile.The reason I chose this is so I could also remove the keyboard and use it at a desk (in the future). The keyboard came with a good sized cord as well as a arm rest for desk setups. Overall I recommend this product, and at $60 for the board and $90 for the keyboard it is fairly priced.

review.title: Most features only work when it's plugged in
review.review: While this has an impressive feature list for a wireless keyboard, most of the features only work when it's plugged in. They're so obsessed with goofy animated lighting effects and low-latency key response that you can't even set a custom solid color for it to use while it's operating wirelessly. The macro facility, which is quite powerful once you get past the awful iCUE UI, allows you to emulate mouse actions and almost anything else... but it also only works when the keyboard is plugged into USB.The wireless also disconnects about once an hour and takes longer than any keyboard I've ever used to reconnect after a disconnect or going to sleep--up to 10 seconds. Lots of fun when it disconnects with a key stuck down.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Key spam, broken keys, RMA issues.
review.review: Honestly this board has been a bigger headache than what it was worth. The purpose was to get a nice full sized board with silent linear switches to replace another small board I was using.The first problem to occur was a constant key spam issue. Support was helpful and RMA'd the unit. The process was archaic and a pain to complete. Requiring RMA numbers all over the box, and a paper trail explaining the issue and why RMA was the resolution. FedEx was way more helpful with the shipping process and getting everything sorted out.Took a week or two to get a new board from Hong Kong which wasn't too slow for the distance. The replacement board immediately had an issue with the Numpad 8 key being chipped on the inside probably from a manufacturing issue. Razer's solution is to replace the entire board for a singular keycap. This is pretty unfortunate and I will just be picking up a custom set of caps. Anyone else looking for this board just be warned if there are any problems expect to be out of a board for a week or two. Also bring your own caps because the ones provided are cheap.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Horrible battery life, bad connections
review.review: I was excited to receive this keyboard.I had been watching it for a while and finally decided to buy it.It is not cheap, and being a Razer product, I was expecting something really good.Instead, I am returning the keyboard due to really poor performance.After I received the keyboard I immediately removed it from the packaging and plugged it in so it would charge.Once fully charged, I kept the keyboard plugged in via the supplied USB cable to do the setup and customization.I did not want to drain the battery at all during this processes.Once everything was setup, I "Synced" the keyboard to the computer using the supplied 2.4 GHz Hyperspeed Dongle.Once all setup was complete, I disconnected the USB cable so I could use it wirelessly.My first issue with the keyboard is how loud it is.I did my research on this keyboard before buying it and selected the Yellow keys - "silent and linear".I fully understand mechanical keys are not perfectly silent, but this is the loudest keyboard I have ever used, and I have been in the technology field for a long time, so I have used some old mechanical keyboards.This is the least of my issues with the keyboard, as this could possibly be ignored, but it was an issue, so I wanted to make sure to get it out there that this is a LOUD keyboard.My second issue was the connection.This keyboard would lose connection at times when using the "Hyperspeed" connection.I would have to patiently wait a while for it to connect again, or turn the keyboard off and back on again.Please note, the computer is only about 3 feet away from the keyboard with nothing obstructing the signal between the two items.I decided to try the Bluetooth connection...no luck.My computer has no problem detecting other Bluetooth devices, no matter what the device is, the age, or the brand.However, my computer could never "find" this keyboard.I even tried making sure it was the only Bluetooth device in the area turned on, and it still never found it.So, my only course of action was to plug the "wireless" keyboard in with the supplied USB cable to ensure I would not lose connection with the computer.My third issue.Not sure how to describe this, but it would randomly do things.After having the wireless keyboard plugged in as a wired keyboard (if you can't tell I am frustrated about this, I am), I would be typing and it would randomly open the start menu or task manager.Other times it would just randomly throw up a string of letters that I didn't type.I am not sure how this happened, and only happened a few times before I decided to box this up and start the return process, but it was weird and random.I have never seen that before with.My final issue, and perhaps the most important was the battery life.As I indicated earlier I let the keyboard fully charge before using, and I kept it plugged in while doing the initial setup.I had the keyboard unplugged and working as a wireless keyboard for maybe a little over an hour before reconnecting to become a wired keyboard.Of course, during that time I had the lights going and was using it as a normal keyboard (not gaming, just internet and email) and of course fighting the connection issues.When I pugged the keyboard back in and went back into the Razer Synapse application, I noticed the battery charge had dropped to 76%.WHAT?!?!?!In just over an hour the battery was drained 24%?This is ridiculous.The keyboard I was replacing (and now using for this review) is a wireless backlit keyboard that only needs to be charged once every few months.This keyboard would not even make it through a full day using it as designed with lights active.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming as it would surely die before the game is finished.So my options now were to either leave the keyboard plugged in, which defeats the purpose of buying a wireless keyboard (and deal with the weird random letters and opening of other applications); or turning the light effects off to save battery life, which defeats the purpose of buying an expensive RGB keyboard.Either way, I would not get what I paid a lot of money for.So, I am returning the keyboard.
product.title: Razer BlackWidow V3 Pro Mechanical Wireless Gaming Keyboard: Green Mechanical Switches - Tactile & Clicky - Chroma RGB Lig...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: Stopped Connecting to Anything After Just 2 Months of Use
review.review: I got this keyboard to replace a Huntsman optical that overall was doing great, but I had an issue with the volume knob (which I use quite regularly) and for me it wasn't the best tying experience for working and gaming. I needed a keyboard that was a little more clicky as I was accidentally hitting other keys with the very short travel of the Huntsman optical. I also wanted wireless so I could pair my work laptop via bluetooth and either connect via a cable or dongle with my personal computer.The Blackwidow V3 Pro at first was amazing. Connected quickly and reliably, the typing experience was much better for my work, the volume knob worked great unlike my Huntsman optical, and the RGB matched perfectly with my other peripherals, and I was in heaven.Then the 2-3 key presses started happening. This wasn't something I noticed with a lot of reviews when I purchased this, but looking back this is a huge problem with this keyboard. This is very problematic depending on what type of game you're playing or if you're pulling double duty and using this keyboard for work. Constantly editing emails or documents was getting very old.I also ran into connection issues after just a month. At first it was just not connecting to bluetooth as quickly, but then if I was using the 2.4Ghz dongle on my personal rig during a game, it would just cut out. It was 3 feet away and within perfect line of sight. Then it got so bad I had to just start plugging it in to game because of random disconnects. It also started randomly flashing the lights.Then today it just stopped connecting to anything. Won't connect to bluetooth, the 2.4ghz dongle or a wired connection. It won't pair with anything new but I was able to reset it and then update the firmware. Then it registers with Synapse if I have it plugged in, but it is still not usable at all. No key presses will register. Also if I press keys while it's connected via the USB cord, it will do random colors like rainbow wave, or do green pulse from where I push the key. The keyboard is entirely useless now after just 2 months.Do not buy this keyboard, or if you do, get a warranty. This is the 2nd Razer keyboard in a row that's had problem. I've typically loved the feel of Razer products, but $500 of peripherals that have either had issues or bit the dust in 2 years is too much. Buyer beware.
product.title: Razer BlackWidow V3 Pro Mechanical Wireless Gaming Keyboard: Green Mechanical Switches - Tactile & Clicky - Chroma RGB Lig...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. But this maybe a con for someone else.I have seen this issue on many other reviews and I have the same major issue. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. As of today (10/4/21) I am sending the first unit back and am receiving the new unit this week.I will update this review with my experience going forward with the replacement.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: NOT a gaming keyboard!
review.review: How in the hell did Logitech get away with labeling this as a gaming keyboard?It's "mechanical" keys are slimy feeling- just like membrane keys. A non-removable palm rest. And idk bout y'all but when I game, it's in the pitch black darkness. I need backlit keys or light of some kind! I'm good on this one. Returned and getting the 915 with beautiful clicky keys.And since I got the combo. the MX Master is not a BAD mouse either... it's ergonomically fitting to my hand, a nice change to the sometimes too-small gaming mice that Logitech designs for my bigger hands.. But the side scroll is defunct and the forward/back buttons are literally on top of each other in a diagonal fashion. This makes it very tough to hit the correct button the first time. Worst of all however is the fact the polling rate is only 125hz. They say you miss 100% of the shots you don't take.. well with this mouse you can take 100 shots and miss a damn well lot of them due to the low rate. Again, returning this as well and getting the G502 wireless.Logitech needs to rethink their branding for this keyboard/mouse. You can even see from a lot of the reviewers here, this is ideally an OFFICE keyboard/mouse setup. Not a gaming setup! The gaming equivalents are the G915 keyboard and G502 or G903 or G604 or G703 or.. y'know what? There's a lot of good logitech gaming mice out there.. But just 1 (wireless) gaming keyboard by logitech worth it's price.
product.title: Logitech G613 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Multihost 2.4 GHz + Blutooth Connectivity - Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Bought 2, switches went bad in both, manually soldering in new switches is a pain!
review.review: The first keyboard I purchased started having bad switch issues about 3 months in. The switches would routinely duplicate the letters, and at one point even the backspace key failed (same style switch). Thankfully the switches are replaceable with a little soldering skill, but this is a real nuisance. Because I was in a rush (and thinking Logitech may have just gotten a bad batch of switches during assembly), I bought a second keyboard, identical model, different batch. STILL having switch failures. On the original keyboard I have now replaced a total of EIGHT switches, on the newer one I've had to replace two.Until/unless Logitech gets better switches I would avoid this keyboard. I didn't bother going through customer service because I knew I could repair this issue myself, but not everyone has the tools or is handy. If you're handy and don't mind replacing switches, I've otherwise enjoyed the keyboard. Keystrokes are nice, responsiveness is excellent, and the range of the wireless is great. But c'mon Logitech, for the cost of this keyboard I shouldn't be having switch issues. Two stars because this is a serious flaw.
product.title: Logitech G613 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Multihost 2.4 GHz + Blutooth Connectivity - Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Much dimmer key light and lightweight/flimsy feel compared to my mechanical keyboard
review.review: I bought this to replace a backlit, but non-RGB tenkeyless mechanical keyboard with this one. My initial reactions were that the spacebar was WAY WAY WAY too loud, the keyboard tactile feedback felt cheap and hollow, and that the backlight was only about half as bright as my non-RGB backlit keyboard.I searched on youtube and found a lot of people who had felt the same way about the loud spacebar sound. I even watched some videos where people had put keyboard o-rings on and reported NO DIFFERENCE. I watched a video where someone put TWO sets of o-rings on the keys and reported NO DIFFERENCE.So... I ordered a set of 40A and 80A orings, and put the 40A on first, then the 80A, and after doing that, I felt that the tactile feedback seemed good and the spacebar sound was acceptably dampened.At this point, I replaced my MAX Blackbird Tenkeyless with my quieted Razer Huntsman. My initial reaction was that the MAX Blackbird is WAY more durable and substantial, and that while RGB is fun, the backlighting on the MAX Blackbird was literally about twice as bright. I debated for a long time about just putting this keyboard in my parts box and keep using my old keyboard.But, I'd already invested the time and since having RGB keyboard/mouse/mouse pad had been so important to me for some intangible reason, I stuck with it.Aside from the flimsier keycaps, and noisy keys, the opto-mechanical switches are REALLY FAST and I have no complaints about this keyboard for gaming. The downside of this to me is that I'm finding that I'm making a LOT more typing errors with this keyboard as the keys are much more sensitive (too sensitive?), but I'm adapting.I just wish there were a higher end Razer tenkeyless keyboard that felt more substantial, had twice the brightness, and had a purchase option for pudding keycaps (since you can't find a set that 100% fits this keyboard).
product.title: Razer Huntsman Tournament Edition TKL Tenkeyless Gaming Keyboard: Fastest Keyboard Switches Ever - Linear Optical Switches...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: Don't waste your time.
review.review: I've owned this keyboard for 6 months now. I initially loved it. However, there is a known issue with these devices where they will begin spamming inputs. Razer support recommends Hard resetting device by holding Capslock+Esc+spacebar and unplugging and replugging device. This WILL NOT resolve this issue. They also further recommend that people update the firmware. The kicker is that even though this Keyboard was released over 2 years ago it DOES NOT have a firmware update tool like the huntsman, Huntsman Elite, and mini have. Meaning if and when this happens to you you're completely dead in the water. My recommendation would be to just put $100 in a shoe box, wait six months and light it on fire. It'll be the same quality of investment as buying this keyboard.

That means it's razers trash ass programming!!!!!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Buy the V2, this one is just bad.
review.review: Was hunting to replace a Razer Blackwidow V2 tournament. Grabbed this unit as I wanted to move to mechano-optical switches and wanted to find the lower keyboard latency available.The V1 of this keyboard has issues.While it's not a "clicky" keyboard, bottoming out they keys has a very audible thunk.The V2 is nearly silent.Second, the keys on this, the V1 of the huntsman feel "lose" with a lot of lateral movement that throws off typing and adds additional noise to using it.The V2 huntsman has no lateral key movement, and no noise because of it.Finally, the V1 huntsman keys, while feeling light, with the springs having a lot of easy movement, resulting in a lot of misfires when gaming and moving fingers.The V2 feel hefty, with a good give but a weight that makes it feel solid.I hate, HATE, the V1 huntsman, but absolutely LOVE the V2 huntsman.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: Wireless doesn't work. Horrible layout. Shady company.
review.review: First thing to know is that the Bluetooth functionality with this keyboard is 100% broken and will not work for any length of time. When it does, the keyboard enters sleep mode with no actual way to turn it off, regardless of what their software or firmware updates claim to have fixed. After a replacement and several firmware upgrades over the year and a half it rarely, if ever, connects wirelessly, and when it does, the battery lasts an hour tops. Since this is advertised as a Bluetooth keyboard I'd call this listing borderline fraudulent.The layout choice is also horrible - question mark key placement is idiosyncratic to this keyboard so you have to retrain your muscle memory. Other 60% boards do not make this very obvious and avoidable mistake.RGB functionality is mediocre but the backlighting itself is more than adequate and has several color presets and brightness settings.The support and documentation are both absolutely abysmal. It's obvious none of the people working for Dierya have the English skills necessary to support a product this complicated in the US market.Finally, switches and keycaps are just okay. It might be nice if all you're used to are rubber domes, but there are better options than this out there that are worth the money.Long story short, look elsewhere.
product.title: DIERYA DK63 60% Keyboard with Dedicated Arrow Keys, Wireless Wired Mechanical Gaming Computer Keyboard True RGB LED Backli...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Review one month after purchase
review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. A lot of my comments follow what other reviews have said.Yes the keyboard is a bit loud as others have stated, but it isn't an issue for me, so I couldn't put it as a pro or con.Pros -The keyboard feels nice, it is heavy and feels like it has quality materials.The lighting controls work with the iCUE software and there are many customizable options and profiles.responsiveness of the keyboard is great.Cons -Unfortunately there are no ports on this keyboard, but I dont tend to use them myself. But this maybe a con for someone else.I have seen this issue on many other reviews and I have the same major issue. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. As of today (10/4/21) I am sending the first unit back and am receiving the new unit this week.I will update this review with my experience going forward with the replacement.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Great initially, but not built to last
review.review: I bought this keyboard in November of 2018. I am a casual gamer, and I really enjoyed the bright colors and the Cherry MX Speed keys. I have never had a keyboard with dedicated macro keys before, and the keyboard itself seemed quite sturdy.Fast-forward to today, and I am having some annoying difficulties with this keyboard that others have noted in the reviews. It does not happen every time, but often when I try to type an "A" it ends up writing "AA" or "AAA". It does not happen every time I press the button either, which only makes it more annoying. As another reviewer noted, this seems to be due to using WASD keys more than the others.In addition, I find that the spacebar is difficult to use in some games. Unless I perfectly hit it in the middle on every press, it will over time begin to slope downward to the left (when my left hand is on WASD my thumb naturally falls just left of the center of the spacebar). This eventually results in the spacebar not registering all of my presses until I press down on the right side and get it back to level.Lastly, switching between users on my computer often causes the keyboard software to glitch and refuse to work until I unplug the USB and plug it back in.None of these issues seem like major concerns, but I bought this keyboard thinking that it would last longer than 3 years. I guess Corsair just does not build them to last.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Ok at first, but the keys break quickly
review.review: I really like this keyboard at first, I was a little concerned with how loud the keys were and if they would be disruptive on a conference call, but people said they couldn’t really hear them. My major problem with this keyboard is the keys start to break.The plastic that makes up the cross pattern that connects the key to the keyboard seems to be very weak. Within about 2 months or so of owning it, the left side control key broke. To Corsairs credit they sent me a replacement key very quickly, but a few months after that the right control key started to come loose.What I have noticed is it is the keys that are around the edge of the keyboard that have the issue. What I believe it to be is it is the keys that you aren’t pressing at a straight up and down, it is the keys that you are reaching over to with your pinky fingers that are really the problem. I have a feeling overtime they would all start to break down, but the ones that are getting more pressure at an angle are just breaking first.Long story short, I replacing this and going back to my trusted Logitech keyboard because, while their customer service was great, I can’t be waiting for replacement keys every couple months.If this is primarily used for gaming and not a combination of day-to-day and gaming I would say it will last you a while, but if you’re thinking about getting this for your day-to-day I wouldn’t recommend it.
product.title: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum Mechanical Gaming Keyboard -6x Programmable Macro Keys - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Tac...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: So fragile that arrived damaged 2 times
review.review: This item may work well if it can be received undamaged, but I will never know.First box arrived, double boxed but no padding between inner and outer box, with several of the keys popped off and loose in the box.Amazon promptly replaced it with the same item packaged the same way and with many of the keys popped off.This time, I thought that maybe the keys are designed to be able to be removed easily for cleaning and maintenance and attempted to snap them back into place.This was successful with all but 2 of the keys, which could not be snapped back into place without them being tilted at an odd angle, despite several attempts to do so.Feels good in terms of weight and seems like a solid build except for the keys, has good features, and was recommended by a trusted computer sales person.The deal breaker is that this is a keyboard without keys that can actually be attached and aligned properly.
product.title: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum Mechanical Gaming Keyboard -6x Programmable Macro Keys - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Tac...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review.title: Great keyboard for gaming, few annoyances nothing major
review.review: I've used this keyboard for about a year. first off it has been great and I do recommend it. I use it for intense MMO gaming and it provides everything I require. It is a bit loud but expected for this type of keyboard. the keys off to the left to create macros. I've never created any before this and use the Icue system it was realitivly easy to figure out but there was a slight learning curve through guess and check but got everything working the way i wanted. Lightning is great and customizable. easy to switch it up or just cut it off.Now for the errors. seems to be few. Had to uninstall and reinstall the icue system because it got corrupted two times during my use somehow. Had a few issues reinstalling and getting everything working the 2nd time.The biggest annoyance (at least its something small) is the volume buttons on top right to mute, lower or raise the volume will just stop working. ill restart icue but that wont work. The only way to fix this is either A: restarting the computer sometimes fixes it. B: Go to settings in Icue and force update the firmware. even though you are currently on that firmware you have to force update it so it starts working again. While this is a rather simple fix. I've had this issue for over a year and it still hasn't been fixed but is a known issue (i found it by googling forums)
product.title: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum Mechanical Gaming Keyboard -6x Programmable Macro Keys - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Tac...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: Nice, but not perfect.
review.review: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum XT Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Backlit RGB LED, Cherry MX RGB Blue, Black.I bought this keyboard to replace a similar G. Skill keyboard that had long since broken. This new keyboard works pretty much as advertised and looks pretty darn cool!Pros:Solidly builtCherry MX RGB options ( I choose Blue as I prefer a "clicky" keyboard.)PBT double-shot keycap set (It is nice to know that the graphics will not rub off with these keycaps.)Cons:PBT double-shot keycap set-(the graphic layout of the number keycaps 1!, 2@, 3#, 4$, etc., looks much more cluttered/congested than the traditional visual layout. Also, the abbreviated keycaps PSC, SLK, BRK, etc., puts my brain on pause every time I look at those keys. Finally, the tactile bumps on the F and J keys are way too subtle for my sense of touch.)Integrated USB Port (I don't need or want it, nor do I want the resulting increase in the diameter of the keyboard cord.)No large L-shaped Enter key.Yeah, I still miss that!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2021
review.title: Terrible Light Blead and color representation. There are so many better options for your keyboard!
review.review: This BEST part of Corsair's newest generation of keyboards is they now use a standard bottom row. This means that you can put almost any keycap set you want on your fancy new keyboard and really make it your own one of a kind keyboard. You are no longer beholden to Corsair's proprietary first party keycap sets. Which is a good thing because these Corsair key caps kind of suck.I've posted some pictures of my K65 keyboard to show what I mean. You can see that the light bleed on these keycaps is just terrible. The red keys in the picture are corsair and the white and blue keycaps are from a third party (drop, I think). On the red switches the entire area around the lettering glows meaning that they are thin in that area. The white switches the only theletter lights up more without the bleed. This is especially true with higher brightness levels and colors closer to white. On the red keycaps when the RGB is set to pure white the color comes through as a deeper pink. The same could be said of the blue third party caps, but it's not nearly as bad.On the upside these keycaps feel good and will fit just about any keyboard, but you can spend the same money and get a much better keycap from places like Drop, Ducky, HyperX or just about anywhere else.Do yourself a favor- look elsewhere.
product.title: CORSAIR PBT Double-Shot PRO Keycap Mod Kit – Double-Shot PBT Keycaps – Onyx Black – Standard Bottom Row – Textured Surface...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021
review.title: Perfect keycap set for my k70 rgb rapifire mk.1
review.review: I tried multiple keycap sets from amazon both the off brand pudding caps and even the hyper x brand puddingd caps and even with buying the special add on set off bottom row keys for my corsair k70 rapidfire none of those sets looked anything like the pictures on the listing. The off brand had a really ugly font and bad quality and even though the hyper x font was better it was incredibly small font compared to my stock corsair caps. I was about to just cut my looses and go back to the stock abs caps when i found these actual corsait pbt caps that not only fit my keyboard perfect have noce large font and the major bonus of being available in arctic white among a few other awesome colors. These corsair caps are exactly what i wanted all along and are basically the same price as the hyper x set but have a way better unboxing presentation. Thank you corsair once again for having exactly what i was looking for to make typing and gaming on my corsair keyboard much more pleasurable. Corsair is usually ine of the most expensive options for pc accessories (rgb fans, aio cooler etc) but they hit the nail right on the head with this keycap line.
product.title: CORSAIR PBT Double-Shot PRO Keycap Mod Kit – Double-Shot PBT Keycaps – Onyx Black – Standard Bottom Row – Textured Surface...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Most features only work when it's plugged in
review.review: While this has an impressive feature list for a wireless keyboard, most of the features only work when it's plugged in. They're so obsessed with goofy animated lighting effects and low-latency key response that you can't even set a custom solid color for it to use while it's operating wirelessly. The macro facility, which is quite powerful once you get past the awful iCUE UI, allows you to emulate mouse actions and almost anything else... but it also only works when the keyboard is plugged into USB.The wireless also disconnects about once an hour and takes longer than any keyboard I've ever used to reconnect after a disconnect or going to sleep--up to 10 seconds. Lots of fun when it disconnects with a key stuck down.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Review one month after purchase
review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. A lot of my comments follow what other reviews have said.Yes the keyboard is a bit loud as others have stated, but it isn't an issue for me, so I couldn't put it as a pro or con.Pros -The keyboard feels nice, it is heavy and feels like it has quality materials.The lighting controls work with the iCUE software and there are many customizable options and profiles.responsiveness of the keyboard is great.Cons -Unfortunately there are no ports on this keyboard, but I dont tend to use them myself. But this maybe a con for someone else.I have seen this issue on many other reviews and I have the same major issue. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. As of today (10/4/21) I am sending the first unit back and am receiving the new unit this week.I will update this review with my experience going forward with the replacement.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.
product.title: Corsair K60 RGB Pro SE Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - Cherry Mechanical Keyswitches - Durable AluminumFrame - Customizable P...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2019
review.title: Fine for gaming but very bad for typing
review.review: Whenever I type with this keyboard it either misses letters or double/triple types the letter. For example if I try to type "Review" I might end up with "Rvieeew". So I spend double the time going back to fix those mistakes. This happens all the time and multiple words within the same sentence. I have read other reviews complaining of the same behavior and have tried all the proposed "fixes" but nothing worked for me except for reducing the polling rate from the CUE software and that just reduced the number of mistypes. Initially it would type the same letter 4 or 5 times, now it does it 2 or 3 times but still makes the same number of mistakes.In gaming you will not notice this and for that purpose it works as described, the feel of the keys is great and it is as silent as can be for a mechanical keyboard. But who wants a keyboard they cannot type on??

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2018
review.title: Very disappointed
review.review: Lots of praise for this keyboard and lots of great reviews. Out of the box it was an awesome keyboard.Only used it for a few months ended up not using my gaming rig for 6 months come back to it and the keyboard is pretty much useless. I ran diagnostics with switch hitter and its showing over 50% of the keys are "double typing" 50% of the time. It's a known issue with the keyboard there's tons of people out there that have had the same problem. I thought about sending it into Corsair but all the forum posts read the same. People who got rma's ended up experiencing the same issue with the replacement keyboard. And not just the Cherry MX Silent switches, other switches as well.Someone claimed a home fix by spraying silicone spray or WD-40 into every individual switch. I'm not interested doing that on one of the most expensive components of my gaming rig. Likely going to toss 180$ keyboard in the trash. Very disappointed, cannot recommend this keyboard.

This is my first mechanical keyboard and I absolutely loathe the clicks of regular switches. This one doesn't click unless I full bottom out, but saying it clicks is an overstatement. Comes with extra WASD and QWERF keys for FPS and MMO respectively, since I play both I just put them both on. No issues.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review.title: Quality keyboard, with an aluminum frame and cherry low profile switches that are way too sensitive
review.review: +++The build quality is good.+++The RGB lighting is good.o The extremely thick and sturdy dual USB cable is total overkill, yet the Keyboard pass-through connection is only USB 2-- the Software provided to control the RGB functions is pretty terrible and Corsair admitted, that the available instructions on how to use this software are incomplete!What was the worst for me personally was the sensitivity of the keys. Just resting my fingers on the keys will cause unintended activations - which caused me endless typos when typing and problems in games, doing things I had no intention to do.This may be different for you, as I am used to Logitech keyboards with tactile keys and low travel, where you have to push the key past the tactile "hump" before you get any activation.So if you are used to non-tactile cherry switches, you can disregard that part of my review.It was surprising to me, to have keys with quite more travel than I'm used to, but that would activate at the very top position.I assume some gamers want just that, so they have faster activations.For me, that was catastrophic and I returned this and ordered another Logitech keyboard - also designed for gaming, but with tactile + clicky keys.I would have gone for just tactile, but those were sold out... ah well:)Hopefully this helps someone who might otherwise end up with the wrong keyboard...Note, that low profile switches that are also tactile seem to be unavailable from Cherry!I give 4 stars, because keys are a personal choice and what doesn't work for me might work for you.
product.title: CORSAIR K70 RGB MK.2 RAPIDFIRE Low Profile - Backlit RGB LED - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Fastest & Linear Low Pro...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021
review.title: Finally, a low-profile mechanical!
review.review: I haven't tried many mechanical keyboard before this one, but they always felt too tall and chunky to me. I grew too accustomed to laptop keyboards in the mid 2000's, and then had a low-profile membrane gaming keyboard (Microsoft Sidewinder) for many years, and like that form factor. When I saw that Corsair, a brand I trust and whose mice I already adore, made a low profile mechanical board, I wanted to try it out. And it didn't disappoint! Love the mechanical feel, which is more stable and linear than the slightly wobbly keys of my old membrane board, without feeling uncomfortably tall like most standard mechanical boards feel to me.All the other features are awesome, too. The iCue software makes customizing the RGB super fun. You can program each key individually with dozens of patterns, in literally any color you can imagine. Corsair really has the best RGB ecosystem. On top of that, the USB passthrough is handy, and the media controls are super convenient. Also, the profile switch button makes it easy to change lighting on the fly, and since my computer lives near my bed, makes it easy to put my whole computer in "stealth mode" by switching to a profile that turns all the RGB off so it doesn't keep me up at night while my gaming rig passively mines crypto to help recoup the cost of building it.All in all, a solid 9.5/10. The only thing it's missing that my old keyboard had is a shortcut button for the calculator.
product.title: CORSAIR K70 RGB MK.2 RAPIDFIRE Low Profile - Backlit RGB LED - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Fastest & Linear Low Pro...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2021
review.title: Great Keyboard, Poor Lighting Quality
review.review: Update: I haven't even had the replacement keyboard a week and the escape key just flat out doesn't work. Do not buy this keyboard, it is pure junk.I really like the way this keyboard feels to type on. The low profile keys are nice, the switches are pretty quiet overall, and it feels very responsive. From a day to day use standpoint, I have absolutely zero complaints about this product. However, one of the reasons to buy a keyboard like this one is the lightning and that's where my issues begin.First, I am very, very lucky if iCUE, Corsair's peripheral management software, recognizes this keyboard, which means it's almost always either on the default rainbow state or stuck on one color (I have it set to rotate between three colors normally to match the lighting on my tower), plus I can't manage any of the keys or use custom keybinds. Often iCUE will even see the keyboard is connected but still won't let me manage it. This is remedied if I unplug it and plug it back in several times; basically, it will eventually always recognize it, but it's a question of how long I have to fidget with it and then a roll of the dice on how long it'll stay connected.Second, when it actually IS working with iCUE, typing on it causes the keys to randomly flash white on keystroke, which is definitely not a thing it should be doing. It's very distracting when every third or fourth keystroke causes the whole keyboard to be briefly bright white. This only happens when the keyboard's iCUE profile is actually working, though, so basically I am stuck with a situation where if the software doesn't see it, it doesn't work right, and if the software sees it, it doesn't work right in a completely different way.I sent the first of these back assuming it was a defect and the second one has all the exact same problems, so my suggestion would be to look elsewhere; I am sure you can get cheaper keyboards with similar keys and skip the lighting problems.
product.title: Corsair K70 RGB MK.2 Low Profile Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - Linear & Quiet, Backlit RGB LED, Cherry MX Low Profile Red

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2021
review.title: Perfect replacement for my Logitech G610
review.review: I had a Logitech keyboard last. This is not a knock against them, as every other product of theirs I've bought (which is many) has served me well, but the G610 was failing earlier than expected. So I needed a new keyboard.Every Corsair product I've ever bought significantly exceeded my expectations. This naturally causes my expectations to rise still further, and this keyboard still beat them. The Cherry Speed switches are quieter than what my last keyboard had, which I love. The required pressing force and travel to actuate them are quite light, which is great for extended use to prevent finger fatigue. Just make sure you're able to only hit the keys you want to press. Accidental actuation is possible.It's noticeably narrower than my G610. I've reclaimed about 3 inches of width on my desk. The spacebar is textured for some reason, but it's fine with me. So is the removable wrist rest, which makes a little more sense. There are 3 brightness settings, plus off. The brightest should be easily visible unless you're standing in direct sunlight at midday. The dimmest won't be irritating in a darkened room.It has a USB pass-through, which requires plugging in a second cable. This is optional and the keyboard will work just fine with only the one cable plugged in (make sure it's the right one; they are labeled). It comes with several replacement keys, and a tool to help replace keys.I did not want to spend $200 on their newest flagship board. I think this was wise; I could not imagine the additional cost being worth it, when this board is so good.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - CORSAIR K70 RGB TKL – Champion Series Tenkeyless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - Cherry MX Speed Keyswitches -...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.
