review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review.title: Quality keyboard, with an aluminum frame and cherry low profile switches that are way too sensitive
review.review: +++The build quality is good.+++The RGB lighting is good.o The extremely thick and sturdy dual USB cable is total overkill, yet the Keyboard pass-through connection is only USB 2-- the Software provided to control the RGB functions is pretty terrible and Corsair admitted, that the available instructions on how to use this software are incomplete!What was the worst for me personally was the sensitivity of the keys. Just resting my fingers on the keys will cause unintended activations - which caused me endless typos when typing and problems in games, doing things I had no intention to do.This may be different for you, as I am used to Logitech keyboards with tactile keys and low travel, where you have to push the key past the tactile "hump" before you get any activation.So if you are used to non-tactile cherry switches, you can disregard that part of my review.It was surprising to me, to have keys with quite more travel than I'm used to, but that would activate at the very top position.I assume some gamers want just that, so they have faster activations.For me, that was catastrophic and I returned this and ordered another Logitech keyboard - also designed for gaming, but with tactile + clicky keys.I would have gone for just tactile, but those were sold out... ah well:)Hopefully this helps someone who might otherwise end up with the wrong keyboard...Note, that low profile switches that are also tactile seem to be unavailable from Cherry!I give 4 stars, because keys are a personal choice and what doesn't work for me might work for you.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021
review.title: Finally, a low-profile mechanical!
review.review: I haven't tried many mechanical keyboard before this one, but they always felt too tall and chunky to me. I grew too accustomed to laptop keyboards in the mid 2000's, and then had a low-profile membrane gaming keyboard (Microsoft Sidewinder) for many years, and like that form factor. When I saw that Corsair, a brand I trust and whose mice I already adore, made a low profile mechanical board, I wanted to try it out. And it didn't disappoint! Love the mechanical feel, which is more stable and linear than the slightly wobbly keys of my old membrane board, without feeling uncomfortably tall like most standard mechanical boards feel to me.All the other features are awesome, too. The iCue software makes customizing the RGB super fun. You can program each key individually with dozens of patterns, in literally any color you can imagine. Corsair really has the best RGB ecosystem. On top of that, the USB passthrough is handy, and the media controls are super convenient. Also, the profile switch button makes it easy to change lighting on the fly, and since my computer lives near my bed, makes it easy to put my whole computer in "stealth mode" by switching to a profile that turns all the RGB off so it doesn't keep me up at night while my gaming rig passively mines crypto to help recoup the cost of building it.All in all, a solid 9.5/10. The only thing it's missing that my old keyboard had is a shortcut button for the calculator.
product.title: CORSAIR K70 RGB MK.2 RAPIDFIRE Low Profile - Backlit RGB LED - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Fastest & Linear Low Pro...

Do not buy this keyboard, it is pure junk.I really like the way this keyboard feels to type on. The low profile keys are nice, the switches are pretty quiet overall, and it feels very responsive. From a day to day use standpoint, I have absolutely zero complaints about this product. However, one of the reasons to buy a keyboard like this one is the lightning and that's where my issues begin.First, I am very, very lucky if iCUE, Corsair's peripheral management software, recognizes this keyboard, which means it's almost always either on the default rainbow state or stuck on one color (I have it set to rotate between three colors normally to match the lighting on my tower), plus I can't manage any of the keys or use custom keybinds. Often iCUE will even see the keyboard is connected but still won't let me manage it. This is remedied if I unplug it and plug it back in several times; basically, it will eventually always recognize it, but it's a question of how long I have to fidget with it and then a roll of the dice on how long it'll stay connected.Second, when it actually IS working with iCUE, typing on it causes the keys to randomly flash white on keystroke, which is definitely not a thing it should be doing. It's very distracting when every third or fourth keystroke causes the whole keyboard to be briefly bright white. This only happens when the keyboard's iCUE profile is actually working, though, so basically I am stuck with a situation where if the software doesn't see it, it doesn't work right, and if the software sees it, it doesn't work right in a completely different way.I sent the first of these back assuming it was a defect and the second one has all the exact same problems, so my suggestion would be to look elsewhere; I am sure you can get cheaper keyboards with similar keys and skip the lighting problems.
product.title: Corsair K70 RGB MK.2 Low Profile Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - Linear & Quiet, Backlit RGB LED, Cherry MX Low Profile Red

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2021
review.title: Good mouse broken keyboard.
review.review: I got this for my new PC build and I couldn't be happier with it. I guess my only complaint is the top, side, andbuttons and the right mouse button. You see, I usually swing my arm over at the mouse and often hit the side buttons. I just wish they were a bit more firm. The way I put my hand on the mouse, I often hold the right mouse button from the side and it feels "sticky" because it hangs off the side a bit too much.It works well with the Corsair iCue software and looks great. I especially like that you can control the whole setup from the mouse. The top two buttons switch between themes in the software so you can set profiles and cycle between them if you have RGB LED's in your rig like I do. Again, I wish they were more firm, because I keep hitting them and then my whole PC goes dark because I only have the one profile (for now). I just wish the keyboard didn't come damaged.The 6, Y. H, and B keys were all DOA. I assume they are connected in some way. The LED's lit up real nicely though. One of the keys also looked pressed in a bit. Perhaps that had something to do with it? It's very frustrating because I had problems with the motherboard and GPU as well. I'm probably not going to buy computer parts on Amazon anymore. Newegg is better for this, but I'll still buy other stuff maybe. This just puts a bad taste in my mouth. I was really looking forward to the dynamic duo of this packaged deal.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2021
review.title: Perfect replacement for my Logitech G610
review.review: I had a Logitech keyboard last. This is not a knock against them, as every other product of theirs I've bought (which is many) has served me well, but the G610 was failing earlier than expected. So I needed a new keyboard.Every Corsair product I've ever bought significantly exceeded my expectations. This naturally causes my expectations to rise still further, and this keyboard still beat them. The Cherry Speed switches are quieter than what my last keyboard had, which I love. The required pressing force and travel to actuate them are quite light, which is great for extended use to prevent finger fatigue. Just make sure you're able to only hit the keys you want to press. Accidental actuation is possible.It's noticeably narrower than my G610. I've reclaimed about 3 inches of width on my desk. The spacebar is textured for some reason, but it's fine with me. So is the removable wrist rest, which makes a little more sense. There are 3 brightness settings, plus off. The brightest should be easily visible unless you're standing in direct sunlight at midday. The dimmest won't be irritating in a darkened room.It has a USB pass-through, which requires plugging in a second cable. This is optional and the keyboard will work just fine with only the one cable plugged in (make sure it's the right one; they are labeled). It comes with several replacement keys, and a tool to help replace keys.I did not want to spend $200 on their newest flagship board. I think this was wise; I could not imagine the additional cost being worth it, when this board is so good.

review.title: Highest quality and most durable keyboard I've used.

I always eat at my desk and I've spilled my drink on it at least a dozen times, and each time I freak out a bit, put it by a fan overnight, and wake up with everything working just fine. I have a hard time finding durable peripherals, but several thousand hours of gaming and typing later, I have no complaints at all with my K70.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: Nice, but not perfect.
review.review: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum XT Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Backlit RGB LED, Cherry MX RGB Blue, Black.I bought this keyboard to replace a similar G. Skill keyboard that had long since broken. This new keyboard works pretty much as advertised and looks pretty darn cool!Pros:Solidly builtCherry MX RGB options ( I choose Blue as I prefer a "clicky" keyboard.)PBT double-shot keycap set (It is nice to know that the graphics will not rub off with these keycaps.)Cons:PBT double-shot keycap set-(the graphic layout of the number keycaps 1!, 2@, 3#, 4$, etc., looks much more cluttered/congested than the traditional visual layout. Also, the abbreviated keycaps PSC, SLK, BRK, etc., puts my brain on pause every time I look at those keys. Finally, the tactile bumps on the F and J keys are way too subtle for my sense of touch.)Integrated USB Port (I don't need or want it, nor do I want the resulting increase in the diameter of the keyboard cord.)No large L-shaped Enter key.Yeah, I still miss that!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Very nice keyboard - exceeded expectations
review.review: Not a keyboard snob here, usually buy cheap ones.Have owned expensive keyboards in past and theydidn't seem to give good value for cost.Was skeptical about buying this keyboard as its expensive.First impressions were it was constructed well and I really like the feel of the optical switches.Although sometimes I think I'm just resting my fingers on the keys and then I look and see its typing.Very sensitive which has its good side and down side.Able to type very fast but just have to be a little careful.But really like the feel of the switches.Thought I'd like mechanical switches better but these are working very good.RGB is excellent very pleased.Have this keyboard paired with 011D XL pc case with glass panels and lots of rgb so this keyboard works so well sitting next to it.Everything on iCue with commander pro.Running older version of iCue to be able to use older profiles.The newer version iCue had nothing but problems.Dont really used the built in profiles.Haven't saved my profiles onto my keyboard, I dont plan of traveling with keyboard.Really become big fan of multimedia keys it surprises me.I try to use dial but its just ok.Like the usb at the back.Cable is kind of big.Wrist rest is very comfortable.Overall fit and finish is very good.Final thoughts is this is a very nice keyboard although expensive.If you wait the prices seem to fluctuate a good amount.I just waited until I saw a good price to buy and saved a good amount that makes this keyboard a much better value.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: Great for a pricey gaming keyboard, not the best for customer support and software
review.review: First off, the keyboard is great and responsive for gaming.The keys feel great, the actuation point is fantastic for quick inputs while gaming, and the macro keys (G#) are helpful too even if just starting/stopping OBS or muting yourself in Discord.However, the software and Corsair side of it are not the best.The software can be very temperamental.Color zones and macros can be difficult to get into, and some only work if iCue is running in the backgroundAnd when it is running in the background, it can act buggy or hod resources if there's a waiting firmware or update.Finally the Optical version of the keyboard is entirely proprietary.If a switch stops working, or something happens that Corsair deems user defect, then they won't RMA it, and since it's proprietary, there's no way to get it repaired or the switch replaced as Corsair doesn't offer paid repair or replacement switches.They recommend buying a new $200 keyboard.Bottom-line is that there are better keyboards for price, and definitely better support for the price and effort as well.But if you do get it, it's a very friendly keyboard.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.title: Review one month after purchase
review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. A lot of my comments follow what other reviews have said.Yes the keyboard is a bit loud as others have stated, but it isn't an issue for me, so I couldn't put it as a pro or con.Pros -The keyboard feels nice, it is heavy and feels like it has quality materials.The lighting controls work with the iCUE software and there are many customizable options and profiles.responsiveness of the keyboard is great.Cons -Unfortunately there are no ports on this keyboard, but I dont tend to use them myself. But this maybe a con for someone else.I have seen this issue on many other reviews and I have the same major issue. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. As of today (10/4/21) I am sending the first unit back and am receiving the new unit this week.I will update this review with my experience going forward with the replacement.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Excellent headset and versatility, but subpar software
review.review: I want to preface this by saying I've had this headset for a year and a half and has held up well through the somewhat torture I've given it! Keep in mind I use this headset anywhere from 10-25 hours a week so if that gives you any idea as to how much I've used these, do with that as you will. Anyways here's a pros and cons list to simplify it with a summary to recap my thoughts on this headset.Pros:-The versatility of these headphones is great mainly because you can plug them into your pc or console, charge them and keep playing or just use them while plugged in, AND connect them to your phone with an aux cord if you wanna walk around with them and blast music.-The sound quality is phenomenal with highs being crisp and lows being bassy and the mids filling the gaps to make a smoothsound or listening to music a joy. The sound isolation is great as you can hear the footsteps of someone below, above, behind. It makes a very immersive experience as it can turn a roar from a zombie around the corner go from "ehh", to "holy hell what was that, and where did it come from" experience. Not always obviously, but I've never gotten an experience like this from any other headset.-They look great, and have held up well even though I can be a bit rough with them from time to time.-When Icue works the customization for the EQ is impressive and enhances the experience if done right. Though careful, with a custom EQ, because if you push it too high or low you could have distortion issues. Something to be aware of as I feel this is more of a software issue rather than the headsets ability to produce the desired sound you want.-Mic quality is superb wireless and connected. I've never had anyone have problems with my mic quality being poor or choppy. Only time there's issues with this is either some software, program, or internet issues and not the mic itself.Cons:-Not a surprise but the cost is up there, but honestly I've gotten my money's worth and they keep going strong after a year and a half so it's a con, but small at this point.-The ear cups are not made to last. I did have to replace the ear cups after about 6 months of regular use, and it wasn't the most comfortable tbh, but I found bigger/better replacement Earcups from a 3rd party that were more much comfortable and have held up better (I have a big head and ears so this was a great find) at the cost of loss to noise canceling it is "supposed" to have.-Battery life on these are pretty good, but not 20 hours as they advertise. Even when they were brand new I was getting MAYBE 14-16 hours if conditions were perfect, but not 20. This being said the LI-Ion battery still gets me a solid 10 hours on a full charge and the recharge is quick so I can just throw the cable on to charge while staying in "wireless" mode and then 30min have passed and it's back to green again so it's a con for not completely accurate advertising, but not terrible battery life by any stretch. Just unrealistic.Cons unrelated to the headset itself, but corsairs software issues:-RGB... Idk WHY, when you turn on the headset, the mic goes RGB and shows the rainbow, but then you can not customize the mic color at all. WHY show that off and then not come through. Solid miss there.-until recently I HATED ICue but I had no choice but to use it for my headset, but with some recent updates it's gotten better. Less buggy and more dependable, but when my headset acts up I usually look at ICue first to make sure it isn't the, poor excuse for, software causing the issue.-ICue is just a very subpar app and honestly needs some major work. Idk why it's as buggy as it is because this headset deserved better than this. I won't drag the rating down because of something the app does wrong where as the headset itself is pretty dang great.-I'm lumping this in the software issue seeing as it's controlled through Icue is the 7.1 surround sound is not phenomenal. It's pretty good in some games that have surround sound features enabled, but for movies, shows, music ect. It's not great as it sometimes cuts out the mids HARD to the point where sometimes an explosion sounds muffled or just wonky for a lack of a better term. Also the higher frequencies tend to get swollowed up during bassier sequences in whatever it is so it leaves it feeling hollow in many scenes. My advice is stick with the stereo setting as it does a pretty great job of sounding equal and correct in any setting rather than hit or miss with everything. Nifty idea that fell flat imo.-voice prompts... Just... Don't use that setting...Finally the...Summary:Overall I maybe leaving a few things out, but most of the cons on the headset itself are little or not a deal breaker (atleast for me), but things to think on how to improve the virtuoso descendants going forward. I personally love the headset itself and there's more I could say, but at this point you'll have based most of your decision on what I said earlier if you even made it this far lol. My biggest gripes are the ICue software we're forced to deal with as it maybe "esthetically" pleasing to look at. It's a far cry from great, or even good. As it stands now it works mostly, but the bugs drive me insane. The lack of thought to letting people mess with the mics light colors is what lends me to believe it's lazy or just cheap to not let people do what they want which is just rediculous to me. I digress from this bit of rage here. In all a great headset itself, but poor software to harness all of the greatness.Headset - 9/10 few fixes/adjustments and it would probably be perfectSoftware (Icue) - was 3 - now after many updates later 6/10. If they could focus on a great customer experience and fix the bugs rather than just cheap implementation of features or lack there of for that matter, and some which haven't changed. This would be a much better experience.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: El mejor auricular inalámbrico que alguna vez tuve. Mejorable
review.review: Es un excelente producto. Las terminaciones son muy buenas. Se nota que es premium y tiene calidad en la construcción.Compatibilidad con todo, menos con Xbox (aquí unicamente se puede usar de forma cableada al joystick). Lo podes conectar al celular por USB-C o bluetooth. Lo uso en la mac, en la PC con windows y en la play de forma inalámbrica o cableada.El micrófono, es el mejor micrófono inalámbrico que vi hasta el momento. No parece que fuera inalámbrico, es demasiado bueno, me vi muchas reviews donde streamers y youtubers lo usan para sus videos, en vez de un micrófono dedicado.La única contra que tiene es la duración de la batería, cuando las luces RGB que están a los costados están activadas.Y eso es prácticamente siempre, porque no tiene memoria interna, entonces la única forma de desactivar las luces es utilizando el software propietario ICUE (que no funciona bien todavía en las macs con chip apple m1). Esdecir solamente podemos tener una duración óptima de la batería cuando lo usamos con luces apagadas, y eso solo pasa en windows.Si no fuera por la duración de la batería, debe ser el auricular inalámbrico más perfecto que hay, para video llamadas en el trabajo, juegos en red, juegos offline, playstation (xbox, solo con cable), y con un microfono que con una precisión asombrosa. Repito el microfono debe ser el punto más alto del headset.Recomandable 100% si no te molesta cargarlo cada 2 dias usandolo en PS4/5 o en mac (al menos hasta el momento) En PC apagandole las luces, dura muchisimo más.

review.title: Shoddy materials
review.review: I've owned this product for a year, and before that anniversary date the M and N keys started fading rapidly on the edges, the O key constantly pops off, and the space bar has flaking paint. This keyboard has seen *light* use since I purchased it. I have had no time to game due to work so it amazes me that after one year that this keyboard wears so quickly. I've used other keyboards from Logitech and Reddragon that had lasted much longer for the same or cheaper price.When I went to RAZER about this, they told me it didn't fall under their warrantee and did not honor any RMA. I do not suggest buying from RAZER. They do not stand by their products which wear and fail quickly under normal or light use. I thought RAZER had high quality products but this is obviously not the case. I will be checking out a Corsair keyboard in the near future.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2021
review.title: It's expensive for a reason.
review.review: This is the first "super high end" keyboard I've bought.I laughed at the thought of spending more than $100 on a keyboard.However, my old one was having issues and I needed a new one.During my review searching, I kept seeing BlackWidow Elite mentioned. It showed up more than a few times.I checked it out and was like "No! I'm not paying almost $200 for that!" then I kept reading. And it showed up a lot.After doing tons of searching through Amazon, I ended up coming back to this one and doing more research. I was intrigued. I started looking for specific reviews about this keyboard. YouTube. Reddit. Amazon. And more...This keyboard has a lot going for it.It's surprising how many bells and whistles this comes with. Each individual key light can be controlled in some manner.The app for it (call Synapse...kind of like in the movie Antitrust) has tons of presets. And there's an entire community of people who make color themes for this. I love it. Someone is always coming up with something new and interesting.The app lets you set up macros and key binds for almost anything. And there's a bunch of other stuff I haven't even messed with.Synapse could use some QOL improvements and some upgrades. The layout design could use some love and navigating the app takes some getting used to. It's not horrible but there is definitely room for improvement. For what it is right now, it's a good app. I don't hate it.What I don't like is that the keyboard immediately prompts you to install Synapse as soon as you plug it in. I'm sure there are some people who want to use the keyboard as just a mechanical keyboard and they don't want to use the app. I'm not sure if this is an option for them, but it should be. A $200 keyboard should not force a software installation to be used.As I have not tried using my keyboard without Synapse, I can't expound on this topic other than to say the popup might be construed as "invasive" to some users.Another small thing I really like about the keyboard is the side USB plug. It's great for doing quick USB connecting and it's within arms reach at all times.I have USB 3.0 hub that I'm going to try connecting to it at some point to give me some additional ports.You also get a plug for audio in and audio out. I don't use these ports so they have no real effect on me and I can't comment on how the sound quality is. But I'm sure there are others who will love the quick audio port access. Especially if you have a tower that doesn't have easily accessible ports.Let's talk about the additional buttons that come with this. The ones not part of the standard 104.In the upper right corner, this keyboard comes with a spinner dial for controlling volume and a rather large mute button in the center of the dial. To the left of the dial are three media buttons. Rewind, play, and forward (in that order).Now, I like having media buttons. But I LOVE these things because, as a scripter, I can reassign these to do a multitude of things.Example: In my main script that I have running at all times, I wrote a piece of code that lets the dial control the main system volume normally but when the Windows key is held, the volume dial adjusts the sound of Winamp without me having to actually open Winamp (Winamp is a music player that has been around forever. I've used it for years and haven't found a better replacement for it.)On a side note, if you're curious about rebinding keys, making advanced custom macros, and more, check out the language AutoHotkey. It's completely free, it's one of the most user-friendly programming languages I know of, and the community loves teaching newcomers how to create programs. They have a very active main forum, subreddit, and Discord.Back to the review.Finally, I want to talk about the key switches. The Razer greens exceeded my expectations. I've been using this keyboard for long enough that I can comfortably say these keys are probably the best ones I've used.Before this, I had Cherry MX Blues and I loved those. But these greens seem like they're just a smidge better. They're really responsive. The pressure requirement per keypress is great. And I love the "clack" they make.There's something almost soothing and zen-like about listening to a keyboard talk as you create something.I do all the major things keyboards are used for: Gaming, coding, and composition.For gaming, it's all about response time and key pressure. The greens have been fantastic in both areas! I've set multiple new records on StepMania (think DDR for your fingers) using this keyboard. The switches seem to be so accurate that I'm hitting notes, rolls, and crossovers that I was having difficulties hitting before. I have a folder of favorite songs and I've gone up 1-2 grades on almost every song in there. Not only that, there are certain songs I had never finished that I've gotten past with this keyboard. I highly doubt that my skill level randomly jumped that much after getting this keyboard. Gotta give props where props are due.For coding and composition, all I care about is not missing keystrokes. Give me what I type.If I'm coding and I miss one letter/number, it can have a myriad of negative effects. It could be an easy error to find or it might be something so unnoticeable that it takes you forever to fix. Either way, I've never had an issue with keystrokes registering when I'm typing. And because the keyboard doesn't have a super high actuation rate, I don't get fatigued fingers after elongated sessions.Finally, I have never experienced any ghosting issues (that's where your keys don't register when you hold too many at once). Apparently, this keyboard has a 10-key rollover with anti-ghosting. I play a ton of different games and not ONCE have I had an issue where multiple keys were being held and some weren't registering. I've also noticed that comments like "BULLS#@T!!! I did too hit that button!!" have become almost non-existent. I couldn't be happier about that.TLDR: The BlackWidow Elite is a solid keyboard, it has great features, the Razer greens are some of the best switches I've ever used, the Synapse app is decent and has a lot of options, side ports are very convenient, the extra media buttons are always welcome, and it never ghosts or miss keystrokes.10/10 would buy again.*Authentic Greg Review*Thanks for reading this review. All of my reviews are 100% "Greg honest". I cannot be bought.Amazon's review system is going downhill. Paid review groups ravage this site and the removal of comment responses has made things worse.I strongly believe in uncompromised reviews where the goal is protecting the buyer and informing the masses.Let's look out for each other!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Great initially, but not built to last
review.review: I bought this keyboard in November of 2018. I am a casual gamer, and I really enjoyed the bright colors and the Cherry MX Speed keys. I have never had a keyboard with dedicated macro keys before, and the keyboard itself seemed quite sturdy.Fast-forward to today, and I am having some annoying difficulties with this keyboard that others have noted in the reviews. It does not happen every time, but often when I try to type an "A" it ends up writing "AA" or "AAA". It does not happen every time I press the button either, which only makes it more annoying. As another reviewer noted, this seems to be due to using WASD keys more than the others.In addition, I find that the spacebar is difficult to use in some games. Unless I perfectly hit it in the middle on every press, it will over time begin to slope downward to the left (when my left hand is on WASD my thumb naturally falls just left of the center of the spacebar). This eventually results in the spacebar not registering all of my presses until I press down on the right side and get it back to level.Lastly, switching between users on my computer often causes the keyboard software to glitch and refuse to work until I unplug the USB and plug it back in.None of these issues seem like major concerns, but I bought this keyboard thinking that it would last longer than 3 years. I guess Corsair just does not build them to last.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Ok at first, but the keys break quickly
review.review: I really like this keyboard at first, I was a little concerned with how loud the keys were and if they would be disruptive on a conference call, but people said they couldn’t really hear them. My major problem with this keyboard is the keys start to break.The plastic that makes up the cross pattern that connects the key to the keyboard seems to be very weak. Within about 2 months or so of owning it, the left side control key broke. To Corsairs credit they sent me a replacement key very quickly, but a few months after that the right control key started to come loose.What I have noticed is it is the keys that are around the edge of the keyboard that have the issue. What I believe it to be is it is the keys that you aren’t pressing at a straight up and down, it is the keys that you are reaching over to with your pinky fingers that are really the problem. I have a feeling overtime they would all start to break down, but the ones that are getting more pressure at an angle are just breaking first.Long story short, I replacing this and going back to my trusted Logitech keyboard because, while their customer service was great, I can’t be waiting for replacement keys every couple months.If this is primarily used for gaming and not a combination of day-to-day and gaming I would say it will last you a while, but if you’re thinking about getting this for your day-to-day I wouldn’t recommend it.
product.title: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum Mechanical Gaming Keyboard -6x Programmable Macro Keys - USB Passthrough & Media Controls - Tac...

review.title: So fragile that arrived damaged 2 times
review.review: This item may work well if it can be received undamaged, but I will never know.First box arrived, double boxed but no padding between inner and outer box, with several of the keys popped off and loose in the box.Amazon promptly replaced it with the same item packaged the same way and with many of the keys popped off.This time, I thought that maybe the keys are designed to be able to be removed easily for cleaning and maintenance and attempted to snap them back into place.This was successful with all but 2 of the keys, which could not be snapped back into place without them being tilted at an odd angle, despite several attempts to do so.Feels good in terms of weight and seems like a solid build except for the keys, has good features, and was recommended by a trusted computer sales person.The deal breaker is that this is a keyboard without keys that can actually be attached and aligned properly.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review.title: Great keyboard for gaming, few annoyances nothing major
review.review: I've used this keyboard for about a year. first off it has been great and I do recommend it. I use it for intense MMO gaming and it provides everything I require. It is a bit loud but expected for this type of keyboard. the keys off to the left to create macros. I've never created any before this and use the Icue system it was realitivly easy to figure out but there was a slight learning curve through guess and check but got everything working the way i wanted. Lightning is great and customizable. easy to switch it up or just cut it off.Now for the errors. seems to be few. Had to uninstall and reinstall the icue system because it got corrupted two times during my use somehow. Had a few issues reinstalling and getting everything working the 2nd time.The biggest annoyance (at least its something small) is the volume buttons on top right to mute, lower or raise the volume will just stop working. ill restart icue but that wont work. The only way to fix this is either A: restarting the computer sometimes fixes it. B: Go to settings in Icue and force update the firmware. even though you are currently on that firmware you have to force update it so it starts working again. While this is a rather simple fix. I've had this issue for over a year and it still hasn't been fixed but is a known issue (i found it by googling forums)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2019
review.title: Fine for gaming but very bad for typing
review.review: Whenever I type with this keyboard it either misses letters or double/triple types the letter. For example if I try to type "Review" I might end up with "Rvieeew". So I spend double the time going back to fix those mistakes. This happens all the time and multiple words within the same sentence. I have read other reviews complaining of the same behavior and have tried all the proposed "fixes" but nothing worked for me except for reducing the polling rate from the CUE software and that just reduced the number of mistypes. Initially it would type the same letter 4 or 5 times, now it does it 2 or 3 times but still makes the same number of mistakes.In gaming you will not notice this and for that purpose it works as described, the feel of the keys is great and it is as silent as can be for a mechanical keyboard. But who wants a keyboard they cannot type on??

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2018
review.title: Very disappointed
review.review: Lots of praise for this keyboard and lots of great reviews. Out of the box it was an awesome keyboard.Only used it for a few months ended up not using my gaming rig for 6 months come back to it and the keyboard is pretty much useless. I ran diagnostics with switch hitter and its showing over 50% of the keys are "double typing" 50% of the time. It's a known issue with the keyboard there's tons of people out there that have had the same problem. I thought about sending it into Corsair but all the forum posts read the same. People who got rma's ended up experiencing the same issue with the replacement keyboard. And not just the Cherry MX Silent switches, other switches as well.Someone claimed a home fix by spraying silicone spray or WD-40 into every individual switch. I'm not interested doing that on one of the most expensive components of my gaming rig. Likely going to toss 180$ keyboard in the trash. Very disappointed, cannot recommend this keyboard.

This is my first mechanical keyboard and I absolutely loathe the clicks of regular switches. This one doesn't click unless I full bottom out, but saying it clicks is an overstatement. Comes with extra WASD and QWERF keys for FPS and MMO respectively, since I play both I just put them both on. No issues.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: Nice, but not perfect.
review.review: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum XT Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Backlit RGB LED, Cherry MX RGB Blue, Black.I bought this keyboard to replace a similar G. Skill keyboard that had long since broken. This new keyboard works pretty much as advertised and looks pretty darn cool!Pros:Solidly builtCherry MX RGB options ( I choose Blue as I prefer a "clicky" keyboard.)PBT double-shot keycap set (It is nice to know that the graphics will not rub off with these keycaps.)Cons:PBT double-shot keycap set-(the graphic layout of the number keycaps 1!, 2@, 3#, 4$, etc., looks much more cluttered/congested than the traditional visual layout. Also, the abbreviated keycaps PSC, SLK, BRK, etc., puts my brain on pause every time I look at those keys. Finally, the tactile bumps on the F and J keys are way too subtle for my sense of touch.)Integrated USB Port (I don't need or want it, nor do I want the resulting increase in the diameter of the keyboard cord.)No large L-shaped Enter key.Yeah, I still miss that!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.review_data: Reviewed in Italy on October 23, 2019
review.title: Mouse semplice
review.review: Premetto che ho acquistato questo mouse cablato scontato a 14€. E' ergonomico, ben fatto e resistente. Ha un tasto centrare per cambiare l'impostazione dei dpi. La colorazione del led può essere solo rossa e può essere regolata di l'intensità e di intermittenza o dissolvenza solo tramite il software iCUE della Corsair scaricabile gratuitamente. Ma non ne vale la pena installare iCUE per gestirlo. Anche perché ogni volta che si avvia il pc, il mouse non memorizza lo stato scelto, ma riparte con quello di default sino all'inizializzazione di Windows, o meglio, all'apertura in background del software iCUE all'avvio. Per questo lo utilizzo sempre con lo stato di default. Ricapitolando e considerando che di listino è sopra i 40€, non posso dare assolutamente una valutazione positiva dato che a questo prezzo c'è assolutamente di meglio con neanche un minimo di paragone. Quindi 5 stelle se è costa massimo 14€, 1 stella altrimenti.
product.title: Corsair KATAR Ambidextrous Gaming Mouse

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Mouse is lagging all the time
review.review: I ordered this mouse because I wanted to switch to wireless mouse experience. I really like this mouse, nice and comfortable design and it fits perfectely in my hand with my claw grip.The only thing that keeps me back to give it 5 stars is the wireless modes. when I switch to 2.4GHz Slipstream wireless mode I get so much lags every 5 seconds which is awful for gaming, you just can't play games like this. When I switch to Bluetooth mode the amount of lags decrease but not completely and you can't controll the RGB lightning when using Bluetooth mode.I have to use the wired mode for smooth experience.UPDATE: I connected the 2.4GHz Slipstream receiver to the front panel and I have 0 lags, also can't notice any lags in bluetooth mode anymore.Advice: Don't connect the Slipstream receiver to the back of your PC and you won't get any lags.
product.title: Corsair Harpoon RGB Wireless - Wireless Rechargeable Gaming Mouse with SLIPSTREAM Technology - 10,000 DPI Optical Sensor

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - Corsair Nightsword RGB - Comfort Performance Tunable FPS/MOBA Optical Ergonomic Gaming Mouse with Backlit R...

review.title: I’m never getting a different mouse ever!
review.review: The Corsair Nightsword RGB is in my opinion the best mouse ever. The material and feel of the mouse is comfortable and from my experience, reduces sweat. The customizable weight makes it the experience of the mouse even better, if you download the corsair icue app on your pc, you can customize the DPI, buttons, and colors on the mouse. Over all I love this mouse and recommend it to anyone who wants a quality mouse for all around use.

review.title: Solid style for the price
review.review: Visuals: Comes in white and looks good next to my case.Ergonomics: The size is about what I’m comfortable with, and the button layout respects that I have only one thumb and doesn’t split the side buttons between both sides. I haven’t looked at whether a left-handed model exists, but the right-handed model is what works for me.Reliability: I’ve owned two of the same model. The first picked up some dirt in the left-button contacts after about six months of service, and in trying to clean the contacts I broke some delicate connectors inside. It would probably have been possible to protect the switches better or to make the internals more user-serviceable.

While the mouse still works, I need to reboot my PC just to reconfigure when this happens. Not the best in show for mouse configuration GUIs.Buttons work well. I find the back row of the side 3x4 grid a bit hard to use, but outside of that it's fantastic.Personally, I am not looking for another mouse anytime soon. This guy meets and exceeds my expectations.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2021
review.title: Corsair please use some better switches
review.review: As others have mentioned my previous Corsair Scimitar had issues with the left mouse button giving phantom double clicks after about a year of use. I figured I was just unlucky and grabbed another because I really like the design of the mouse and how it feels in my hand. However, I am already having issues with this mouse giving the double click issue as well, this time with the right mouse button. I've had this one for even less time than the previous. For something that costs 80 dollars this really isn't acceptable and I will be switching to a different brand for my next one.Also, iCue is the worst software package I have ever used, and is basically required to get any sort of functionality out of the mmo buttons on the side.The Logitech mmo mouse (G600) while not looking nearly as attractive lasted me for about 5 years before I finally gave it to a friend after picking up my first Scimitar. He's still using that mouse. It also comes in at half the price and has a "better" software setup. Not that Logi's is amazing either, but it's far better than iCue. Personally, I will probably pick up another of these because I'd rather have something that lasts than something that looks nice and fails in such a short time period.https://www.amazon.com/Logitech-Gaming-Backlit-Programmable-Buttons/dp/B0086UK7IQ/

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2021
review.title: Pretty painful for beginners
review.review: Edit: still dealing with customer service via snail mail basically, one response a day and I’m pretty sure it’s different people because I get asked the same questions. Going to likely and painfully return this horrible product especially after hearing this happen to others.Edit: this product is the most frustrating experience, nothing lights up properly and customer service told me I had to play email tag because their “tech support” doesn’t cover troubleshooting this and the people that do only answer by email. Sometimes 2 fans light up, other times just one but never all 3 and nothing else in the kit has ever lit up as intended. Stay away.This product comes in great packaging and you really feel like you got value for money especially when you tally up the individual items.It’s also not the cheapest, but I wanted to get something higher quality being my first time and all, but this wasn’t quite the case.To begin I learned the pipes were called something that’s just a fancy word for acrylic, and I learned very fast that it’s not very forgiving and easy to mess up. Couple that with the types of adapters you get which pretty much commit you to hardline tubing and you are stuck either with attempting to use them (and in my case immediately messing up a tube despite watching videos prior,) or investing a lot more money to get better tubes or different adapters, but it doesn’t end there…It comes with a squeeze container for filling the pump which broke off inside just from using, that was 2 hours of draining and playing rubik’s cube trying to get out, not fun. But it doesn’t end there either…The pump is awkward as heck, if you have it all plugged in the thing doesn’t operate at full power when filling and you are stuck trying to figure out why the tubes aren’t filling, why does it gotta be like that?The directions aren’t the best, and this process was very painful, I got coolant all over my motherboard and cards despite my best intent to cover everything which yes, is part to user error but I also feel the acrylic isn’t the best use and I wish there were more options from Corsair like being able to buy a kit with soft tubing. Knowing what I do now I may have opted for a cheaper kit and gotten soft line tubing to save the headache and for more flexibility.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2021
review.title: Great product!
review.review: This build turned out way better than I expected! I did purchase some extra 90 degree fittings just in case I needed them and with my case being an itx I definitely needed them.i changed the rad to a 240 since the 360 was not able to fit in my case. As far as temps, I have a ryzen 5 3600 with an aorus 3090 wb card. Temps for my gpu never got over 70 and my cpu was the same. I do think the fans included with this are ment for a bigger case. My overall build went smooth and I had more than enough tubing(had 3 sticks left so only used half of what was included). Definitely a good buy if your a beginner like me!Update: I was getting high temps on my cpu. And by high it was 83c after playing 1 game of warzone. I re-seated and reapplied thermal paste to the cpu plate and still no change. After trying for a second time to re-seat it I decided to remover the washer on the mounting screws that the instruction say to put on. (I included a pic of the instructions.) After removing those washer I immediately saw a changed. Played a few games and my cpu temp stayed in the high 60s.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2021
review.title: Trash
review.review: I can't believe I have to write something bad about a new mouse. I've had a sharkoon mouse since 2014 and now it hurts my fingers to click. So I bought this crosair mouse. I didn't buy it because I'm left handed. I got it because of the two right side buttons. I'm not sure why gaming mouses don't have right side buttons. So basically I got this mouse for the buttons.I play 3 different action MMORPGs with action combat, using mouse clicks for skills.The left side buttons are so faulty and trash. There's friction between my finger and the mouse skills popping off when I click.This mouse was not designed for gaming... The left side buttons are too far forward and flimsy. It does not feel like I'm pressing a button, more like reaching for something unsecured and difficult to push.The clickers need to pressed rather than lightly touched. I find this to be harder to deal with ... Think about slamming your hand flat on a table, this is what it feels like to press the clickers.Something more annoying than the buttons is the failure to load. Sharkoon always loads, crosair does not.I have had to restart computer, unplug and replug, even loaded the ique software. Why? Because the mouse DOES NOT COME ON.. A few times it shut off completely. Unable to scroll and lost cursor...Do you know how ANNOYING this is?I like to have a mouse with right side buttons... But honestly my old sharkoon is waaay better!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2021
review.title: Poorly Designed Scroll Wheel
review.review: Whoever designed the scroll wheel/axle on this mouse should consider contacting the university they attended to see if they can get a refund on their degree. There's nothing supporting the scroll wheel except a tiny plastic axle that's prone to bending. Once that axle is bent, the wheel rotation becomes lopsided and the wheel grinds up against the mouse body, making the scrolling inconsistent and anything but smooth. So far, I've been able to temporarily deal with this by bending the wheel back into place with a thin piece of metal, but it's become quite annoying to deal with. The whole reason I spent the extra money to get a Corsair mouse is that I thought they would be high-quality and long-lasting, like Corsair keyboards are. Suffice it to say, this mouse did not meet my expectations.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2021
review.title: A nearly perfect mouse SO FAR.
review.review: Mice are something that seem to last about a year. Going into a review, you should not really expect much more than that these days if you are a hardcore user. Bearing that in mind, there are still some huge quality differences between something like this and Corsair's Harpoon.I had a Harpoon, the cheaper version of this mouse, for about a year. It did an okay job. It has less options through iCUE, and in general it's just a lesser mouse in every way. The second Harpoon I had came broken in both wheel and Omron switches, so I decided to go back to a Sabre, which I previously abandoned due to it not lasting more than 1.5 years before.Well, I guess I am here to stay, because despite Corsair manufacturing mice to basically die in a year or two, this is so much better than a Harpoon. It has dual DPI axis settings, tons of lighting settings that the other doesn't have including more options for when you are not using iCUE, and of course it can poll up into the 8000Hz range along with much improved ergonomics.Previously, you had to manually kill the iCUE process, instead of exiting normally, to retain lighting, such as no lighting, if you didn't want the iCUE process running at all. You could not exit out of it normally, or your lighting would go right back to brightly lit rainbow default. This is fixed with their "hardware lighting" option, except for the three DPI markers, which you still need to kill the process to get back to your normal settings.They really need to include the DPI settings in the hardware lighting option, because some of us do not want Corsair processes running at all, and we want a no lit mouse but with the option at least of having it lit when needed. Of course you can bypass all of this and just get the unlit version I think. But they still need to make a way for the DPI lights to shut off without iCUE on, and without having to use the workaround, which does work fine anyway.From a comfort standpoint, it's also a cut above. In fact, this is probably the most comfortable mouse I have ever used. Everything seems almost perfectly suited to my hands and movements. The mouse itself is quite light but not so that you would get annoyed. It glides extremely well, and there is a calibration setting for glide sensitivity built into iCUE for their better mice. It works, and this is the first time I feel not annoyed by iCUE in ages. It has come a long way, and this mouse makes full use of it.So in reality they have made steps forward in nearly every category here. iCUE is no longer garbage, the mouse functions extremely well, and it is a massive cut above their cheaper options.That about sums it up honestly. Much improved in just about every way. The click area is the same hard plastic with coating that will probably wear away after a year or two of solid use. So keep that in mind as well. These don't last forever. Happy gaming.
product.title: CORSAIR Sabre RGB PRO Champion Series FPS/MOBA Gaming Mouse - Ergonomic Shape for Esports and Competitive Play - Ultra-Lig...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: 2 modes are great in this mouse.
review.review: The pros - this mouse has a pretty good battery life, it can be plugged in or wireless and the wireless charging is a nice feature. Corsairs software is top notch and you can adjust the settings on the fly and even set up profiles for what apps you have running. Indicator lights work well and it has enough buttons to do normal FPS gaming and surfing options.The con, and this is unfortunately a fairly large one, I get a hair of lag when its wireless, meaning wireless mode is not ideal for FPS gaming, or really any gaming. So I frequently operate it wirelessly when I'm just surfing the net and stuff but if I'm going to play I plug it in.This might be my setup creating an issue, my tower does sit 4 feet from the mouse, the drawers for the desk are between the mouse and its receiver so these are all things that could be the cause and that I'll try and tweak down the road but it is something I am experiencing so figured fair warning to anyone else who may have a similar set up.

review.title: Best pump I have used.
review.review: I have been using d5 pumps now for 15 years. I have been using the same d5 forever, they don't seem to break. I bought a Koolance housing for it that is well made. This new rig I just made. even though they call it a full tower its not. I couldn't get my old pump to fit and look half way decent. So I decided to purchase a new one, this unit comes with so many mounting options I don't see myself using the d5 again. I currently have it mounted to my 240 rad and it works great. The only thing I don't like about it is if you want to control it via software you have to buy another corsair unit to hook it up to the pc. I was hoping since my motherboard had a corsair light and or fan hookup directly on my motherboard I wasn't going to need it, but that's not the case. I am just running it with out the software and it works just fine.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: 2021 Review – CORSAIR is simply Beautiful
review.review: First, I never show my enthusiast build – because it’s like restoring an old muscle car = a masterpiece and constant work in progress. The expense and headache never end (7 years now). The exception to the rule = Corsair’s XD7 water loop system. I must come out of the shadows with this thing.If you are on a budget = stop reading right now… go to the Financial Aid office and ask for money to support your bad computer habit (cuz you are in trouble dude).Even if this ‘work of art’ fails tomorrow, I will enjoy this moment. I give THANOS credit to the engineering and designers of this pump. It makes perfect sense and saves a lot of space in an EATX case (or perhaps smaller).Along with this unit – the picture shows the Corsair XC7 RGB (CPU cold plate) and the Corsair XG7 RGB (GPU water block / cold plate). And I never thought I would be staring at my own …. for three days without blinking my eyes. (see photo)Tech Specs:> The XG7 (Rev B) is a perfect fit for my EVGA 2080 XC – which is a reference card (meaning NVIDIA gives the reference and EVGA slaps two fans and a shroud over the …..) If your card is bigger than a reference size (10.5 inches long) – then you will likely shed tears finding the correct block (sorry). The problem for many is thickness (like capacitors and extra cooling junk).> The XC7 is a perfect fit for my Intel socket LGA 1200 processor (or any other); Corsair gives you the back plate and spring-loaded screws which can be mounted to where they don’t flop around on install.Advice:Remember: this is just a water pump with pretty lights and outrageous plumbing. The rest is up to you and extensive research. I had to watch several YOUTUBE videos that didn’t teach me nothing about setting up a custom loop (good for reference only or nothing at all). Takes a bit of time…But I know one rule = buy two of everything you can’t find at WALMART or BESTBUY. I needed (12) compression fittings (which come 4 to a box). I needed (2) 90-degree fittings. I did the calculations before I started. Surprisingly, the Corsair hose and coolant (1000 ml) was enough to do the entire build (can’t waste nothing testing).Hope this helps…

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2021
review.title: Didn't expect would be that good
review.review: This is the kind of product you are not sure you really need until you get it and wonder how you could manage to live without it. With all the not so good reviews, especially about the screen, I hesitated for a long time before to buy it but when I got some money as a gift from a aunt I decided to try it.First of all, the device looks very good quality and it sticks very well to my K95. The buttons and widgets are easy to setup with iCUE and you can configure them as you like (color, size, background image, etc.). You can only set 6 buttons per screen but you can set as many screens as you want and it's easy to switch between them by swiping with your finger. I switched from a two monitors setup to a single 32" one a year ago and I was missing very much to be able to monitor my temperatures while gaming without having to run some overlay programs. Turns out that thing does it wonderfully well.Unlike some other people said I didn't notice any increase of CPU usage after I connected it (but maybe it's because my Ryzen 5900x just doesn't feel it).About the screen, it's true that if you look at it from an angle you don't see anything anymore but... this thing is not supposed to be looked at from a 45 degree angle. It is supposed to be watched when you are in front of your keyboard and when you do that it's amazingly clear and bright. My only negative point is that the touch functionality when you press a button is not always super reactive but I realize that it works fine if you aim more toward the bottom of the screen instead of the top. In that way it works just fine.Overall, it's an expansive device but for me it worth it. Really awesome gadget to have in your setup.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2021
review.title: A nearly perfect mouse SO FAR.
review.review: Mice are something that seem to last about a year. Going into a review, you should not really expect much more than that these days if you are a hardcore user. Bearing that in mind, there are still some huge quality differences between something like this and Corsair's Harpoon.I had a Harpoon, the cheaper version of this mouse, for about a year. It did an okay job. It has less options through iCUE, and in general it's just a lesser mouse in every way. The second Harpoon I had came broken in both wheel and Omron switches, so I decided to go back to a Sabre, which I previously abandoned due to it not lasting more than 1.5 years before.Well, I guess I am here to stay, because despite Corsair manufacturing mice to basically die in a year or two, this is so much better than a Harpoon. It has dual DPI axis settings, tons of lighting settings that the other doesn't have including more options for when you are not using iCUE, and of course it can poll up into the 8000Hz range along with much improved ergonomics.Previously, you had to manually kill the iCUE process, instead of exiting normally, to retain lighting, such as no lighting, if you didn't want the iCUE process running at all. You could not exit out of it normally, or your lighting would go right back to brightly lit rainbow default. This is fixed with their "hardware lighting" option, except for the three DPI markers, which you still need to kill the process to get back to your normal settings.They really need to include the DPI settings in the hardware lighting option, because some of us do not want Corsair processes running at all, and we want a no lit mouse but with the option at least of having it lit when needed. Of course you can bypass all of this and just get the unlit version I think. But they still need to make a way for the DPI lights to shut off without iCUE on, and without having to use the workaround, which does work fine anyway.From a comfort standpoint, it's also a cut above. In fact, this is probably the most comfortable mouse I have ever used. Everything seems almost perfectly suited to my hands and movements. The mouse itself is quite light but not so that you would get annoyed. It glides extremely well, and there is a calibration setting for glide sensitivity built into iCUE for their better mice. It works, and this is the first time I feel not annoyed by iCUE in ages. It has come a long way, and this mouse makes full use of it.So in reality they have made steps forward in nearly every category here. iCUE is no longer garbage, the mouse functions extremely well, and it is a massive cut above their cheaper options.That about sums it up honestly. Much improved in just about every way. The click area is the same hard plastic with coating that will probably wear away after a year or two of solid use. So keep that in mind as well. These don't last forever. Happy gaming.
product.title: CORSAIR Sabre RGB PRO Champion Series FPS/MOBA Gaming Mouse - Ergonomic Shape for Esports and Competitive Play - Ultra-Lig...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2016
review.title: Great Mouse if Trouble Free!Good Customer Service.
review.review: I purchased this mouse in March of 2015.Functionally it works great, and your color scheme for this mouse will sync up with your Corsair branded RGB keyboard, if you have one.For instance, I have my keyboard displaying a rainbow like rotation.With a few clicks using Corsair's software, my mouse also does this as well, creating a perfectly matched pair of RGB peripherals!It's really a nice touch.However, a few weeks ago, my middle mouse button stopped functioning.Since I macro functions that I constantly use to this button, this was a major issue.Hopping on forums, I found that other people with this mouse have also had this issue.I contacted Corsair's support page on their website, which channeled me to an RMA form.I filled it out, and, thankfully, Corsair agreed to send me a new mouse.I did have to cover the shipping cost which was a bummer.On the one hand, it's cool that Corsair sent me a brand new replacement after 10 months of use.On the other, you would expect a mouse in this price range to last more than 10 months free of defect, which causes me to have some concerns about quality.If it weren't for that, it would definitely be 5 stars instead of 4.Only time will tell how long the replacement will last.Overall, I understand that defective units do sometimes appear, so my experience is not enough to prevent a recommendation of this mouse.It's a great mouse with really cool features.As long as the quality is there, it would be a total homerun.
product.title: Corsair Gaming Sabre RGB 8200 DPI Laser Gaming Mouse (CH-9000090-NA)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2016
review.title: As a whole i like the idea behind the Link functionality between my keyboard
review.review: It's coming up on a year now for how long i've had this mouse.As a whole i like the idea behind the Link functionality between my keyboard, headset, mouse and soon mousepad but I think i wouldve been better off with another mouse line. The biggest complaint is the middle mouse button stopped working after 2 months! I find that very annoying for games that have that bound to it. I've worked around that by rebinding middle mouse to one of the two side buttons which work very well for any push-to-talk programs you would have. Switching DPI on the fly is pretty useful as well, having a 4k TV as a monitor being able to tap it and see what setting you're at based on color is a nice feature.You WILL NOT like this mouse if you have certain grip styles. I use a claw grip and throughout my life never noticed people had different ways they hold the mouse. if you palm your mouse do not pick this up.The design has a very large flange base that sticks out, that gets some taking use to. and its coating in a rubber like substance that is very easy to clean.Overall I would love to have given it 5 stars, but having the middle mouse button broken after only 2 months was pretty disappointing.

review.review: This mouse was perfect for me to use for both FPS and RTS games like CS:GO, League of Legends and Starcraft 2. You can easily control your mouse sensitivity with buttons and the mouse is really easy to program with macros (I recommend you to use Green - Sensitivity Level when you are playing games. Red Level is somehow dull for me). Also, this mouse has a really fancy RGB lights all around it so it can easily satisfy with the overall design when you use it with other gaming gears with RGB lighting. And this mouse has a really fast reaction speed so you don't have to worry about the malfunction during your game. Moreover, this mouse is huge so it will completely fill your hand, which will make your hand to be much more comfortable.One thing to be aware of is that Mac users cannot program this mouse or change the RGB color.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2018
review.title: Just the right amount of buttons
review.review: As I was mapping the 8 buttons to my liking, I thought I may run out of actions I wanted to map.When I was done, I realized it was just the right amount.I now use my left hand less clicking on key combos.The mouse slides smoothly across my $10 mouse pad keyboard rest combo.I only wished it had side scrolling.I run 2 widescreen monitors side by side, but they are only 1920 and minutes into my work day, I already have 4 windows snapped across and excel only goes out to column K.The mouse is used for work and not gaming so I have not tested the "sniper" button with my integrated intel graphics.As with other reviews, I do have some issue with the software.Lighting is easy enough to set up, but the button mapping was odd.It is 2018 and Corsair still requires each button mapping to be its own rule.It took a minute before I realized I was mapping the 8th key map to button 2 because it was the same rule.If key bindings for games were like this, I would ditch my pc and just game on consoles (not really, but it would be frustrating).Good job Corsair on refurbishing this mouse, though.Corsair made my mouse like new again.Not even a greasy smudge on hard, rubberized surface.I am pleased.
product.title: Corsair Gaming Sabre RGB 8200 DPI Laser Gaming Mouse CH-9000090-NA (Renewed)

Tried reaching out to support but it won't even send an email to reset the account and it's not in spam either. I'm used to more from Corsair this is disappointing I'm just gonna try to revive my old logitech mouse, it was so good and their software is actually good too.
product.title: Corsair Gaming Sabre RGB 8200 DPI Laser Gaming Mouse CH-9000090-NA (Renewed)
Sponsored Ad - Corsair Nightsword RGB - Comfort Performance Tunable FPS/MOBA Optical Ergonomic Gaming Mouse with Backlit R...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2021
review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

It's an easy fix to just go out and buy new skatez, but, for a new product, I should have to just yet.Other things I am not a fan of is this mouse is good for smaller hands, I feel. Also, the definition between the buttons are not very defined, and I feel you can easily click the wrong button. If the mouse was a little wider, I think it would be a bit more comfortable.

review.title: Mouse is lagging all the time
review.review: I ordered this mouse because I wanted to switch to wireless mouse experience. I really like this mouse, nice and comfortable design and it fits perfectely in my hand with my claw grip.The only thing that keeps me back to give it 5 stars is the wireless modes. when I switch to 2.4GHz Slipstream wireless mode I get so much lags every 5 seconds which is awful for gaming, you just can't play games like this. When I switch to Bluetooth mode the amount of lags decrease but not completely and you can't controll the RGB lightning when using Bluetooth mode.I have to use the wired mode for smooth experience.UPDATE: I connected the 2.4GHz Slipstream receiver to the front panel and I have 0 lags, also can't notice any lags in bluetooth mode anymore.Advice: Don't connect the Slipstream receiver to the back of your PC and you won't get any lags.
