review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: Almost
review.review: I really had high hopes for this laptop but I found a couple of issues that caused me to return it. First, there was a little bit of backlight bleed on the bottom left side of the screen. While the screen was nice and there was the normal amount of IPS glow, the little white light bleeding through on the bottom left caused me some concern. Although it was not much, it was enough for me to wonder if it would get worse over time. Knowing that there have been some who have complained about screen issues, I did not want to take the chance.Second, the laptop had a few keys that had tactile issues. The #3, #4, and W were not as responsive and springy as the other keys. When I barely moved my fingers across the number row without applying pressure, I could feel that the #3 and #4 keys seemed to be off a little. It worked when typing but I could tell the difference between them and the other keys. The W key was not as bad but you could still feel the difference between it and the Q, E, A, and S. While they may have never caused any issues throughout the life of the laptop, I don't want to take that risk with a $1000+ laptop. I have seen videos and forum posts about this same model where keys are sticking and/or not responding. I did not want to send it to Lenovo for warranty service since I just bought it. Personally, I don't trust a device that has to receive warranty repairs right out of the box. Hopefully, Lenovo can address these issues because this seems like it could be a very great machine.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Good price for Ryzen 5000 series... However
review.review: Ordered this machine as it's the best value for a Ryzen 5000 series CPU which comes with an earlier generation graphics card. (GTX1650). The engineers over at Lenovo took some serious shortcuts with this machine, possibly to encourage consumers to move up to their Legion line. This machine is advertised to allow storage expansion via an open second M. 2 slot, at the expense of the open 2.5" HDD/SSD bay. You have to choose between them because the second M. 2 slot literally blocks the installation of a 2.5" drive. There is no work around for this whatsoever. So I decided to do without the 2.5" bay and I stall a second NVMe, only to see the manufacturer did not install (not include) a standoff for the second SSD. The female threads are there, but no standoff. I immediately called Lenovo and they gave me the part number for the screw pack (which includes the oddly sized standoff) However that part is on back-order and a ship date is unknown. Thankfully some folks on here appear to have received the SSD standoff installed (some machines arrive with it installed in the 2242 position requiring it to be moved to allow 2280) Bit mine arrived with none.So with a brand new 1TB M.2 2280 SSD in hand and no way to install it due to the manufacturer's oversight I initiated a RMA.Coming from last year's Acer Nitro 5, this machine is a definite downgrade. The Acer included all required hardware and their support experience is far above Lenovo. I'm surprised by this as Lenovo is well known for high quality products. But this seems to be true only for their upper end SKU's.I decided to she'll out an extra $200 to go back to the Acer Nitro Series with slightly upgraded specs. IMHO this is well worth the extra cost to avoid future issues with the Lenovo Gaming 3, which is a far lower end machine overall.The cooling on the Lenovo Gaming 3 is another strange engineering fault. It's unclear why they would place the main exhaust literally at the hinge of the laptop's display. In closed position (where many people will have it to use external monitor setup) it blocks roughly 50% of the rear exhaust port by having the lid closed. With the lid open, the extremely hot air is rushed directly towards the bottom half of the display. There is also a second exhaust port which isn't fully utilized by the machine. On Lenovo's high end Legion machines the thermal solution makes sense as the display is moved forward to accommodate. Even with the highly efficient AMD 5600h, this machine gets hot fast. This is another huge oversight by Lenovo on this SKU.But if you don't plan on doing any upgrades or just plan on adding a bit of memory and using the machine as is, this is the cheapest priced Ryzen 5000 with a discrete GPU. If you want full upgradability and a more reliable feature set, it's worth paying $200 more to get the Acer Nitro 5 with a current gen 3060 GPU which allows 3 storage options at once and reliable cooling with it's quad exhaust setup. Lenovo is still a good brand but it's worth paying a bit more now for the Legion model or a Acer Nitro, etc. than settling for this budget offering.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: Fantastic Value Buy!
review.review: I did alot of research prior to my purchase and this deal hands down was the absolute best for my use case. I needed a new laptop for work and with the next gen console nightmare I thought Id get one that can do a bit of intermediate level gaming as well.Firstly the look of most laptops in this price range were a no go for me. The hp pavilion and acer nitro look too "gamery" as I carry this to work with me most days. This laptop unlike those looks standard and Lenovo is a brand I've had many positive experiences with before.The speed is lightning quick and I've added an additional 8 gb of ram and a 1tb m.2 ssd which has improved performance even more and covered my one gripe which was the lack of storage. The upgrade itself was pretty easy to do myself.As for the gamimg experience, with only a gtx 1650 you do have to tone down your settings in most titles to come close to capping out your 120hz screen but I'm fine with that. I've attached two pictures of apex legends in the firing range after running around, shooting and using abilities for 5 mins each doing my best to simulate what your in-game experience would be. One picture shows the results at all min settings and the other at all max settings. At all max the fps dips to between 30 to 40 with alot of stuff happening on the screen (bangalore smokes and simultaneous ultimates for example). This isnt really playable in a game where frames matter. At all min you sit at 110 to 130 most of the time with a dip to maybe 70-80 under the conditions I detailed above. The textures are pretty bad however. I've settled on a low-med mix that nets me around 80-90 most of the time. Compared to my ps4 (RIP my next gen ownership ambition btw) this feels amazing. If you want to experience games at their full graphical intensity and dont want to be forced to skimp on visuals look elsewhere but be prepared to pay at least 100% more for a 3060 laptop or at least 30-50% more on a 3050ti laptop.If this is your budget then I DEFINITELY recommend this laptop.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2021
review.title: Wow, love, love, love this.
review.review: So I’m a 34 year old dad who loves gaming but doesn’t have the time or money to invest heavily in a full on gaming system, also I wanted a good entry level laptop with a nice keyboard. I stumble on this read everyone’s reviews and say ok let’s do it. Right off the bat i love it, windows is smooth, everything great. The next day I buy 2 x 16 crucial ram and upgrade from 8 go to 32 this took 5 mins: I download hades the game open it and….wow, beautiful and fast, no glitching nice frame rate, the white backlit keyboard glowing nicely in my room. It’s perfect for a casual gamer like me, the keyboard is comfy and amazing, next I’ll be adding a m.2 ssd since they left a connection and open space. This is the value of values. For more top end games I’m not sure but for me it’s perfect.! Great product Lenovo!Edit: so it has fully exceeded expectations, I added a 1 tb Samsung 980 pro ssd in the m2 slot. And its a perfect fit for me, 32 gb ram and 1.256 tb storage. I’ve started a campaign in divinity 2 original sin in high settings and it runs great, and our worlds in high setting and it runs great! I’m very impressed with Lenovo, for the price point I feel like this was the best bang for the buck, just 300 in upgrades and I have a AAA gaming laptop. This is a buy for those who want really nice casual gaming, if your not a pro who streams, but just want to jump on and play a bit.

review.title: Great laptop, just three items could have made it 5 star.
review.review: This is a great little laptop with lots of power for the price.Gen 11 i7, an RTX 3060, Thunderport 4, and a very bright 144 Hz display.But there are plenty of reviews that will list out all the wonderful specs.Here are my only complaints.I do have some light bleed around the top and bottom edges of the screen which is disappointing.It is hard to find the battery specs on this laptop but I think it is something like 59 MAH.You you pack this much horse power in a chasey I wish it contained a max 99 MAH battery.There is an extra 2.5" drive bay next to the battery, it would be awesome to offer a bigger battery option at the sacrifice of the drive bay.Lastly, a MUX switch would have been great.I understand this would add to the cost but I would pay extra for those options and a MUX switch it relatively cheap to build into a laptop.Other than that, I researched close to 30 laptops before settling on this one and it did not disappoint.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: 4.5 Stars, great laptop, great features, very satisfied
review.review: Received this laptop as a birthday gift from my wife.Wanted to get something that would allow me to play the latest games without lag and replace my old laptop that had a failing keyboard.I use my computers for hours on end and have put this through it's paces.For the price (especially considering the cost of things going up) this has been great.Also received 2 game downloads and a laptop sleeve, which are a nice bonus.It's almost unheard of in this economic climate for additional things to be added to a purchase.I'm 99% satisfied with the speed, features, fans, look of the computer.My biggest issues which knock it down to 4.5 stars are the smaller hard drive; really anything less than 1tb is brutal given how big media is now.Yes I realize the cloud is a thing, but frankly I hate it and don't trust using it.It does the space to slot in more storage and I broke down and did (easy process, took 5 min)The other issue is the volume.Yeah laptops aren't known for their sound, most of the laptops I've purchased I always paid for an upgraded sound card or when building my own would upgrade the sound card.It's not an issue when listening to everything, but occasionally a video or game will be noticeably quieter than I would like at max volume.All in all though, especially for this price, the laptop is a great.I expect to get a few years out of it and have no issue thus far.To close this is probably the nicest laptop I've ever had.The keyboard lights, the light on the back of the laptop, nice sleek lines.Hopefully my kids don't start popping the keys off of this laptop like my kids did to my old Alienware.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2021
review.title: Decent budget gaming rig
review.review: I have been using this laptop for about 5 months and have been pretty pleased thus far. It has met my expectations for performance.Pros:-Speed is excellent-Nice feature set (SD reader!)Cons:-Can get warm during heavier use/charging-Screen brightness is 'meh'I was a little weary of ordering a laptop through Amazon but the price for the config I wanted was hard to argue (could not find a lower price for 16GB/1 TB option anywhere - even if I did it myself). Laptop showed up quickly and has worked great. There is some bloatware, so take some time initially to scrub it. I chose the HP laptop based on reviews and that it was one of the few that actually had a SD card reader. While it seems minor, it is one last peripheral to carry. I use it with Cura frequently and it boots very fast and slices quickly. Light gaming has been speedy and more than sufficient. Battery life is average - not horrible but not great.It can get warmer when charging or gaming. I bought a melamine cutting board to keep my laptop off my lap and have found it to be a low cost option to keep the fan ports unobstructed (not needed for light activities but let's me place it on soft surfaces, etc. without any worries).The screen is probably my only real complaint. It works fine - colors are acceptable and response is fine. It is just not that bright. This is the only reason I have not given this 5 stars. I knew this going in - so it is not completely fair to knock it down a star but want people to go in aware.
product.title: 2021 New HP Pavilion 15.6" FHD Gaming Laptop, AMD 6-Core Ryzen 5 4600H Up to 4.0 GHz (Beats i5-9300H), 16GB RAM, 256GB SSD...

review.title: Disappointed.
review.review: I could not get this to start up. I got the checker screen within a minute of turning this computer on.It took me hours to get through the set up. It crashed over and over. I updated through safe mode, bot fixed.I ran hp bios to check components, no problems found. HP had me check that ram was properly installed, still no fix. It would lock up in install screens, it made it to windows a couple of boots, but crashed within minutes. Ended up sending it back. Not sure if it was shipping damage or a badly installed component. I was pretty unhappy with the whole experience. Ended up buying something from a local store. No problems.

review.title: Good for the price
review.review: I'll start off by saying that the battery life on this laptop sucks. It doesn't last very long unplugged (about an hour while just using it and around 30-40 minutes while gaming). This isn't really a problem for me since I always have it plugged in but I thought people would want to know. It works great for the few games I've played on it (Arma 3, Dying Light, Jump force, and Storm 4) and judging on the specs it will do fine in basically all popular multiplayer and most single player games out right now. I would recommend a ssd upgrade and a ram upgrade though (it has 2 ram slots so you can add another stick and it also has a slot for a 2.5 inch ssd and I believe another m.2)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2021
review.title: Outstanding latptop with one negative
review.review: This is my second MSI laptop and the quality is top notch; performance, screen clarity and color brilliance, all are exceptional.The only negative is the "Killer" network controller app; it is hands down the absolute worst piece of garbage software I've seen since I got my first computer in 1984.No matter what I did, it constantly throttled down my internet access to about 10% (often much less) of the potential bandwidth available.If you buy this (or another computer) with this app on it, disable or uninstall it and you'll be much happier.
product.title: MSI GS66 Stealth 15.6" 240Hz 3ms Ultra Thin and Light Gaming Laptop Intel Core i7-10750H RTX2070 Max-Q 16GB 1TB NVMe SSD W...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2021
review.title: Heavy gaming machine
review.review: It is packaged well by MSI, very slick looking laptop.Initially I was a little frustrated by what looked like small debris that got between the screen and casing. I used some screen cleaner along with the microfiber towel that came with the laptop to get the majority out, so that was solved.Now as far performance, I spend initial time updating the graphics driver which was easy and noticed that most drivers were up to date which was good.I used 3DMARK to run a check on the processor and Video card. Got the following for CPUMax threads 371716 threads 36658 threads 32884 threads 23682 threads 14191 thread 727And as far as GPU I got a 6287 time spy scoreWhich is higher then a lot of laptop gaming PCs.So the scores were within what you would expect.What was concerning was how hot the cpu temp got during testing. Went over 90 Celsius a good portion of the test while the GPU went to 75 Celsius.I might have to check and see if it’s the thermal paste they used but not sure if I want to mess around either with it.So it is heavy due to the big battery which you would expect from a gaming pc, the fans do their job but you hear them and it gets hot.Performance wise the screen is amazing and gaming on it is awesome. I used it first day to play the new world beta and it looked and played awesome.Very pleased.Update 8/6/21I am moving the laptop from 4 stars to 5Like I mentioned above the laptop gets hot when you play for a long time and I recommend headphones or ear buds while gaming as having the fan to max (by pressing FN and F8(fan key) can be veeeery loud!But the benchmarks I initially posted are low as compared to what I am getting now as I did not have it to the extreme performance on the MSI Dragon Center clicked before. This laptop is a powerhouse!Update 8/10/21:Didn't mention this in my previous review but the "brick" or power supply is terrible. With a system like this you end up having to use the power supply alot as the battery drains pretty quickly if your not hooked up. Well the issue is with the cord, the cord is too short. You end up sometimes having to either lift the brick off the ground and put it on the couch with your or try to get it real close to the chair, its just too short... So if your someone that gets frustrated by stuff like that you will be irritated with this power supply.
product.title: MSI GS66 Stealth 15.6" 240Hz 3ms Ultra Thin and Light Gaming Laptop Intel Core i7-10750H RTX2070 Max-Q 16GB 1TB NVMe SSD W...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2021
review.title: Nice value and easy to upgrade
review.review: I wanted a decently-equipped, lightweight 14-inch laptop to use on the go without breaking the bank and this hit all the notes.I wound up dual-booting it with Pop OS and setup worked well and the 256 GB drive left me more than enough space for a dual install.The memory is partially soldered to the motherboard while another 4 GB stick is replaceable so I swapped that out with an 8 GB one to bump up the system memory to 12 GBs.I believe it can handle up to 20 GB(16 GB stick + 4 GB), and noticed that memory usage in Windows 10 was more stable with the upgrade.That said, 8 GBs is likely more than enough.You can also replace the SSD with another NVMe, though make sure you get the right form factor - it's a 2242 (the smallest one) in case you're looking.But it's quite easy to replace it if you want.I've not tried to stress-test the CPU but I've been able to run a docker image + multiple Chrome tabs + VS code without the fan even kicking on, and my guess is it could handle light-ish gaming as well.For basic office/web/home usage it'll be more than enough.Again, calibrate your expectations but this isn't a bargain-basement device.Screen is solid - it's FHD but at 14 inches you don't see much pixelation and the IPS limits washout from different angles.Brightness is solid as well, though it's certainly not the brightest you'll see.But again, it's good for the price point.And the backlit keyboard has multiple brightness settings depending on the environment.My one big complain is the USB-C port is for data transfer only - no power in or video out.The device has a full-size HDMI port so it's not a deal-breaker but I really would have liked to not have to carry around a device-specific charger.Not a deal breaker but that feels like an unnecessary corner to cut.Still, a good value thus far and I'm happy with how this Ideapad will scale with my needs.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: It works wonderfully, until it doesnt...
review.review: The laptop is just great. Fells like a hight quality build. Screen has a beautiful display. RGB Chroma makes it look cool. Most importantly it runs most games out there at 1920 x 1080 resolution on ultra high settings with no noticeable FPS drops. Yes it does get hot when running games at those settings but if you play it in an A/C cooled room, connected to a TV via HDMI, it doesnt get as hot. And its How I always used the laptopThat is also why my review is a 2 Star rating. In less than one year the HDMI port on my laptop stopped working. The computer does detect the TV and lets me assign a resolution for it but theres no display on my TV. Its funny that one should pay over $2000 on a computer for it to start breaking apart in less than a year. After trying litterally every troubleshooting step I could find and contacting Razer they decided I should send the computer for repair. And as of now Im waiting for them to reply to me. Havent heard from them since before yesterday.I will update the review as the story develops. But as of now I could not justify their ultra expensive release prices for their products if they are not even going to outlast the manufacturers warranty.Update 1: Razer will sell their products to Puerto Rico customers. Even on their webise they will ship them to Puerto Rico. Even Best Buy storea in the island sell Razer products. But in case of a warranty claim. If the product needs to be sent for repairs/replacement, it has to be sent first to an address in the USA so it can then be sent to Razer.This might also apply to any US territory. So, dear purchaser please consider it seriously before purchasing from Razer. Specially if you live in a US territory like Puerto Rico. These guys are anti-consumer.

Last years graphics is fine for the saving I garnered.I'm a firm believer in I'd still be happy with my last years pc this year.I easily installed a 2 TB m2 hard drive in the extra slot (love it has an empty slot for that) and the 16 GB ram seems to run my photo editing with fine speed and my older games.This does not have thunderbolt to connect a display through the C port but has two type C ports that I use to connect all peripherals and then just use the hdmi to connect one monitor and use the laptop screen as a second so don't purchase a C type universal docking station to connect displays, display put through won't work on this 2020 model, i believe it has been updated by razer to work on the 2021 models.Very very happy with this purchase for my needs.Oh i thought I would miss the number bad, especially when photo editing but i've adapted to that quickly and do not miss it.

If you just use a mouse you won't have to worry about that. It also scrolls backwards up is down and down is up, you can fix that in the touchpad settings.Other than that it's typical windows, takes 20 minutes to download updates and get it set up. Has included programs like antivirus and office trials that mainly just pop up offers wanting you to buy things,you can just uninstall those. Take off the Lenovo apps also, they just want to track you usage (spy on you) and don't really offer anything of value.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Almost a perfect laptop for the price held back by buggy included software.
review.review: Great laptop and it fits my needs perfectly, would have been a perfect device if not for the buggy and frustrating included Software.Pros:-Excellent performance from the 3060 with 105W TDP coupled with the octa-core 11800h.-Great thermals with the GPU never exceeding 80C and the processor rarely going above 80C while playing even the most demanding games.-Stunning OLED display.-Sleek design and sturdy build quality (besides the slightly wobbly hinge).Cons:-Very buggy and frustrating to use included control software. My main gripe was that the fan profiles reset every time you plug in or remove the charge and you have to manually set it to what you want every single time. I ultimately ended up giving up on getting it to work properly and switched over to using a 3rd party software.-Battery life is average at best, I get around 6 - 7 hours of battery life doing moderate web browsing and coding after the latest BIOS update which is enough for me to get by but I would have preferred to get a couple of hours more especially considering that this model has a 99kwh battery.-The screen hinge can be a bit to the wobbly side but it doesn't wobble during normal typing so it doesn't bother me too much.In conclusion, I am very satisfied with this laptop but I wish they would improve their software.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review.title: Underwhelming
review.review: Purchasing this laptops is another testament to the fact that good specs don't always amount to a great product. I was deciding between the Gigabyte 17" and a MacBook Pro 16" and finally picked the AERO because of it's impressive screen and graphics card. Needles to say I'm experiencing buyers remorse.The Bad:Horrible webcam/nosecam: I don't know why Gigabyte decided to even include this monstrosity. It's completely useless as it gives everyone in your Zoom meeting a detailed look up your nostrils. The cam is mounted in the body so it's not adjustable unless you raise the entire laptop. In the world of remote work a good, usable webcam is a MUST. Dishing out 2500 bucks and realizing that you still need to by an additional webcam to mount on your screen is a joke. GIGABYTE PLEASE FIX.Charging port: It’s located on the right, middle of the laptop which interferes with your mouse, if you have a tight space and are right-handed. Most coffee shops I go to have tiny tables and given the size of this 17.3” laptop there’s very little room.Battery life: I’m a graphic designer that works in 3D occasionally. When I use Photoshop/Illustrator and Dimension I can’t get more than 1 hour of battery life out of this thing even in power saver mode.Screen changes brightness: Yes, it will go darker or lighter without you touching any settings. Not the end of the world, but annoying.Screen goes black: I’ve used this laptop for a month and so far I’ve had at least 5 instances where the screen goes completely black for a second or two. Gigabyte WTF?Annoying keyboard: I’m used to Macs where to change volume you hit F11 or F12. In this thing you have to hold down the Function key in order to adjust volume, so it becomes a two handed operation. I find this really annoying as volume setting is something that is the most adjusted function and needs to be as intuitive as possible.RGB keyboard: This is a Creator’s laptop not a “gamer” laptop. Having the keyboard pulse like a rainbow on acid is not only distracting but also extremely tasteless. If you want to compete with Macbooks please get rid of this gimmick that appeals to 12 year olds.Now the Good:This thing is fast.The screen is beautiful.The GPU kicks ass. It’s 10 times (10!) faster at rendering 3D than my 13” Macbook pro.It’s relatively slim and not too cheesy looking (minus the RGB keyboard) which fortunately you can turn off.About $2500 cheaper than a similarly spec’d out Mac. Mac’s however have better ergonomics.Ports. Useful, but because of its shortcomings I have to use up one USB port for an external cam and another for a mouse. So it’s a mixed bag.Summary:This laptop is good if you keep it plugged in all the time and use it like a desktop. Hauling it around and working on the go is not a real option as you only have about an hour. Gigabyte needs to put more into their product usability testing.
product.title: GIGABYTE AERO 17 HDR XD - 17.3" UHD 4k IPS Anti-Glare, Intel Core i7, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070 Laptop GPU 8GB GDDR6, 16GB R...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2021
review.title: Self-changing laptop
review.review: I wanted to like this laptop.But, alas, I can't -- the reason?With all the bloatware, trying to set this to operate consistently has been impossible.No matter what I set or how I set it (for example, the type size because I'm visually impaired) the very next time I boot it, it changes to something else.Admittedly, some of that is the insanity of Window 10 but it is surely not limited to that.Every day, I have to spend a half-hour or more tweaking settings back to where I want them.It gets old.Very old.Very quickly.Support for dealing with this problem is nonexistent, I get canned responses from Gigabyte that clearly indicate they aren't even trying to understand much answer the problem.At this price point, that's just not good enough.My other laptop is an MSI -- while they deserve more credit than Gigabyte -- they are hardly stellar either which is why, after buying the MSI, I thought I'd try Gigabyte.Big mistake, should have stuck with the devil I know......Understand that I'm not some gibbering technoignoramus -- with over 45 years of computing experience, I know my way around things PC -- yet this problem simply baffles me.I've never, in my life, had any form of pc that resets itself to whatever settings it wants.I can promise that I will never buy anything Gigabyte ever again.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2021
review.title: Beast Laptop
review.review: I've had this for a couple days now. Only upgrade I did was adding a 2nd NVME (2TB). This laptop cold boots in 7-10 seconds. It can easily do heavy load multitasking (even with the 16GB Ram). I'm not a real gamer, so I cant comment on that. However for Photoshop, Autocad and 4k movie editing this laptop has way more then enough power to handle.The fact that this has 4k HDR display is crazy to me. This display is literally breathtaking. The HDR is "Entry level HDR" so it's not like my TV but to have this on my laptop pictures/videos looks amazing!(1 month update)This laptop after a month is perfect!, I only ran into one issue after installing GEFORCE EXPERIENCE... it causes random BSOD. Unistalling it fixed everything.I did one additional upgrade to 64gb RAM. The 16gb that comes with is probably good enough for the average user.. but I'd recommend atleast upgrading it to 32gb eventually.It is very quite when doing websearching, youtube watching, Autocad or even video/photo editing.When my son used it for minecraft, you can start hearing the fans spin after the laptop starts heating up.... nothing too loud though.(2 Month Update, Final update unless something happens)So after using it for a couple months I realized when using the Laptop on battery once in a while the screen would flash black randomly. This is easily fixed by updating the Intel graphics driver to the newest (As of this review the newest version is: 30.0.100.9805).One more thing for people that have problems with the keyboard settings not staying... update the Gigabyte Control Panel. For me, that fixed it and my keyboard lights up how I selected every startup.Everything else is working great and as expected!I really love this laptop!

Because the gpu rtx3080 only has the same 8gb video memory of cards much cheaper. You can get age76 Raider for ablout the same amazing setup for2x the video ram aat 16gb.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2021
review.title: Amazing 4k OLED screen. Powerful laptop. Very happy with this.
review.review: Note: There is a $500 rebate on this laptop until August 31, 2021. Don't forget to get it. I am not sure if I am allowed to post the link here.--- Pros ---I'll never get tired of the screen. This thin-bezel 4K HDR Samsung OLED is pure bliss. Must see it in person to believe how good it looks.The processor is the absolute latest, fastest 8 core (16 thread) processor from Intel. It has the latest Gen 4 PCI-Express, supporting the FASTEST NVME drives and Thunderbolt 4 peripherals in on the market. This is huge for speed of devices attached, and future-proofs the laptop since this technology is new.It comes with a blazing fast boot drive. It's a PCIe Gen4 OEM 500GB Samsung 980 Pro. I am surprised this isn't mentioned anywhere. I only know because I opened the laptop and looked under the hood. This drive has nearly 6,800MBps of read speed(!) Fast as it gets!This is your serious daily-driver work laptop by day, RGB Goofball by night (if that's your thing). Gorgeous modern metallic body with nothing screaming GAMERRR.Putting this guy under heavy stress and I saw internal PEAK temperatures reach about 75C, yet the laptop itself was lukewarm at best thanks to nice cooling.I/O and Connectivity Galore. USB-C Thunderbolt 4, HDMI, Mini Display AND Wi-fi 6? Check.This Laptop is a combination of awesome little details that build to "Almost Perfect". I could be talking about it all day long and it wouldn't be enough. Definitively recommended and a Winner in my personal opinion. Did I mention anything about the OLED?--- Cons ---It's a RTX 3080 with 105W of power. Seriously Gigabyte? The new "Gamer-Focused" Aorus 15P has 130W and this professional content creator gets stuck with just 105W? Maybe I'm just being petty.The Webcam angle is... depressing at best (it's positioned at the top of the keyboard, aiming up). At least I will know if I have BOOGERS during an online conference.The charging port is at the right side of the laptop. For more constricted work spaces like mine, it does rob valuable space to where the mouse could glide.The "Gigabyte Control Center" is good in concept, but bad in execution. It would be great if it didn't fail to remember keyboard lighting settings. Also the "AI tuner" banner pop-up is super annoying. It displays on screen every time you switch an application. And like the keyboard lighting, turning it "off" only does so until you reboot the computer. Once rebooted you must turn them it again. Annoying. I hope they fix this with an update.That's it. These are the only complaints I actually have of this guy in about a month of ownership.--- Overall Review ---This laptop is the latest money can buy. Has everything one could ask for and more. It truly has an unbeatable VALUE to what it offers and it sits at the very top of "overall specs versus dollar" list of any top-end laptop.

review.review: Laptops pack a lot of kick, but, considering the price, it is sub-par from multiple perspectives.1. The Control Center software is terrible. Some settings can't be saved and they roll back to defaults after laptop reboot. "Smart Utilities" are not smart and not utilities. Webcam is low quality and chin cam location is just plain stupid.3. Terrible speakers: no volume and the sound is muffled - can't use it for meetings4. Microphone is also weird not perfect and not great for meetings5. Integrated Bluetooth is terrible - ipods constantly lag (unable to use them in gaming) and I unable to use the ipods microphone as the laptop can't detect it.6. The screen is good in terms of colors, but very reflective7. The power adapter is a BOMB that weighs as much as the laptop and connector is plugged on the side!8. Used it for ~4 hours for casual browsing (no gaming) and the battery diedOverall- I give it 3 stars. Will be sending it back and getting myself Razer or Alienware.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2021
review.title: Looks great and stays cool.
review.review: Over all a very solid machine. It's not perfect, but it runs great, looks good doing it, and won't burn you.2021 09 30 Update at the bottom.The Pros:*Very powerful CPU/GPU*Outstanding cooling system. So far the Aero 15 is running at least 20C cooler than my previous machine. Stock temps in the mid 40s, mid-high 70s under heavy load. I'd be surprised if I ever see this machine thermal throttling in anything remotely like a normal use case. Unlike my previous machine that would regularly hit 95C gaming. (see update about fan quality below)*The best looking screen I have ever seen on a laptop. Every other screen I have looks bland and washed out compared to this glorious 4k OLED. Pictures and reviews I've seen just don't convey how amazing it really looks.*Very good build quality overall.*Bright LED keyboard with a full numpad (fully customizable). Feels better than most laptop keyboards too.*2 RAM and SSD slots are easily accessible by removing the bottom plate (just one set of screws). Also got a thermal pad for a second SSD included in the box.*Built in sliding webcam cover. No need for tape on this one.*So. Many. Ports.The Cons:*The OLED screen is 60 hz. 4k 60 fps is great for most gaming scenarios, but I'd avoid this laptop if you absolutely need ultra high framerates, or want to play twitchy competitive shooters like CS or Valorant where more frames literally win games. The upside is that you can up the GFX settings more than on a higher refresh screen and still get the most out of it.*The OLED screen is not anti glare. There may be a technical reason for that, but regardless, avoid using this in bright areas, or while wearing any reflective clothing. It's reflective enough to be a decent mirror when turned off.*16GB of RAM isn't enough for a machine this powerful. Mine came stock with 2x8GB 3200 Crucial branded chips. They seem to be good RAM, just not big enough. It runs much better with 32GB 3200 HyperX installed. Can support up to 64, so there's room to improve when prices come down.*The built in webcam sucks, to be blunt. It's fairly low quality and poorly positioned. If you need a good webcam, hook up an external, there's more than enough ports to go around.*Gigabyte's Control Center software is a clunky mess, although it does have some useful features. Still not a fun experience using it though.*Unable to undervolt the CPU. This is more about newer chips than this laptop in particular, but I haven't found a way to do it safely.*The screen hinges are a bit weird. It's not loose or flimsy, but the screen can wobble a bit more than what I'd expect.*The function keys are horribly designed. The secondary function of each key is not illuminated, making it very hard to see in the dark. Sleep and Wifi are right next to screen brightness controls, and brightness up is on f4. I'm sure somebody has ruined their day by hitting the wrong button trying to change brightness. The fn key for keyboard brightness is the spacebar, and only has off, 'bright' and 'super bright' settings. For anything in between you need to use the software.*Built in speakers are mediocre. They're not too bad, but like the webcam, they feel like a cut corner compared to the higher quality of the rest of this system.Edit: A few observations after 3 months of use:* Gigabyte really cut corners on the fans. The cooling system works as well as I initially thought it did, but the fans themselves are low quality and wear out quickly. My GPU fan is already starting to wear out and produce irritating excess noise. There's no actual performance loss from it so far, but I've ordered a replacement fan.Dropped a star from 5 to 4 because of this, since after a bit of research it's been a persistent problem with the Aero series for years and remains unfixed by Gigabyte. This is the last place you want to use cheap parts. Inexcusably bad on a product that does so many things right.* I disassembled the Aero 15 for the first time to oil the GPU fan while I wait for the replacement, and I absolutely love the interior design. It's so well thought out and easy to tear down to clean or repair. The heatsink has numbered retained screws, and there are fewer screws than I'm used to seeing in general. Also no easy to break ribbon cables in sight. The downside, again with the fans, is that you have to remove the entire heatsink to access them, so I had to repaste as well.*Oiling the GPU fan reduced the noise it was making by about 80%. This isn't a long term fix, but it does treat the symptoms. Note that this is NOT something the typical end user should be attempting to do. If you aren't confident about your ability to open up a laptop this could be a much bigger problem that requires an RMA, and from what I've heard Gigabyte RMA is a horrible experience.*Also worth mentioning since I tried it, this laptop does not run well with Linux on bare metal. Maybe somebody more experienced with Linux could get it running good, but I couldn't. Stick to VMs or WSL if you need Linux on this machine.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2021
review.title: Great system and screen but odd keyboard lighting
review.review: The screen is terrific, and the form factor is light enough, esp. for a gaming rig.Two things that I didn't notice from the product pictures that are super-annoying:1) The power connector is on the right *middle* of the unit -- since the adapter has an anti-static bulge about 1-1/2" from the connector, you will have to put up with this unsightly cylinder of black plastic as you work whenever this laptop is plugged in. (You can't access the ports on the right if the power cable is facing frontwards.)2) The RGB per-key lighting is beautiful BUT the secondary characters (i.e., when you hit Shift) like for the lighting, sound and even common characters like ( ) @ # $ % on the number row do not light up -- they are not backlit! The problem (via Reddit) is that the Omron switches -- which have excellent tactile feel and travel -- have center lighting only. All right, but the printed secondary characters are done in a wispy light gray which you absolutely cannot see in the dark. (This is a poor design choice here.) They should be near white -- or at least reflect the light of the keys a bit. I just couldn't use this as a developer at night -- you'll need a separate light on to write / program at night. Of course, if you are a good typist, it doesn't matter for the common characters, but for the lighting, sound and other functions you aren't likely to know them by 'muscle memory.')Otherwise, an excellent laptop, but these are two hands-on gotchas you might not notice till you try this out this system in real life.

review.review: I have had my Gigabyte AERO 15 OLED UHD for a year now. It is awesome. I read about the screen shaking when in use, and this is simply NOT the case.. It is very stable and it looks awesome.. Feels substantial and tough, but light and sleek at the same time.. The processing is superb. The keyboard feels perfect and has a satisfying, very soft 'click' .. It honestly feels perfect.. It looks like I spent $3,000 on it and the image quality is beautiful.. I just stared at the google images for several minutes when I first got it.. The picture quality is like you are looking through a window at the real world.. I'm super happy with it. I did upgrade the Ram to 32 G (2 16G Samsung) just for fun... Didn't feel like I really needed it though.. If you are on the fence and you are really picky about how the picture looks just get it .. You'll be really happy you got it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review.title: A decent set of hardware from a terrible vendor - some design issues
review.review: Overall, my biggest gripe is that the warranty supplied here is borderline fraudulent. I purchased this laptop "Brand New" on January 18th, only to find my 1 year warranty was expired when the laptop's DC port failed after 4 months. I build and fix computers in my spare time, and this laptop has required me to open it up and fix a problem every month since I've owned it (that damn right fan). The laptop additionally was clearly used as there were screws missing from the enclosure and scratch marks on the case. One last issue is that the DC port sits isolated on a flimsy corner of the motherboard, which is capable of freely wiggling until the soldered connections break. Absurd from a usage standpoint.Customer service from Gigabyte is unhelpful here - just return it with amazon and go get a different model. It's frustrating because with a few tweaks, this could be a spectacular computer.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review.title: Terrible Product and Terrible Customer Service
review.review: I purchased the Gigabyte AERO 15 laptop on April 20th, 2020 and had nothing but headaches from the start.Within the first month I had to do a hard factory reset and reinstall all of the software because it kept glitching, restarting, and freezing on me.The 3.5mm audio jack does not work.And just recently the cooling fan began malfunctioning and it sounds like a jet engine on my table every time I have the computer turned on.I am using this for my small videography business and use it extensively for video editing.I had some deadlines I needed to meet so I worked through the noise and I couldn't afford to send my laptop to them for a few weeks for repair.I finally got some free time to reach out to Gigabyte about the issue and they tell me it will cost $120 service fee plus cost of parts/labor for the repair because it is less than 3 weeks out of their 1 year warranty.This is absolutely ridiculous!I work for a manufacturing company and we waive costs on product repairs just out of warranty to keep customers happy and because we stand behind our products.I spoke to two people on the phone and they refused to waive the fees/costs of repair for a faulty product that they sold.It was "company policy" to not budge on the warranty.Apparently there is no one with enough authority at Gigabyte to keep customers happy with their crappy products.I will never buy a Gigabyte product again!UPDATE:The SD card reader scrambled TWO of my memory cards.I lost two projects and had to refund money from my videography business because I lost all of the footage!This computer and company are a POS!I purchased a newer, more powerful MSI laptop from BestBuy.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review.title: Great Laptop
review.review: Can’t say enough about this laptop. I’m running the Aero 15 with RTX 2060, i7 9750, and OLED screen.The screen is about as crisp as you can get and the hardware works great together. After I bought the laptop I read a few negative reviews that got me worried. Some of them spoke about the fans being loud. Yes the fans will ramp up while gaming but it’s not a bad thing if you want cool hardware. I’ve heard no “coil whining” and had no issues with the WiFi. If you have issues with this computer it can most likely be fixed by tweaking the firmware and downloading drivers. If you are not at all tech savvy but still want to buy this computer because of the quality the first thing I would do is take it to a friend or someone that can find all the drivers for you and make all the adjustments needed to get this thing working to it’s potential, because once it’s optimized there’s no stopping it. Everything about this laptop screams “Cool”. From the way it runs, to the looks of the screen, the keyboard, and the logo on the back of the screen. The placement of the camera isn’t an issue if you don’t care about the views from your webcam, which I don’t. As far as gaming goes, I’ve run COD Black Ops Cold War (Multiplayer and Main Story) and No Mans Sky, both of which have worked great. May have to lower the video settings in the game itself to get the FPS up but it’s possible to run games at 70 FPS. Maybe my experience has been better than others but I would definitely recommend this laptop based on what I’ve experienced thus far. Will update the review if that at all changes. Hope this helps.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2021
review.title: Defective wifi + shipping delays
review.review: Update: after 2 weeks waiting for replacement, the replacement item still has not shipped despite being listed "in stock". I'm downgrading the review to 1-star due to product defects and shipping delays.Fairly soon after I received the laptop, I began noticing wifi glitches, resulting in wifi disconnecting for a few seconds at a time every few minutes. At first I thought it was my router, but after a few days the laptop kept having problems, while other devices on the same network were working perfectly. Product support had me reinstall drivers, then reinstall Windows, neither of which resolved the problem. The manufacturer was unable to provide an estimate for repairs and recommended I exchange the laptop through Amazon. Amazon support was very helpful in processing the return, however, a week later the replacement still has not shipped due to "processing delays". So I'm out $2k and three weeks later am still waiting for the laptop. I'll update the review when the replacement laptop arrives.Other notes:Screen looks good. Camera placement is super weird, but I knew that going in. Fans are on the loud side, but not too bad if you're just surfing the web or watching videos. Sound was fine. Keyboard backlight was a little annoying in a dark room, but it can be easily turned off/on with Fn+Space. This is probably a good laptop, but seems like there's definitely occasional manufacturing problems, so be careful if you need something that guaranteed "just works" right out of the box.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2021
review.title: Have had laptop {AERO 15 OLED XD) for couple of weeks. Lets call it a 4.5 star
review.review: I've had the laptop {AERO 15 OLED XD-73US624SP version) for a couple of weeks now.OVERALLDespite, missed opportunities in design and implementation, overall I am happy I got the laptop.I seriously love the OLED screen; cpu performance is right where it needs to be. I am happy with the 16 GB of ram and the 1 TB gen 4 SSD.For others who need more storage, the presence of the 2nd gen 3 SSD slot is a big plus. I expect this laptop to serve me well for long time. I guess I can love and still be aware of misses. As of this moment, I am still flipping on giving a 4 or 5 rating.A 4.5 would be comfortable for me to give.But then again my perfect laptop would have to be 6 stars. LOL.I decided to move this support warning from the bottom of the text to the top, because it really bothers that I cannot register the laptopSUPPORTI am perplexed. I have been trying to register the laptop for weeks now.Every link I have tried fails with most common error being 502 Bad Gateway. Does not matter which browser I try and have tried from multiple desktops and laptops. I have bought motherboards and graphics cards from them in the past. So I am surprised and disappointed that they no longer FULLY support their products.These are their own links imbedded in their own web pages.Yeah I expect they are going to reply, Don’t worry, we cover it etc. …… I understand that with Gigabyte being hacked, the company may be distracted from maintaining the business. It reflects badly upon the company.SCREENI love the 4k screen with its high resolution so I can have plenty of open windows and because of the crisp text I can still clearly read data. Basically I can lay panels out on the 15 inch screen like I would for my 27 inch monitor and still read just as well.Most people won’t care but data hogs will be happy. (if you are one, you will know what I am talking about.) Being a 4K screen, Windows will be “suggesting” a 250% scaling which I have dialed back so I can fit more on the display. I have not found any flaws in my display such as dead pixels or backlight issues or bleed. Movies are gorgeous, crisp and bright BUT there is a but.. see section on speakers.KEYBOARDVery Decent. A bit of concave shaping helps center fingers. The little locator bars on the J & F help touch typing and a light bit of bounce and key travel helps.Better than keyboard on my old asus . About equal to my old old Toshibabut not quite as nice of the feel of my Lenovo TabX1. A Plus for the AERO, there a real 10 key pad (sadlylacking on the TabX1 due to size). The backlighting is a BIG plus. I have used the control center to zone the colors and brightness for alphanumeric, function keys, control keys and the ten keys.Whoever decided to NOT include the shifted characters for the backlight needs to be wacked up the side of the head. Duh… Guess I will have to keep a flashlight with me at night.SPEAKERSBluntly barely adequate. The listening environment has to be totally quiet.If there is noise such as a fan in the room then the Volume on every setting from Windows, to the player or video application has to be at maximum. I tried to watch a movie and had to turn off a room fan (it’s August).While I couldhear strongly spoken dialogue, anything whispered was totally lost and I had no idea of what was said. Gigabyte brags “DTS:X Ultra Immerse yourself In Cinema Grade Sound” So external speakers or headphones are going to be needed. Hooking up a good Bluetooth speaker solved the problem for the movie.DOCUMENTATIONNot as good as my prior Gigabyte experiences. When I found the manual on the hard drive I thought I was in good shape.Nope, it was just a soft copy of the 2 page quick start guide.So online you will go hunting.Some specifications are there on the sales portion of the Gigabyte site. I am making a offline copy of the Gigabyte info, just in case they delete the info. Then there are a few third party review sites that cover technical data for the laptop.NOSE CAMIf you have already read or watched the reviews available, you already know the camera placement and quality are such a mess that Gigabyte could have and should have done better right at the beginning of the design and layout planning.I knew about it before I ordered and I will never ever use it. A total waste.
product.title: GIGABYTE AERO 15 OLED XD - 15.6" UHD 4k AMOLED IPS, Intel Core i7, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070 Laptop GPU 8GB GDDR6, 16GB RAM,...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2021
review.title: Worst first experience with Gigabyte
review.review: I ordered this laptop after long searching for machine that fits for both gaming and graphic design. Great screen, excellent specifications for this price, easy upgrades. But when my new laptop arrived it has green hue on the left bottom corner of the screen. I contacted Amazon Customers service and after they were unable to help me they sent me to Gigabyte customer service.Gigabyte e-support answered only after a week and after I sent them pictures they redirected me to their warranty service. So I left RMA request with description of my problem and waited for two days for respond (24-48 hour their usual respond time). But when I tried to check status of my request, I was unable to do that because all of their services went down after ransomeware attack. And they still down for more than 2 weeks.Then I again contacted Amazon Customer service and asked for replacement, which they sent right away ( Thank you, Amazon customer service workers!)BUT! Instead of Aero 15 XD I got Aero 15 KD, which is cheaper version with lower specs, such as 3060 gpu vs 3070 gpu and 512gb SSD/1tb SSD. And it looks like wrong laptop was sent from Gigabyte. I had actual laptop package inside of Gigabyte shipping box with shipping label to Amazon with correct model name on it, but with different model inside. So that means this error was made on Gigabyte's side.I requested refund and from now on I will avoid any Gigabyte products.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2019
review.title: Endless Blue Screens
review.review: I really want to love this computer. It's thin and light (for a powerhouse) and gets decent battery life, but it blue screens constantly. It's been doing so, about once a week, since I pulled it out of the box. Multiple clean reinstalls of Windows, along with testing various versions of drivers, have done nothing to mitigate the issue. People seem to blame the Nvidia+Intel graphics card combos, but neither my previous Dell or Asus laptops (both w/ Nvidia + Intel combos) had this issue.I'm apparently not alone here. I wish I had read the reviews more closely before buying it. It feels like a sucker punch to pay so much for a machine that you cannot rely on for doing the most basic of tasks without crashing.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2018
review.title: Amazing build quality. questionable SSD
review.review: This is a product I was very excited to purchase. I had been looking into getting this laptop for the past 4 months. the sleek design caught my eye and I loved how it didnt look like a gaming laptop that I could use at home and anywhere I go. I had the money to either build a pc or to buy this laptop and I decided to get the laptop because it has a 144hz IPS panel that is crystal smooth and clear. I play games like Overwatch and Rainbow Six Siege and get an easy 120-144 fps. very enjoyable experience. I am a little upset because it seems that the SSD inside my laptop is pretty slow and is constantly using 50%+ disk space while doing absolutely nothing which is disappointing at the price I paid for this so I need to buy a new SSD and a screwdriver to install it. I dont mind the fan noise because this is a powerful laptop and having the fans are very important. overall I am very happy with this purchase. I chose the GTX 1060 because i'm not trying to get the "ultimate experience" with ultra settings. Ill wait for my pc to do that. this is a perfect gaming laptop with the best compromising that you can have. Before I got this laptop I thought RGB was the ugliest thing to see on videos but when I turned this laptop on I've really started to like the look. I highly recommend this laptop if you want something powerful and something sleek to use in public.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2021
review.title: PRODUCTS COMES WITH EXPIRED WARRANTIES
review.review: Bottom line, just don't buy anything from GIGABYTE.I used this laptop for less than a year. In that amount of time, I've had two different laptops of the same model. Both had the exact same hardware issues within 5 months where the computer freezes, BSODS, and then is stuck in a BIOS bootloop. After doing some research, I found that this issue is quite common in GIGABYTE laptops and is most likely caused by the SSD.What's even worse is their customer service. The products come with the warranties already expired. If you do decide to take the leap of faith and buying a GIGABYTE product, my advice is to check the serial number of the item before even opening the box and confirming the warranty is not already expired on the GIGABYTE website. I am currently trying to get a refund for the replacement but it looks like I'll be paying a $200 restocking fee. -$200 for this glitchy piece of garbage.Don't waste your money.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
review.title: BLUE SCREEN OF DEATH. Battery does not live up to what it claims
review.review: ***This is an update to my previous post. I've had this laptop for a little over three months now and have now started getting the dreaded BLUE SCREEN! This is my work laptop and so I don't use it for any personal gaming/activities. This is pretty disappointing considering the fact how expensive it is.Changing my 2 stars to 1. Would give it half a star if I could. Ultimately it's your money and your choice but my suggestion is DO NOT BUY!So the main reason that I got this laptop because I needed a work computer with a long battery life. I have a desktop for all my gaming needs. When i first received the laptop, I noticed that the seal was already coming off, as I was excited about the laptop itself I just brushed it off as perhaps shipping issue. As I turned it on and got everything set up, I was pounded with notification to download a bunch of things that I didn't need or seemed fishy. I opted to just reset the laptop and delete everything. Hopefully it hasn't been tempered with....I've had the laptop for two weeks now and I have to say that I am quite disappointed with it. The feature that I was looking forward to most which was the long battery life does not live up to what it says. I get maybe 3-4 hours at most with a full charge with just watching youtube/prime movies and doing some work. I haven't tested out the gaming capacity side of this laptop yet so I can't comment on that too much but I did try running two instances of Bluestacks at low settings and it lagged both of them pretty hard. It handled one instances okay.So overall the laptop itself works fine, however the reason why I bought it was for the battery life and it doesn't live up to what it claims about it's long battery life.

Aside from that, the 144hz can be connected to another large 144hz monitor for greater gaming experience. The only downside of this is that it gets so HOT and may cause the motherboard and internal parts to fry. I would recommend buying a gaming fan cooler to avoid this disaster.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
review.title: Fantastic... if it Worked
review.review: I bought this back in February, and the 4K OLED screen is amazing, the graphical performance is better than I've had in other laptops, and the cooling seems to do a decent job at keeping the machine from thermal throttling too much. High-speed hardware and a great price for one of the few laptops with a 4K display, let alone a nice OLED one.Unfortunately, every time I try to play a game on it with a second SSD installed, it'll decide to cut my internet speed down by 90% or more, if it even stays connected to the Internet in the first place. On top of that, it'll sporadically disconnect from any peripherals I use with it, including mice, headsets, external keyboards, wired or wireless, it'll get dropped if that second hard drive is in there.I've already sent it in once, and when I got it back and the issue showed up again after only a couple of days, I tried to troubleshoot it more myself so I could provide Gigabyte with more information. However when I went to try and submit a second RMA request, I found my login information was suddenly not on file, even though I've already sent it back to them once. No big deal, seeing as I can make a fresh account and go from there, right?Wrong. Now the serial number that was fine before is registering in a different country, and I cant get my RMA request processed regardless.If you're getting this for streaming or for business, you should be fine. But if you're looking for a great new gaming laptop, this thing will make you regret buying it.Seeing as it's still under warranty, I'm still trying to get this laptop either replaced or my money back. But seeing as their tech support is apparently so swamped that they can't get to me in a timely manner or bother their specialists to actually call me back, and submitting an e-ticket usually takes a week or more to hear back, I'm hoping this review gets their attention and we can get this problem solved once and for all.All I can really say is buyer beware. If you get a bad unit, there's a good chance you'll be stuck with it for quite some time.

review.title: Dead laptop.. no reply from tech support $1800 wasted
review.review: I ordered this laptop 3 1/2 months ago and it worked great. About a week ago, it stopped charging.Called Tech support and got automated message just telling me to leave a number. Been over a week.Zero reply. Laptop still dead.No tech support at all.No call back no email nothing.Now I have an $1800 paper weight!!!While laptop worked it was ok, but I recommend you buy a bigger name brand with actualtech support unless you have $1800 to burn.Good luck to anyone who buys this junk.Hope you never need tech support.I’m only hoping Amazon will read this and help me replace the laptop before my son starts college!!!UpDate!! 9/7/21.Its been over 3 weeks since we contacted tech support.They did call back,after two weeks, and said they would email and RMA# and instructions to return for repair.Its been over a week, still no RMA or instructions, no contact other than the automated call saying I would get RMA.Also with more research, it appears the charging port is a common issue.Update 9/16/21Gigabyte has completely stopped responding.No warranty, No Help, Only a vVoice mail that says they will call back.Yet No Call back from Gigabyte customer service..Absolutely horrible.Warranty is useless.I wish Amazon would let me Use a Zero RatingComplete Junk!!!!Zero Tech Support.DO NOT BUY!!!Amazon finally agreed to let me return it to them, still nothing from Seller.

La pantalla oled es lo mejor que puedes pillar en un notebook. Tuve que vender mi MacBook Pro i9 16” por un apuro económico y compré este equipo para poder seguir editando videos, debo decir que no hecho de menos en absoluto mi MacBook, al contrario, la calidad de la pantalla de este Aero es muy superior a la del MacBook y el desempeño tanto en edición de video como en juegos es igual o mejor al desempeño del MacBook. La gran cantidad de puertos que trae te facilita enormemente la vida. En cuanto al ruido, debo decir que el equipo es muy silencioso. Hasta el momento estoy tremendamente encantado con este equipo, es la mejor compra que he hecho en Amazon.Contras: el equipo es de aluminio y se marcan muy fácilmente los desos al tomarlo. La aplicación control center de gigabyte no es de las mejores. El audio del equipo no satura, tampoco suena mal, pero bueno bueno no es. Eso lo único que que he encontrado a nivel de detalles

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
review.title: Great laptop, but some weird software
review.review: I got this laptop for work and to play games while I travel, and it's awesome! It looks and feels like a professional's machine, not a gamer's toy, so it fits into any kind of working environment. Aluminum chassis, sleek black design, no excessive RGB lighting.It has a lot of useful ports and little need for dongles. The two USB-Cs were a nice touch. One of them will fast-charge my cellphone, which is a huge plus for me when on the go.The POWER of this machine is awesome. Even though its light and small, it can run VR games at full FPS, supports raytracing, and can run Unity, Slack, Visual Studio, 24 VNC clients and compile video at the same time. Can't believe this thing's got an i9 AND an RTX 2070 for under $2k. Be wary though: when this thing gets going, it gets HOT. You can't do real work / gaming on your lap, and I nearly burned myself touching the underside when I needed to move it.I haven't really tested the battery that well, but I did manage to do some off-and-on video editing / web browsing for about 4-5 hours before needing to charge. But as you should know, that kind of battery life is not going to last for long.The only problems I've had, other than its hot-to-the-touch underside, is the pre-installed software. As a tech pro, I'm okay with handling some of the hiccups, but others might have problems. First, the "A.I." it has installed is handy at times, an annoyance at others. You can read about it elsewhere, but my two cents: It's really cool how it handles power regulation for different apps so you don't have to. I was also pleasantly surprised when it changed my keyboard lighting based on what game I was playing, all automatically. However, the program is a bit CPU intensive, and it will override settings that you don't want it to touch, so you'll have to configure it accordingly; however, I usually just turn it off 100% to avoid fiddling with settings and to get some CPU utilization back.Most of the pre-installed software is just no use to me at all, and usually just cause annoyances. These can be easily uninstalled, but if you like a crystal clean machine upon purchase so you don't have to do anything (which doesn't really exist for current PC's anyway), you're gonna have a bad time.Also the camera is bad, but pretty on-par as far as laptop PC cameras go. I never use it, so it's fine for me.BOTTOM LINE: if you're thinking about getting a Razor Blade or an Alienware m15, seriously consider getting this. It has power, professional looks, and a small form factor for under $2,000.

review.title: HDR does not work! Gigabyte MALWARE all over the place.Screen still pretty without it though.
review.review: So for $2,500 and an emphasis on a great screen, I'd expect the HDR (which is in the NAME) to work.Unfortunately it does not. It completely bogs down the entire system, making watching videos, playing games, and navigating Windows pretty much impossible. Super laggy.After speaking with support it was clear they were not going to be any help. They recommended I reinstall the Gigabyte control center (lol) and "update" the drivers. (Update in quotes because most of the recommended drivers from the control center were old and out of date, including the Nvidia drivers.)Be aware that support for this laptop will be non-existent.I did a full wipe and reinstall of windows to see if maybe all the garbage software Gigabyte installed was causing the issues, but, nope. HDR is broken on this computer.As far as the internals, as long as HDR is off, this will rip though any game you throw at it on ultra settings, and the screen is still pretty. Only 60hz refresh rate though.I bought this computer because I wanted a mobile 3070 chip and a 17 inch screen. For those reasons it works, so I'm not super disappointed. But for $2500 I expected a LOT more, like the HDR to work, and the pre installed gigabyte software to not completely break the machine.If I had to do it again, I would not buy this laptop.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review.title: Terrible Fan Issues and Customer Support
review.review: Bought this laptop to use for college and games, and was extremely happy at first. After about 3 months of normal use, the GPU fan starting making an awful grinding sound. After getting to school, the fan eventually stopped working completely, causing the laptop to overheat and crash when doing things as simple as web browsing. Communicating with Gigabyte took 3 or more days between responses, and ended with having to pay $100 in shipping due to the warranty being limited, not full. It took nearly a two weeks (aside from shipping times) for a simple fan replacement that would likely take a technician no longer than an hour. During this time I had to work out getting a temporary laptop to use for school, which was an ordeal in and of itself.After receiving the laptop for the second time, it worked perfectly and I was once again happy. It is now 1 year later, and the other fan just died. The warranty only lasts a year, so it's up by now. I could easily do the replacement myself, but Gigabyte is stingy with their parts and I can only find a replacement fan from a third party for $85, which is far higher than the actual value of the part. After lots of research last year and this year, this seems to be a relatively common problem with the Aero 15 series in general. Despite loving the laptop when it works, this experience has prompted me to never want to buy a product from Gigabyte again.Don't be optimistic, don't be fooled by the generally good specs, don't take a risk, and don't waste your money; a laptop of this price should absolutely not have problems as simple as these, with such poor customer support to back it up. Despite the fact that there are some favorable reviews, if you would rather not deal with these same issues, go with a more reputable manufacturer.
product.title: Gigabyte AERO 15 OLED SA-7US5020SH 15" Thin Bezel Samsung UHD Amoled, i7-9750H, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660 Ti, Samsung 8GB RA...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2020
review.title: Rough edges overwhelm an intriguing idea
review.review: When I was looking to purchase a new laptop in early-mid 2019, my desired features were for it to be relatively thin and light while still holding a discrete graphics card, have a Thunderbolt 3 port (or more), and ideally have a monitor with good color reproduction.My intended use was primarily for gaming, but I was also looking for a portable workstation for photo and video editing.Unfortunately, most Windows laptops don't have Thunderbolt, end of.Of the few that did, most had only one, and often it was only available on models with lower-end processors and/or no discrete graphics card.And even the tiny number that checked those boxes generally had TN panels with limited color accuracy.So my selection was fairly limited.The AERO 15 seemed to have (most) of the specs I was looking for.And the new line had OLED displays that promised superb color accuracy.While the price was certainly higher, it had the best combination of size, weight, processor/GPU, and monitor available.Plus it had two M.2 slots for PCIe SSDs (another rarity), and seemed to be user upgradeable with relative ease, which was important given that the models available paired memory and SSD upgrades with faster processors and GPUs.Sadly, reality is much harsher.The problems started immediately.I had read that the AERO series could be finicky about the RAM it took.So after extensive research and finding lists of apparently compatible RAM on various forums (absolutely no official statement from Gigabyte, only supposedly official lists of compatible RAM provided by tech support and posted on forums), I selected a set that seemed to offer the best price/performance ratio for the range in which I was looking, and ordered it at the same time.After booting the laptop up the first time to confirm it worked, I powered it off, flipped it over, and began the laborious process of removing all 12 screws from the backplate.It took a bit of work with a spudger, but the backplate came off to reveal a fairly good arrangement of internals.It was a bit disconcerting to find that the thermal pad on the SSD had been folded in application and was mostly just scrunched up between the end of the SSD and the backplate.But nevertheless, it was easy enough to pop out the stock DIMM and replace it with my new paired set.Screwing everything back together, I plugged in the power, hit the power key, and...nothing.The laptop would not post.So out with the screws again (that was dumb), off with the backplate, double check that everything is seated properly, and nothing.One more attempt for good measure, and I decide to swap back to the original DIMM to make sure everything should work.Yup, no problem.So I spent several hours over that night and the next day trying to get my RAM replacement to work.I had a partial success fairly early on, when I got it to post with the original stick (8 GB Samsung) and and one of the new ones (16GB Corsair).Of course, it was then running both DIMMs at the slower speed of the Samsung, and there was no reason I should run a mismatched pair.So I pulled the Samsung and put in the other Corsair, and was right back to the black screen of futility.Eventually, I gave up.Some of that was forced, because I'm pretty sure I fried the Samsung DIMM by accidentally hotplugging it.How was it an accident?Well I forgot another fun feature of this laptop.It won't shut off.See it refused to post with the Corsair memory, but it still powered up, spun the fans, all that jazz.And when it didn't post, I'd hold down the power button to force it to shut down, and it would.And then, sometime in the next few seconds, it would start up again.And I was impatient, and wanted my relatively expensive laptop to work, so I didn't disconnect or discharge the battery, and I wasn't quite fast enough in swapping DIMMs before it powered on again.So I discharged the battery overnight, tried again the next day in every combination I could think of, and gave up and ordered a pair of the same model of Samsung memory it had come with.When the memory arrived, I inserted it, flipped the laptop over, hit the power button, and it was fine.Actually I think it made my heart sink by not posting the first time, but at the second attempt, it booted fine and I've never had an issue with not booting due to RAM since.Which brings me to the experience of using it.It's...fine.Gigabyte packages it with several control panels that are supposed to make customizing everything and getting the most out of it a breeze.From other reviews I read, this is a bit hit or miss, and it mostly just got in my way when I didn't actually want to make changes.It is a nice package - mostly black, no gaudy trim with the exception of the faux-chrome "AERO" plate between the rear heatsinks, and while it does have a giant AERO logo in LEDs on the lid, at least they're white.I had/have no complaints about the speed, though I haven't really pushed it.The fans are loud when they rev up, which is most of the time, though that's partly due to my leaving it on a fairly aggressive cooling setting.Crapware is mostly nonexistant (except for the unavoidable Windows stuff).But it's not just the firmware that has quality problems.The hardware also apparently has iffy quality control, as I've discovered today when my GPU fan bearings failed.Even if Gigabyte would still honor the warranty (if it even still falls in the warranty period), their RMA process is infamously bad, with every forum discussing issues with Gigabyte full of posts about a complete lack of communication from customer support.So where do I go from here?Would I recommend this version, or a newer one, or would I buy a Gigabyte laptop again?I'm not sure.When it was working, I quite liked it.But, purely anecdotally, every other laptop I've owned has just worked.I didn't have the stress of wondering if I had just sunk thousands of dollars into a fancy paperweight with other brands, just because my memory wasn't on a super secret list of four models (not even just brands; specific models) that would work.While they've worn out and/or gotten slower, that was after three or four years of hard use, not one.And I have no confidence that, if there had been a serious problem during the warranty period and I had wanted to return or get it fixed, that I would have had any success doing so.So I guess the tl;dr is:If you do plenty of research about the specific model you're looking to buy to find out exactly what parts you can use to upgrade it, and if you're willing to fly solo and/or with the help of random (helpful and kind) people on the internet, and if you're ok gambling that you won't have any major part fail quickly (but not so quickly it can be warrantied), then yeah, go ahead and get this (or a similar) laptop from Gigabyte.But if not, then I'd say it's worth whatever tradeoff there may be in increased price (potentially Razer) or slightly worse specs (Dell, several other brands) is probably worth it to avoid a brand and line that has so many issues.
