review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
review.title: Stable and powerful rig.
review.review: After getting the keyboard LEDs to finally just serve as backlighting (and remain so through boots), removal of the bloatware, removing unneeded permissions for apps, and stopping bing from trying to sell me junk (usual Windows install stuff) it is a good rig and runs well under load.I have not tinkered with the power settingsI certainly wish three were a way of preventing the thing from wanting to be a gawdy gaming rig with intrusive keyboard glamour when I press a keystroke.This is a creators rig.That annoyance should be absent and left for the adolescentgaming crowd under 14 y/o.Cooling fans are much quieter than other 'Content Creators' lap tops. Yet, it remains running.In tests of 2 other creator lap tops, this is a rare surprise (one competitor system gets hot to the touch and then locks up before thermal throttling).If the battery lasted longer, this would be a great mobile rig.At its current battery life; it is a portable rig.Cant be away from mains for long at all (2hrs of watching LinkedIn training via wireless and it was done).It has taken almost all I have thrown at other laptops and seemingly is ready for more.Booger cam is no problem for me.I disable built-in cameras and microphones in all lap tops so it will use those external ones by default.So, the cover was perfect and saved me a cam cover/tape to cover it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2020
review.title: One of the best gaming laptops I have used
review.review: The laptop itself is amazing. It is sleek, sturdy, and well built. The one thing I would say that bugs me about the design would be the camera location. But, of course, if you want no bezel, you need to put the camera somewhere, and a camera down there is better than no camera. The access to the internals is pretty easy but you need a T6 screwdriver to access it. The main problem with this laptop would be the detection of memory. I bought the 16 GB memory variant but I wanted to take it to the max with 64 GB. However, I found out how hard this is very soon. The BIOS has a very hard time recognizing what ram is put in. For example, if I were to take out the existing ram and put it back in, it had problems booting up; I would be met with a black screen that keeps running the fans on high. If I were to try to force shut it down, it would just turn back on. Which made it pretty damn hard to swap ram as I was afraid offring the entire laptop. I just had to keep taking it out and putting it back in for it to recognize the ram and now I am set with 32GB and I gave up on putting the other 32 in there for a while. I have submitted a ticket. will update on how that goes. The other one thing that kind of annoys me is the battery life when doing anything other than standby is pretty low when compared to their claims but not bad nevertheless.Overall, I am pretty happy with my purchase and the 240HZ panel is a beauty to work on and game.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
review.title: Manual Adjustments Needed!
review.review: I had a Surface Book 2 before this one, but this OLED screen is probably the most beautiful laptop screen I've ever seen. Performance is good, but there's one MASSIVE CATCH.THERMALS were terrible, sitting around 52 *C on IDLE and upwards of 90 *C under load. Fans were ALWAYS running and very loud.I was about to return this until I tried to manually adjust a few things as a last effort (through Windows Apps only, I did not touch any hardware stuff since that may impact the Warranty/Return Policy). I have this laptop for only a few days, so take this with a grain of salt. I'll try to update if something comes up.First, you need to finish all of your Windows Updates.Then download Gigabyte Control Center from Gigabyte website if you don't have it already. Update every driver available through there. Then here's the tricky part. Refer to online threads (aka Google search) if you are not familiar.1) Go to Nvidia Control Center. Under Manage 3D Setting, change Power Management Mode to Adaptive.2) Open an app called Intel Extreme Tuning Utility (should be installed along with Windows Update, but download if you need to). Undervolt CPU Core and CPU Cache by 100 mV (-0.100 V). Decrease Graphics Ratio Limit by 2 units.3) Go to Control Panel > Hardware and Sound > Battery Options > Change plan settings (recommend do this for all options) > Change advanced power settings > Processor power management > minimum processor rate. Change all values to 0 or 1 %.4) Restart your PC.5) Go to Gigabyte Control Center again. Using the lowest CPU slider option and on Quite Mode in Device Setting, the laptop should run ~40-45 *C on idle, and fans should not be running when using typical web browsing/Office apps.When under load (playing games, video editing, etc.) changes above should not have noticeable effects on performance. It's a pity that the laptop doesn't come with these settings automatically, but this is the work you have to do if your unit has problems like mine. If these changes does not work, considering returning your laptop. Again, I only have this laptop for a few days. Take these advises with a grain of salt.
product.title: Gigabyte AERO 15 OLED SA-7US5020SH 15" Thin Bezel Samsung UHD Amoled, i7-9750H, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660 Ti, Samsung 8GB RA...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
review.title: Not for casuals. Seriously.
review.review: If I weren't technically inclined I would be utterly heartbroken over this purchase. If all you do is edit photos and tinker around on the internet - it's fine but this laptop is marketed to power users. If you game in any capacity, do a lot of video rendering or anything that comes close to maxing cpu loads then you will absolutely thermal throttle 100% of the time. This laptop requires use of Throttlestop and the know-how to set it up. You cannot use intel XTU. After setting it to max out at 3.8-3.9 Ghz and setting a -150mv undervolt it now barely ever breaks mid 70 degrees Celsius. Before it would it 90 degree before a games splash screen was loaded. It was that bad. 4.0ghz seems to be the tipping point before heat skyrockets.Next, a few weeks ago the gpu fan started making crunching sounds and then go silent. I opened the monitoring utility and saw that when it went silent that it was actually turning off. The fan was trying to start and puttering out. I had to disassemble everything to get to the fans and take it apart to oil it after 2 months of ownership! The entire inside was spotless but it seems that bad fans are pretty common and other people have had to send their computers away. NOPE! Not this guy. Cost me 7 bucks because I had to repaste the CPU and GPU over a freaking bad fan - thank god the motor still had power. I just thought the cute little guy liked to chirp at me from time to time. Didn't know it was a time bomb.Next, RAM. Just buy Samsung. Don't do anything else. Other motherboards will let you mix brands - hell even frequencies. This one is a picky eater.So with that being said, where else are you going to get a laptop this BEAUTIFUL and UNIQUE? This product once the bugs are sorted is an absolute joy. The GPU now easily overclocks 100mhz (MSI Afterburner) and runs neck in neck with the desktop version with (now) great thermals and frames. I can now take it anywhere without worrying about it self-destructing.However, the fact that if I were a common consumer I probably would be without a computer and living in warranty nightmare I cannot recommend this to anyone aside from techy nerds. If at any point you did not understand my jargon - back off. If you did and are not intimidated - enter at your own risk and use my experience to guide you.
product.title: Gigabyte AERO 15 OLED SA-7US5020SH 15" Thin Bezel Samsung UHD Amoled, i7-9750H, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660 Ti, Samsung 8GB RA...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2021
review.title: Good Laptop, Top Notch service
review.review: I am a computer person that uses computers all day for work using Solidworks an other design programs that can be stressful on computers. At night I game, for a few hours before bed. I have not had a Laptop for several years preferring to build my own computer and continually upgrade. Needless to say I was nervous about getting a Laptop.having an issue with the laptop after only a week of use only made me have buyers remorse. Thankfully tho Computer Upgrade Kings with Amazon worked with me on figuring out the problem with the laptop and got a replacement in just a few days.I am not sure what the problem was exactly with the laptop. The battery life went from 4+ hours on delivery to <1 hour a week later. The Laptop was overheating and crashing during the boot cycle.The new Laptop is working very well, good battery life @ ~ 6 hours gaming time with the GPU at max.It does run warm while plugged in but not past 75C. It will run cooler while under battery power. I believe this is because it dials down the power consumption. I have mine on a cooling pad and the GPU stays <65C consistently.All-in-all its a good laptop. I would get it again.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2021
review.title: Truly fantastic laptop, really low-performance SSD upgrade.
review.review: I love every single thing about this laptop, except one part of the Computer Upgrade King "upgrade". The RAM part was fine, but they put an Adata Swordfish 2tb SSD in it, and the performance of those is known to be terrible. I have no idea why they would spec a low-performance drive like that as the main drive for a laptop with this sort of performance, but they did. It would actually be a good add-on as a 2nd drive, but they should disclose exactly what drive they put in it as an "upgrade" vs a generic product description entry like it is so people are aware and can plan accordingly. If you are contemplating buying a system for them, I can say they are responsive, and the system is certainly stable, but you should ask exactly what parts are going on the machine.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Super fast laptop for work!
review.review: I don't use this laptop to play games, but to work editing videos with 2D and 3D animations. Compared to my desktop i7-7820X, this i7-11800H is 25% faster, but the difference is in the NVidia Geforce RTX 3070 video card, it is 4 times faster than my desktop NVidia Geforce RTX 1660. I can work on it 8K videos in DaVinci Resolve 17 without any problem and animate in Fusion easily due to its 8 GB of VRAM. The prices of electronic products are going up, so I decided to buy it now before the prices go up any more.Another advantage of this laptop is its aluminum chassis, which unlike my previous laptops, is very strong and feels sturdy. The mechanical keyboard is very good and the battery life of about 4 hours is relatively acceptable for a laptop with that much power. My previous gaming laptop had a battery life of 1.5 hours.What I don't like is that it only has two M.2 bays and that the fans make too much noise if I use it in the most powerful mode.Otherwise, it is an excellent purchase.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2018
review.title: Overpowered and Unneccessary (A 1 year Later Review)
review.review: The Aorus X5 V7, laptop does it's job, with an i7-7820HQ CPU and full size GTX 1070 with 16 GB of DDR4 RAM, it smashes the most demanding games on the max graphics, such as The Witcher 3, The Division, Arma 3, and the new Black Ops 4.While it does accomplish it's job, there are a lot of unnecessary features that make me regret purchasing this laptop when it was $2500. (As of 9/18/18, it is $1799.00 on Amazon).The Unnecessary Features/ Negatives1) You don't need the Overclockable CPU, it's not worth the extra processing speed, and contributes to the laptop's overall heat (this laptop runs 80-90 degrees Celsius normally with AAA games).2) You don't need the 3K, 2880 x 1620 pixels screen resolution. On a 15.6 inch screen, one can't tell the difference between 1080p and 1620p resolutions with most games. (Running it on a higher resolution just contributes to the heat anyway)3) The Screen is only a 59.97 Hz refresh rate, meaning that the max FPS you can get is 60 with any game, this seems a bit counter intuitive when you have a 3K resolution screen, and a full size GTX 1070 graphics card. The laptop does have G-Sync capabilities which does help when you have a screen that is capped at 60 FPS, but one would rather have a 144 Hz refresh screen than one with the extra cost added on because of G Sync and higher resolution.4) The laptop runs REALLY HOT, on most modern AAA games, the laptop (When using MSI Afterburner) clocks temperatures of 80-90 degrees Celsius. Which makes the laptop unable to be played on a lap, unless you want to scald yourself, I even bought a laptop cooler, which doesn't help much at all. The keyboard even gets so hot, it's at time unbearable to be playing on it, even on a desk.- The added processing power of the i7-7820HQ processor just adds too much heat to the compact design of this laptop. And now that there are the 8th gen CPUs out, the 7820HQ is just obsolete.- Even the power brick gets hot to the touch. Recommending you leave it somewhere away from your feet.5) The laptop within a couple days of delivery, would randomly shut down ( no BSOD), just a random freeze for about 5 seconds, then a full shutdown. Assuming related to the heating issues, there's no error message so there's no way to tell).6) After a year and a couple weeks ( The warranty is only for a YEAR by the way), I started to get awkward BSODs, and using the Manufacturer's Driver Update Utility (Aorus) is not recommended. Most of the Drivers that the program gives you are out of date by more than a few months, free programs such as Driver Booster from iObit work a lot better. The BSODs would give Driver Verifier DMA Violation errors, and no error code, so yet another random shut down that is un-diagnosable.- After performing a fresh install of Windows 10 and all applications. I performed a hard drive health check with HWinfor, and found that the M.2 SSD was already at 74%. Which is very low for a 1 year old laptop. The issues are likely related to the terrible heat managing system for the beefy specs.7) If you do lose a key (which I did), there is not a place that I could find, online or offline, that provides key replacements. The only way you could get a replacement, is to pay for shipping, ship it to the nearest service center for Aorus, and get the entire keyboard replaced.8) Because of the heat requirements, the fans get REALLY loud, you will NEED to use headphones or crank up the speakers all the way. My friend described it as a "Jet Engine" when playing with the fans at maximum. High pitched and very loud, you can't game in public like the library, or a coffee shop. ( Make sure to clean the fans regularly, I had the right fan start to go out on me after about 8 months, and it never got back up to it's full speeds after cleaning).The Positives1) It gets the job done, runs the games, and gives 60 FPS comfortably on 1080p resolution ( I almost never found the need to run the laptop on 1620p)2) The keyboard is really nice, feels great, and has great response (Until I lost a key). The individually lit RGB software is easy to use and a nice add-on.3) The profile makes it inconspicuous, and doesn't "scream" gamer laptop. With the black metal frame, and only a lit up Aorus logo on the top, it prevents distractions when using it in public.4) Despite the Heating issues, and the temperatures that the laptop reaches, there is a good default fan controlling software (Command and Control) that lets you ramp up the fans as much as they can go, which stabilizes the temperatures at least to the range of 80-90 C.5) The Laptop comes with attachable feet, as if they knew you would need more circulation for this laptop, which haven't failed me in helping the laptop cool itself.6) G-Sync capabilities are nice, you rarely notice screen tears, and you can even change the settings to apply to not only fullscreen mode when gaming.7) The IO is very nice, providing an Ethernet Port, 2 USB 3.0 slots (Thunderbolt 3 Support), 2 USB 2.0 slots, an HDMI slot. an SD card slot, a separate mic and headphone jack, a USB A slot, and a Kensington slot. You won't need an extra USB splitter unless you are using all peripherals.8) The weight for what it contains is very nice, allowing extreme portability for such a powerful machine. Only weighing 5.5 pounds (past 6.0 if you carry the power brick).9) The battery lasts 3-4 hours depending on what you are doing, which is very respectable for a gaming laptop with such powerful specs, if you plan on taking it to more than a few classes, I'd recommend taking the power brick with you.10) The speakers are really nice, they get very loud, and have good sound quality even at the max volumes, you rarely hear peaking or loss in quality unless it's the file itself you are listening to.11) The X-Rite Pantone Calibration, allows for one to flip a switch and get good color accuracy.Overall, the laptop does it's job, plays games with a small figure. However, at a year later, this laptop is not worth it. For what I paid for, I rarely need to overclock the CPU, and since doing that will increase the heat output even further than it already does, I'm sure you'd be putting the laptop on its deathbed. Now with laptops giving 144 Hz refresh rate, 1080p screens, with 8th generation i7 and i5 CPUs, this laptop has been effectively phased out. The negatives of this laptop just make it not worth your money.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2018
review.title: Very nice laptop overall
review.review: This is a really powerful laptop but it has a few down sides.Pros.1. Powerful CPU and GPU2. Nice full size keyboard and its RGB3. Nice screen along with G-sync4. A large selection of ports5. Thin size for whats inside.6. Can be very quiet.7. Ample storage and ram space. Both can be upgraded.8. Dedicated audio card.9. 4 speakers. See cons also.Cons.1. Heat. It gets hot on the bottom side.2. Fans can be really noisey when you dont set them up correctly.3. Its only a 60hz screen in $2300.00 laptop.4. Track pad could be better.5. The aorus software it hard to get used to and could be better implimented.6. Battery life sucks.7. Speakers lack substance.I know I have a few cons on here but you cannot have it all. This is a gaming laptop, it will get hot especially with the hardware that is in it. It has plenty or storage and ram and both can be upgraded. Theres an open m.2 slot and two open ram slots. The screen is very nice and can get bright but its a small thing that its only 60hz. Its plenty but for the price it could have been better. The aorus software works fine once you get to know how it operates. I wish there was a better tutorial out there for it. Once you get used to it, the software is fine. I wish they would have used optimus instead of g-sync. I have tried a few other laptops such as the acer predator triton 700 gtx 1060 (I could not get used to the track pad and keyboard location but over all nice. It also had a very clicky keyboard), razer blade 14 gtx 1060( it ran hot all the time and the fans were really loud, like a small jet engine, also limited upgradeability), gigabyte aero 15 ( I know same manufacture but the aero 15 was very nice, small, compact, and great battery life, but it had a few down falls. Coil whine, weak screen hinges, lound ac charger, screen sleep closing angle was way to early like at 45 degrees, plus I had one die on me), 2017 macbook pro 256gb model. (Very nice, great battery life, thin, great speakers, and great screen. The downsides of the macbook pro were no upgrade options. Repair cost were out of sight, and only thunderbolt port options.)The aorus x5 v7 fit the bill of all my needsd of storage and ram capacity, great screen, full size keyboard and backlit, 15 inch, powerful graphics card and cpu. The only downside is the heat and the battery life. I can squeeze 2.5 hrs while just web browsing. It was hard finding a laptop that did not annoy me as much as the others.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2017
review.title: Great laptop for editing, gaming on ultra - Gigabyte did well with this one!
review.review: This review is for the x5 v7 model - I purchased this laptop mostly for video editing but also some gaming on the go. I've had the X5 v7 about two and a half weeks and these are my impressions of it so far:Pros:OCs very well - 4.3GHz stock and can be pushed more in the BIOS if you want.X-Rite pantone screen color profile looks great.The Command and Control and Driver update Utility are awesome and make monitoring your machine easy. I really like if you minimize C&C utility that you get a dashboard with all the important machine info like GPU-CPU load, temps, fan speeds, adjust OC.Full metal body feels sturdy and doesn't creak.RGB keyboard looks even on each key and has a lot of options via software.1070 is a beast and can play most games on max quality.Thunderbolt 3 port is a huge space saver - I'm using this dock for everything but powering the laptop: Dell 3GMVT Thunderbolt Dock TB16, 240W, blackWeighs only 5.5 lbs - not bad for how powerful it is.Cons:A little "flash-lighting" in upper right corner.Screen is a little flimsy compared to rest of laptop.Laptop is a fingerprint magnetBottom panel to get to internals is a little sharp- be careful when opening it!Things to note:Battery life on a laptop like this while gaming is not good, but that should be expected!It gets loud under full load. When not using it for gaming or encoding, I set fan mode to quiet and it's super quiet.Overall, it's a good laptop and the con's aren't deal-breakers for me. I would recommend checking out this machine for your next beast!

review.title: Laptop heat ruined the SSD inside
review.review: I’ve had this laptop for a few months, probably around half a year, and its worked pretty great, good fps, decent keyboard and mostly just decent all around HOWEVER it gets incredibly hot. So hot, that it ruined components inside of it and right now i have mine getting repaired. There was absolutely no dust build up, and minimal use (Mainly got it for downtime at work, only time it is used is 2 or 3 times a week for a couple hours) And for the current price which is now up like nearly $800 more than when I got it, its an ABSOLUTE waste of money. When using the laptop for anything other than gaming its relatively okay. But playing even barely graphically demanding games make the back of the laptop get so hot you cant really touch it comfortable. On top of that, the vents on the bottom have AWFUL airflow since the rubber risers on the bottom practically go all the way around it and trap all the hot air inside. The repairman i brought it also said that it barely even has any kind of heatsink in it because of how tightly crammed in all the components are.IF you plan on buying this, make sure you do everything you can to keep it cooled and increase circulation on the bottom, definitely buy the best cooling pad you can as well

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2021
review.title: Less than a year old, and the fan on the left side is going.
review.review: This is actually the SECOND laptop I've gotten of this make. The first one I got had the fan on the right side go out during a gaming session and never turn back on. I had to send it in for warranty repairs and ended up getting a second one. Now the fan on the LEFT side is going. it's making a very very loud rattling, and when in use, the fan will get stuck on something and just stop for seconds at a time before starting again with a loud rattling. I've BABIED this laptop. I just can't recommend Gigabyte laptops at this point. I bought it for the mechanical keyboard, and LOVED that aspect of it, but when I'm 0/2 for cooling that lasts, it's just not worth it.

I'm not sure whether it's my machine alone or if it's an issue with gigabyte itself in their laptops. Everything works except for dual monitor from my tb dock. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: No XMP Support
review.review: You get what you pay for. It's got the latest 11th gen Intel and 30 series Nvidia, so no slouch in 1080/1440 gaming. THUNDERBOLT 4 means you can add some awesome and useful external hubs or EGPUs (you could theoretically just upgrade your graphics card next year instead of buying a whole new PC).My only gripe with this "gamer" laptop is that it doesn't come with XMP support. You can't turn it on and it isn't enabled by default. So any RAM you buy could end up running at a much slower speed than advertised. My 3200 RAM with tight timings ended up with 2666 loose timings due to no XMP. If they had included XMP, this laptop would be perfect within its' current price range ($1600).

The ram is good for gaming, but I will have to upgrade to 32 GB becuase I also develop software.The cons:- AORUS Control Center app is horrible, every time I turn on the computer, it forgets the previous AI mode it was before (Turbo or Gaming or Creator). And also it forgets the mode I leaved my RGB keyboard (static). It's really annoying.- The app doesn't show the current temperature of the CPU and GPU, only the load in percentage.- Camera is in the bottom, so when you are in a videocall, people will see your nostrils.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2021
review.title: Nice Look - Good Performance For Low Wattage
review.review: Note: I bought my laptop for the original $1999 price not the overblown price.First this is a low wattage "low weight" laptop for its class. And the GPU is not based off the desktop RTX 3080 but rather a full GA104 chip which I guess comes from the RTX 3070. Not sure though because Nvidia is not clear on this with the laptop chips. It could be a full RTX 3060 chip. Laptop chip specs here if you want to look: https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/geforce/gaming-laptops/Pros: Strong performing laptop compared to lower end RTX 3070 and RTX 3060 models. Gathering from benchmarks others have done with those models.Other Pros:32GB RAM1TB M.2 SSD (Wish it had 2TB though) -- I did add my own 2TB M.2 SSDIntel 8core/16 Thread CPUNice looking laptopRGB LightingNegatives: Mainly the low wattage which keeps the GPU and CPU from showing their true strengths.Anyway, I really do not have anything to compare this laptop GPU to except my old RTX 2080ti desktop. It doesn't seem to beat it although it is up and down on that front. The low wattage is what keeps this chip down and that is to be expected. But it does have over 6000 CUDA cores so it is beefy in that respect.Do I have buyers remorse? Not really. It does well in gaming at 1080p and 1440p and is not held back by the 8 core Intel chip at all.That being said, I did ramp up as many settings as I could to max out the wattage and power.The laptop comes with the Aorus software to set power to performance and boost the CPU and GPU to max but be wise in your actual needs. The software is a little quirky but after you figure it out it should stay set to where you want it. But don't stop there. Go to the Nvidia control panel in 3D settings and set power management to "prefer maximum performance".Also, I have low latency set to Ultra.And resizable bar should be enabled by default although I have no idea if that is helping anything. Especially since Intel chips were not built with that in mind. Where to check: Nvidia control panel then go up top to help then select system info and it should say enabled.I do have an older GTX 1060 laptop with a 6 core Intel chip and it blows that away on all fronts if that helps any.In conclusion for the price I paid I am happy. If you are still worried about that low wattage performance then check out a "full laptop wattage" RTX 3070 and that should be fine too. But they come with less storage usually.If you want me to do any specific tests before you buy something like this just ask. If I get the email then I will do my best to help.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Almost Perfect
review.review: This is my first Chromebook, and I love almost everything about it.1. The speed is lightening fast2. It is extremely easy to use. I set it up & played around with it for a couple of hours, and learned a ton about the ins & outs of the Chromebook.3. A big 'Yay', on the lack of useless bloatware that is so common on Windows systems.4. The touch screen and mouse pad are both very responsive.5. The screen is crystal clear, and I absolutely LOVE the night time blue light filter. It is so much more pronounced than similar filters on any of my other devices. It really helps with eye strain, and you can use it during the day if you want as well.If I think of any more positives as I use it more, I will add updates.And now, for the one glaring flaw that kept me from giving five stars; The keyboard could be much better, visually. The keys are light, and so are the letters. There is not much contrast at all, so the letters/numbers are really hard to see. Luckily, I've been typing for so long that I can get by. But it'd be much easier if I could see the letters without straining!Since I love everything else about it though, I will happily keep it. I am good about updating my reviews, so if I run into any more pros or cons I will be sure to edit this.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Did not last!
review.review: I bought this, to use on occasion. So in the last several months, I might have used it a dozen times, was great! Nice speed, great screen, brightness was adequate.Then the weirdest thing happened. I started it up, joined a zoom meeting. Within 20 minutes, the screen froze and it stuttered audibly. I closed the lid, it kept stuttering audibly. The back was hot. I tried to do a hard shutdown, kept stuttering. I tried to do a hard shutdown for a longer time, stuttering. Finally I just kept the power button in for 2 minutes and it finally stopped. It took several hours to cool down. Later I started it up again, and it worked fine. I used it for some documents, light web viewing. Was fine for several weeks.Today, I used it for a zoom meeting again. After the meeting was over, a notification said restart for new update. I clicked restart, screen went black. It never came back on. It is been several hours, I open the lid and it won't come on. I press the power button and it won't come on.I'm sitting here with $1,000 dead Chromebook, only a few months old. I would never recommend this Chromebook.
product.title: ASUS Chromebook Flip C436 2-in-1 Laptop, 14" Touchscreen FHD 4-Way NanoEdge, Intel Core i3-10110U, 128GB PCIe SSD, Fingerp...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Best chromebook I've used. Perfect for everyday user
review.review: The laptop is very well built and doesn't feel cheap. Arguably the best chromebook for the price and features on the market. The keyboard is Back lit and the display is good. The 8gb ram gives it fast response and having 64gb of built in storage is very nice. Gives you plenty of storage for your average user. You can always expand storage with SD card or external hard drive. The battery is very good and touch screen is very responsive. The display is bright and vibrant. With consistent use doing web searching and messing around you will get 8 + hours easy. Charging is fast as well. I did alot of comparison shopping and if you are looking for a laptop for everyday use this is an excellent choice. You can download Microsoft Word and excel free from app store and they work very well. It does take a day or two to get use to the chrome o.s. versus using windows. But, that is expected. It lays flat like a tablet would and automatically turns off keyboard when in the tablet position. The touchscreen is just like using a tablet and response is very good. The camera is decent enough for video calls etc. But probably not as good as newer smart phones offer.I came from a windows o.s background and within a few hours I was use to chrome features and navigation. The apps or "programs" are in the task bar which you can be move from bottom left and right side of the screen. At first I was annoyed not being able to move the icons on the home screen as I did with windows machines, but after a while I liked the Taskbar and wasn't bothered at all.To right click you use two fingers at once to click the pad. This threw me off at first. I kept trying to click the right side of the pad with no luck until I looked that up. Just an FYI if you're new to chromebook. But, you get use to that quickly. Overall I'd give it a 9/10. I am fairly tech savvy and needed a laptop for email, web surfing, and other basic needs. This was perfect for me and does everything I need a computer to do fast and efficiently. Enjoy.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2021
review.title: Overall great computer
review.review: I bought this computer for online college courses.. I have had it for almost 2 years and overall it has been a great computer and is still going strong! It’s still as fast as it was the day I took it out of the package and handles every workload I’ve thrown at it with ease. Surprisingly durable.. I can’t count how many times it got dropped or something along those lines & I thought for sure it was broken, but so far it has held up well to all of the accidental abuse over the last couple of years. The only complaint I have is that one of the shift buttons sticks and the screenshot function does not always work properly. Thankfully there are 2 shift buttons and I just use the snipping tool, so those are just minor inconveniences. Overall, I love this computer and would recommend it to anyone.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Almost a perfect laptop for the price held back by buggy included software.
review.review: Great laptop and it fits my needs perfectly, would have been a perfect device if not for the buggy and frustrating included Software.Pros:-Excellent performance from the 3060 with 105W TDP coupled with the octa-core 11800h.-Great thermals with the GPU never exceeding 80C and the processor rarely going above 80C while playing even the most demanding games.-Stunning OLED display.-Sleek design and sturdy build quality (besides the slightly wobbly hinge).Cons:-Very buggy and frustrating to use included control software. My main gripe was that the fan profiles reset every time you plug in or remove the charge and you have to manually set it to what you want every single time. I ultimately ended up giving up on getting it to work properly and switched over to using a 3rd party software.-Battery life is average at best, I get around 6 - 7 hours of battery life doing moderate web browsing and coding after the latest BIOS update which is enough for me to get by but I would have preferred to get a couple of hours more especially considering that this model has a 99kwh battery.-The screen hinge can be a bit to the wobbly side but it doesn't wobble during normal typing so it doesn't bother me too much.In conclusion, I am very satisfied with this laptop but I wish they would improve their software.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review.title: Underwhelming
review.review: Purchasing this laptops is another testament to the fact that good specs don't always amount to a great product. I was deciding between the Gigabyte 17" and a MacBook Pro 16" and finally picked the AERO because of it's impressive screen and graphics card. Needles to say I'm experiencing buyers remorse.The Bad:Horrible webcam/nosecam: I don't know why Gigabyte decided to even include this monstrosity. It's completely useless as it gives everyone in your Zoom meeting a detailed look up your nostrils. The cam is mounted in the body so it's not adjustable unless you raise the entire laptop. In the world of remote work a good, usable webcam is a MUST. Dishing out 2500 bucks and realizing that you still need to by an additional webcam to mount on your screen is a joke. GIGABYTE PLEASE FIX.Charging port: It’s located on the right, middle of the laptop which interferes with your mouse, if you have a tight space and are right-handed. Most coffee shops I go to have tiny tables and given the size of this 17.3” laptop there’s very little room.Battery life: I’m a graphic designer that works in 3D occasionally. When I use Photoshop/Illustrator and Dimension I can’t get more than 1 hour of battery life out of this thing even in power saver mode.Screen changes brightness: Yes, it will go darker or lighter without you touching any settings. Not the end of the world, but annoying.Screen goes black: I’ve used this laptop for a month and so far I’ve had at least 5 instances where the screen goes completely black for a second or two. Gigabyte WTF?Annoying keyboard: I’m used to Macs where to change volume you hit F11 or F12. In this thing you have to hold down the Function key in order to adjust volume, so it becomes a two handed operation. I find this really annoying as volume setting is something that is the most adjusted function and needs to be as intuitive as possible.RGB keyboard: This is a Creator’s laptop not a “gamer” laptop. Having the keyboard pulse like a rainbow on acid is not only distracting but also extremely tasteless. If you want to compete with Macbooks please get rid of this gimmick that appeals to 12 year olds.Now the Good:This thing is fast.The screen is beautiful.The GPU kicks ass. It’s 10 times (10!) faster at rendering 3D than my 13” Macbook pro.It’s relatively slim and not too cheesy looking (minus the RGB keyboard) which fortunately you can turn off.About $2500 cheaper than a similarly spec’d out Mac. Mac’s however have better ergonomics.Ports. Useful, but because of its shortcomings I have to use up one USB port for an external cam and another for a mouse. So it’s a mixed bag.Summary:This laptop is good if you keep it plugged in all the time and use it like a desktop. Hauling it around and working on the go is not a real option as you only have about an hour. Gigabyte needs to put more into their product usability testing.
product.title: GIGABYTE AERO 17 HDR XD - 17.3" UHD 4k IPS Anti-Glare, Intel Core i7, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070 Laptop GPU 8GB GDDR6, 16GB R...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2021
review.title: Self-changing laptop
review.review: I wanted to like this laptop.But, alas, I can't -- the reason?With all the bloatware, trying to set this to operate consistently has been impossible.No matter what I set or how I set it (for example, the type size because I'm visually impaired) the very next time I boot it, it changes to something else.Admittedly, some of that is the insanity of Window 10 but it is surely not limited to that.Every day, I have to spend a half-hour or more tweaking settings back to where I want them.It gets old.Very old.Very quickly.Support for dealing with this problem is nonexistent, I get canned responses from Gigabyte that clearly indicate they aren't even trying to understand much answer the problem.At this price point, that's just not good enough.My other laptop is an MSI -- while they deserve more credit than Gigabyte -- they are hardly stellar either which is why, after buying the MSI, I thought I'd try Gigabyte.Big mistake, should have stuck with the devil I know......Understand that I'm not some gibbering technoignoramus -- with over 45 years of computing experience, I know my way around things PC -- yet this problem simply baffles me.I've never, in my life, had any form of pc that resets itself to whatever settings it wants.I can promise that I will never buy anything Gigabyte ever again.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2021
review.title: Beast Laptop
review.review: I've had this for a couple days now. Only upgrade I did was adding a 2nd NVME (2TB). This laptop cold boots in 7-10 seconds. It can easily do heavy load multitasking (even with the 16GB Ram). I'm not a real gamer, so I cant comment on that. However for Photoshop, Autocad and 4k movie editing this laptop has way more then enough power to handle.The fact that this has 4k HDR display is crazy to me. This display is literally breathtaking. The HDR is "Entry level HDR" so it's not like my TV but to have this on my laptop pictures/videos looks amazing!(1 month update)This laptop after a month is perfect!, I only ran into one issue after installing GEFORCE EXPERIENCE... it causes random BSOD. Unistalling it fixed everything.I did one additional upgrade to 64gb RAM. The 16gb that comes with is probably good enough for the average user.. but I'd recommend atleast upgrading it to 32gb eventually.It is very quite when doing websearching, youtube watching, Autocad or even video/photo editing.When my son used it for minecraft, you can start hearing the fans spin after the laptop starts heating up.... nothing too loud though.(2 Month Update, Final update unless something happens)So after using it for a couple months I realized when using the Laptop on battery once in a while the screen would flash black randomly. This is easily fixed by updating the Intel graphics driver to the newest (As of this review the newest version is: 30.0.100.9805).One more thing for people that have problems with the keyboard settings not staying... update the Gigabyte Control Panel. For me, that fixed it and my keyboard lights up how I selected every startup.Everything else is working great and as expected!I really love this laptop!

review.title: New Laptop CRASHING CONSTANTLY
review.review: Received my laptop from Gigabyte this morning very excited to start getting my Steam games downloaded as this is the most powerful/expensive computer I've ever purchased. Made sure all my drivers were updated, checked to make sure all Windows updates were installed and started downloading games. Not even halfway through downloading my THIRD game I started blue-screening with the error message "WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR".For the uninitiated this error is usually caused by driver issues (not possible as I've already triple checked this), uninstalled Windows updates (also triple checked), or last but not least hardware issues (including but not limited to: RAM mounted incorrectly, failing harddrive, cooling system not operating correctly, etc.)I AM HIGHLY DISAPPOINTED IN GIGABYTE and the fact that I'm now going to have send back my less than one day old laptop to be repaired when these things should be checked before the product is sent.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2021
review.title: Great system and screen but odd keyboard lighting
review.review: The screen is terrific, and the form factor is light enough, esp. for a gaming rig.Two things that I didn't notice from the product pictures that are super-annoying:1) The power connector is on the right *middle* of the unit -- since the adapter has an anti-static bulge about 1-1/2" from the connector, you will have to put up with this unsightly cylinder of black plastic as you work whenever this laptop is plugged in. (You can't access the ports on the right if the power cable is facing frontwards.)2) The RGB per-key lighting is beautiful BUT the secondary characters (i.e., when you hit Shift) like for the lighting, sound and even common characters like ( ) @ # $ % on the number row do not light up -- they are not backlit! The problem (via Reddit) is that the Omron switches -- which have excellent tactile feel and travel -- have center lighting only. All right, but the printed secondary characters are done in a wispy light gray which you absolutely cannot see in the dark. (This is a poor design choice here.) They should be near white -- or at least reflect the light of the keys a bit. I just couldn't use this as a developer at night -- you'll need a separate light on to write / program at night. Of course, if you are a good typist, it doesn't matter for the common characters, but for the lighting, sound and other functions you aren't likely to know them by 'muscle memory.')Otherwise, an excellent laptop, but these are two hands-on gotchas you might not notice till you try this out this system in real life.
product.title: Gigabyte AERO 15 OLED Thin and Light Laptop, 15.6 Thin Bezel UHD AMOLED Panel, i7-9750H, NVIDIA GeForce GTX1660Ti,16GB RA...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: This is a great laptop all around...
review.review: I have had my Gigabyte AERO 15 OLED UHD for a year now. It is awesome. I read about the screen shaking when in use, and this is simply NOT the case.. It is very stable and it looks awesome.. Feels substantial and tough, but light and sleek at the same time.. The processing is superb. The keyboard feels perfect and has a satisfying, very soft 'click' .. It honestly feels perfect.. It looks like I spent $3,000 on it and the image quality is beautiful.. I just stared at the google images for several minutes when I first got it.. The picture quality is like you are looking through a window at the real world.. I'm super happy with it. I did upgrade the Ram to 32 G (2 16G Samsung) just for fun... Didn't feel like I really needed it though.. If you are on the fence and you are really picky about how the picture looks just get it .. You'll be really happy you got it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review.title: A decent set of hardware from a terrible vendor - some design issues
review.review: Overall, my biggest gripe is that the warranty supplied here is borderline fraudulent. I purchased this laptop "Brand New" on January 18th, only to find my 1 year warranty was expired when the laptop's DC port failed after 4 months. I build and fix computers in my spare time, and this laptop has required me to open it up and fix a problem every month since I've owned it (that damn right fan). The laptop additionally was clearly used as there were screws missing from the enclosure and scratch marks on the case. One last issue is that the DC port sits isolated on a flimsy corner of the motherboard, which is capable of freely wiggling until the soldered connections break. Absurd from a usage standpoint.Customer service from Gigabyte is unhelpful here - just return it with amazon and go get a different model. It's frustrating because with a few tweaks, this could be a spectacular computer.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review.title: Terrible Product and Terrible Customer Service
review.review: I purchased the Gigabyte AERO 15 laptop on April 20th, 2020 and had nothing but headaches from the start.Within the first month I had to do a hard factory reset and reinstall all of the software because it kept glitching, restarting, and freezing on me.The 3.5mm audio jack does not work.And just recently the cooling fan began malfunctioning and it sounds like a jet engine on my table every time I have the computer turned on.I am using this for my small videography business and use it extensively for video editing.I had some deadlines I needed to meet so I worked through the noise and I couldn't afford to send my laptop to them for a few weeks for repair.I finally got some free time to reach out to Gigabyte about the issue and they tell me it will cost $120 service fee plus cost of parts/labor for the repair because it is less than 3 weeks out of their 1 year warranty.This is absolutely ridiculous!I work for a manufacturing company and we waive costs on product repairs just out of warranty to keep customers happy and because we stand behind our products.I spoke to two people on the phone and they refused to waive the fees/costs of repair for a faulty product that they sold.It was "company policy" to not budge on the warranty.Apparently there is no one with enough authority at Gigabyte to keep customers happy with their crappy products.I will never buy a Gigabyte product again!UPDATE:The SD card reader scrambled TWO of my memory cards.I lost two projects and had to refund money from my videography business because I lost all of the footage!This computer and company are a POS!I purchased a newer, more powerful MSI laptop from BestBuy.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review.title: Great Laptop
review.review: Can’t say enough about this laptop. I’m running the Aero 15 with RTX 2060, i7 9750, and OLED screen.The screen is about as crisp as you can get and the hardware works great together. After I bought the laptop I read a few negative reviews that got me worried. Some of them spoke about the fans being loud. Yes the fans will ramp up while gaming but it’s not a bad thing if you want cool hardware. I’ve heard no “coil whining” and had no issues with the WiFi. If you have issues with this computer it can most likely be fixed by tweaking the firmware and downloading drivers. If you are not at all tech savvy but still want to buy this computer because of the quality the first thing I would do is take it to a friend or someone that can find all the drivers for you and make all the adjustments needed to get this thing working to it’s potential, because once it’s optimized there’s no stopping it. Everything about this laptop screams “Cool”. From the way it runs, to the looks of the screen, the keyboard, and the logo on the back of the screen. The placement of the camera isn’t an issue if you don’t care about the views from your webcam, which I don’t. As far as gaming goes, I’ve run COD Black Ops Cold War (Multiplayer and Main Story) and No Mans Sky, both of which have worked great. May have to lower the video settings in the game itself to get the FPS up but it’s possible to run games at 70 FPS. Maybe my experience has been better than others but I would definitely recommend this laptop based on what I’ve experienced thus far. Will update the review if that at all changes. Hope this helps.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
review.title: Good laptop after some tweaking
review.review: I got this laptop a few days ago and have tested it for nearly 48h.Some things to consider• Pretty good screen for a laptop. 144hz and good looking out of the box• Laptop frame feels solid but isnt overly heavy.• The 6gb RTX 3060 runs games really well. Division 2 averaged over 120 fps at max settings at 1080p. I tested war thunder, escape from tarkov andmordhau as well and both were extremely smooth (both hit 144hz reliably at ultra 1080p). No noticable input or screen lag in mordhau so fast shooterswill benefit as well.• No noticeable micro stutters when switching from• The laptop top doesn’t feel hot under pressure but I wouldn’t play this on my lap.• I added a 1tb WD Blue NVMe stick to this laptop, its easy to do and there are videos of how to do it.• The GPU runs cool for a laptop (avg 78 under pressure) but the CPU doesn’t. You can fix this by limiting the max power in power settings for the CPU or undervolting it. The cpu has initial spikes in temp but usually ends up in the mid 80s which is a little hot but expected.• Use dragon center to tune the performance. Don’t run extreme performance without cooler boost.• Buy a cooling pad and watch temps for the CPU, the CPU is the only thing that holds this beast back because it tends to hit high temps (95c max from what I saw) if left at max settings.• It has 2x USB3.2and 2x USB-C so you might need to buy an usb dongle. It has a single jack for a headset so you might need to buy a splitter depending on your headset.• One HDMI only. No displayport at all which is something to consider. The HDMI is capable of 4k 60hz but at the end of the day its HDMI. Should be compatible with g sync or g sync supported monitors.
product.title: MSI GF65 Thin 10UE-047 15.6" 144Hz 3ms Gaming Laptop Intel Core i7-10750H RTX3060 16GB 512GB NVMe SSD Win10

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: Almost
review.review: I really had high hopes for this laptop but I found a couple of issues that caused me to return it. First, there was a little bit of backlight bleed on the bottom left side of the screen. While the screen was nice and there was the normal amount of IPS glow, the little white light bleeding through on the bottom left caused me some concern. Although it was not much, it was enough for me to wonder if it would get worse over time. Knowing that there have been some who have complained about screen issues, I did not want to take the chance.Second, the laptop had a few keys that had tactile issues. The #3, #4, and W were not as responsive and springy as the other keys. When I barely moved my fingers across the number row without applying pressure, I could feel that the #3 and #4 keys seemed to be off a little. It worked when typing but I could tell the difference between them and the other keys. The W key was not as bad but you could still feel the difference between it and the Q, E, A, and S. While they may have never caused any issues throughout the life of the laptop, I don't want to take that risk with a $1000+ laptop. I have seen videos and forum posts about this same model where keys are sticking and/or not responding. I did not want to send it to Lenovo for warranty service since I just bought it. Personally, I don't trust a device that has to receive warranty repairs right out of the box. Hopefully, Lenovo can address these issues because this seems like it could be a very great machine.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Too light, cheap plastic, flimsy
review.review: I gave it two stars because specs and performance are both acceptable but that’s where the good ends for me. It’s wordy but here’s the scoop: This 16” 2021 Gram is the cheapest, “plasticky” feeling laptop I’ve ever held. The specs are good, performance is good but there is zero chance of this thing lasting through anything (regardless of that phony“military tested” hogwash they claim) and to make matters even worse, there is, likely a near ZERO chance of LG standing behind it because LG is as bad as it gets when it comes to support (based on 1st hand experience). It is probably called the Gram because it weighs close enough to a gram that they can legally name it that. It feels like a $149 Chromebook. Seriously, it does! If anyone says otherwise, they aren’t being too honest. It may actually BE better than a cheap Chromebook but it surely does NOT feel like it. It feels too light, too flimsy and too cheap, IMO. This is my 2nd Gram and on the first one, the screen strangely snapped like a thin dry twig (think toothpick) and a few years later I thought I’d try LG again and this feels even MORE like a product from Toys R Us than the first one I purchased from LG a couple years back. I sent this new, even flimsier version back like I should have done with the first one and proceeded to pay the extra few bucks for a beautiful, well built, solid aluminum and perfectly weighted Microsoft Surface Laptop 4 and this gem is a keeper! Complete different league of products….period! And not too much more $$ either! What the hell was I thinking? Screw me once, shame on you….etc……Summary: If you are a fan of ridiculously light electronics or you are a fan of well assembled Fisher Price toys, the LG Gram might be a perfect choice. If a solid, premium feeling device is desirable then my recommendation is a definite pass on LG’s Gram! It just feels wrong and over priced! Especially after holding and using a Surface Laptop 4 (which also has a touch screen). The Surface Laptop 4 works, looks AND feels 100% premium and frankly, aside from decent looks and of course performance, how a laptop “feels” is important to me. That is the straight forward scoop folks….from a 30 year computer (IT) professional. P.S. So I don’t seem like a MS fanboy, there ARE other premium feeling laptops, ASUS Zenbook, HP Spectre, some Dell models and a limited few others like MacBooks but MAC OS sucks BUT their hardware is quite premium and, really sets the bar for hardware but MS hit it out of the park here!I’m just comparing with the Surface Laptop 4 because I have one and can fairly compare it with the hapless Gram.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Broken in under 90 days.
review.review: I purchased this in January and in September I went to open up my laptop, hit the power button and the key board lit up and the screen remained blank. The cpu wasn't even making any noises. I called acer who had me trouble shoot it by pressing F2 and selecting a few options and that brought windows back up. About 4 days later I went to open it up and the same problem occurred. I called acer who told me to send it in, which cost me 50 dollars via UPS and took over 2 weeks to be returned. On the repair report, acer claimed I was unwilling to trouble shoot the problem which is a lie. They replaced the SSD and did a systems check and sent it back to me. It worked fine for 2 days then, to my dismay, it had the same problem, key board lit up, no display or computer fans running. I called acer to ask for a refund but they told me to ask Amazon for a refund. Amazon would only refund me 80% because it was past the 90 day return policy. Absolutely trash laptop, customer service and over all experience. Purchase something else!

review.title: not as ompressed as I thought I would be
review.review: Overall for the price it would be hard to find a better laptop deal out there for more than twice the price!!!!It looks and feels more like a new unit than a refurbish.most of my grief was windows setup. It refused to accept or sendconfirmation text to a for sure working phone numbers and at last did so with a text to an email account.Even then it called that email account "un verified"and forced me to enter a 4 digit code to access windows.Not exactly secure tohave an easily hacked 4 number code be my access code to windows but I had no choice.This version of win-10 want to do things for me that more or less let it track and trace location contacts and history.Be careful what questions you do not change from yes to no on setup.I made the huge mistake of selecting "switch to win-11"...My god its worse than win-10 even fighting me if I want to switch browsers away from IE.Lots of hinks with win-11.Dont rush to try it on a new computer!!!!!AS for the computer.... once you get out of the new "S-mode"you can loose IE explorer and load a better browser and programs "s=mode" fights you about.The backlit keyboard is nice.Mouse is OK for limited use but for real work its to jittery ... As a video player it works well on its 15 inch screen or external monitor.Since I:m not really sure what its up to on line I set it up with a LAN I can switch off thus cutting it off from the web.A good idea with any computer that thinks to much!!!!Overall for the price it would be hard to find a better laptop deal out there for more than twice the price!!!!It looks and feels more like a new unit than a refurbish.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Able laptop, but limited.
review.review: A good working computer for the price, but it has limitations.The laptop works okay with the Celeron 1 GHz processor and 4 GB RAM as long as it is in Windows “S Mode”, however that means the user is limited to the applications in the “Windows Store”.The “S Mode” operating system runs more efficiently and securely than the full version of Windows 10.If the user needs a “non-Windows Store” application, one must permanently leave “S Mode” via “Settings/Update/Activation/Switch/Store”.The switch is taxing on both the processor and memory as the L210 laptop has the minimum specs necessary.Lastly, this laptop was advertised as having 1 year of MS Office installed. That was found to be untrue.
product.title: ASUS Laptop L210 Ultra Thin Laptop, 11.6” HD Display, Intel Celeron N4020 Processor, 4GB RAM, 64GB Storage, NumberPad, Win...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Decent, limited, bargain laptop
review.review: This is a decent, but limited, laptop. 64GB is just enough to run Windows OS and Microsoft Office. Remember, also, this is EMMC memory and not a true SSD. I got a 256GB SD and formatted it to NSFT so I could put my OneDrive on it. If you want to install anything other than Windows and MSOffice, I recommend looking for programs you and install on the non-system drive. That limits your choices.Battery life is good. I was asked to review the touch screen. Mine doesn't have one.Still, I can edit simple documents, do my email, and browse the web, maybe read a Kindle book or two, all for +/- $200 and 2 lbs. to carry around.If you want a fully functional laptop, you'll need to look in the $500 range or take a chance on a refurbished one, if you want to spend less.
product.title: ASUS Laptop L210 Ultra Thin Laptop, 11.6” HD Display, Intel Celeron N4020 Processor, 4GB RAM, 64GB Storage, NumberPad, Win...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Great Ubuntu Ultrabook
review.review: I love this laptop.I got it for Windows but I wanted to see the performance of Ubuntu 20.04.I am much happier with Ubuntu.Things that don't work after initial install with Ubuntu 20.04 LTS:WIFI, Asus Touchpad (numberpad).The Additional Drivers did not add the correct working driver, but both drivers/utilities were easy to find with a little searching so I have everything working so far.I needed a temp USB network card to download and install the WIFI drivers.Battery is amazing and suspend works with fresh install of 20.04I give this a 5 star because I am comparing this with other laptops in that price point.I am blown away at what a capable little Linux development box, I have been running PHPStorm and Docker.Feather light laptop with silent running.I don't gameso I can't really speak to that but for 228, I wouldn't expect too much.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Excellent secondary or beginner gaming computer.
review.review: I bought the Acer Nitro 5 with the i5 10300H CPU and the RTX 3050. I upgraded to 16 GB of RAM and added a 1 TB internal SSD and the review is based on the computer after the upgrades.Pros:-The visual fidelity is outstanding. Games like Battlefield 4 and 5 run perfectly and look amazing. Forza -Horizon 4 runs amazing at high FPS around 80 to 90 on high settings.-The Windows home screen and Cortana work great since it has a built in mic and designated buttons on the keyboard. Much better usage than on a PC.-It is very lightweight and portable.-Screen has soft colors but is very crisp.-Boot times are very fast.Cons-The battery life is atrocious but who isn't gaming without plugging in first? Watching Youtube only the battery lasted unplugged around 3 hours.-The laptop gets pretty warm and the fans are loud almost instantly loading into a game. This is not a huge issue for anyone wearing headphones.-The layout of the keyboard is very tight and you will click the wrong keys at some point. Also the touchpad is in a very strange position offset to the left so you'll want to disable it and use a mouse.Overall, this is a fantastic laptop for anyone getting into gaming computing. I own a PC with a 2080ti and even still am impressed by this little computer. The budgeting option to spend $168 a month for 5 months was a no brainer to me. If you are going to buy a laptop for any reason, might as well get a gaming one like this!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Very good for the price :)
review.review: This is my first laptop after a decade and I am very happy to purchase this one. So many good words about Nitro 5s, even this one is not one of the better ones, I added another 8Gb ram and 2 TB 2.5 SSD to make it bit more usable. Not that anything wrong with 8Gb ram and 256Gb SSD but 8Gb rams are not that expensive at all these days.. I had 2TB SSD from my big computer, just switched it over. Talking about upgrading the laptop, it's so easy. Comes with everything you need to add another 2.5 SSD. YouTube videos helped me out though, made my job a lot easier. This computer does play FPS games, and plays them very smooth. The fans start running though, and you might think it's overheating, that's not the case, it's normal. They don't go full speed. I also play mobile games and stream through laptop... no heating no fan issues at all... it's like so smooth and easy for the machine. For this price, I highly recommend it, if you are in a tight budged like I am. One more thing for this laptop, I am going to travel Europe next year, and it won't be problem bringing it with me, since it is travel friendly :)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Problematic wi-fi
review.review: If it weren't for the wi-fi problems, I'd readily give this a 5. It's solidly constructed, with a comfortable keyboard, good screen, feels fast despite not being high-spec. But increasingly in the last few weeks, it's had trouble holding a wi-fi connection, even when just a few feet away from the router. Doesn't matter whether it's at home or elsewhere, the same issue happens: at least a couple times an hour, it'll stop seeing the router and become completely disconnected. It takes anywhere from 30 seconds to a few minutes to see the router again and reconnect. It's not a heat issue -- this thing never gets hot -- and it's not a line of sight problem or anything like that. Moving it to another place doesn't help it see the connection again.Pretty disappointing. The first HP Chromebook I had back in 2015 was one of the most reliable laptops I've owned, so was hoping to find the same kind of quality here.
product.title: HP Chromebook 14-inch HD Laptop, Intel Celeron N4000, 4 GB RAM, 32 GB eMMC, Chrome (14a-na0020nr, Ceramic White)

They seem to be tied together in the circuitry and I don't know what is causing them to fail or work together.I'm considering getting a replacement, but at the same time, I might just end up with an even worse one. The manufacturing standards seem to be quite low.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2021
review.title: Almost excellent laptop.
review.review: Been playing around with the 16 inch version for several weeks now. build-wise I am very pleased. The screen doesn't wobble too much and the keyboard is just lovely to use. I will say there's one potential issue, where if you put enough weight/pressure on the space left or right of the touch pad, you can get it to register as a click, but in practical use it never happened. Something to watch out for if you have massive sausage arms that lay flat on the laptop, maybe. That aside, I REALLY like the trackpad. It's been like a decade since I used a laptop pad so I was assuming a mouse would be a mandatory purchase, but not anymore. The multi-touch controls work great, and it's nice and big so I never feel like my fingers are gravitating too far into a corner to browse properly.On the software side of things I am impressed with the SSD and operating system. Once you got your user settings entered the first time around, the computer can go from the powered-off state to your home screen in like fifteen seconds. I haven't extensively tested the CPU, though I've found it can run Overwatch at low settings and 60fps with only minimal tinkering.I primarily use it for writing and the occasional google research/time waster, which it handles with ease, and I'm sure it could stream a Spotify setlise or play iTunes on top of that as well. It also didn't seem like a big deal at first, but the fingerprint scanner is so nifty to have, I have actually become spoiled on it and feel irritated when I have to type my password out on the desktop.There are some "bloatware" applications pre-installed that you could do without, such as McCaffee, but mostly the applications seem fine. There's the LG Virtoo app that can sync to an LG phone, which I also happen to have. Testing it...I mean, it works, you can send/receive calls through the laptop and copy over any photos you've taken, but the bluetooth connectivity would kill your phone battery with any extensive use, and the sound/mic quality on the Gram is not professional by any means. Far more useful is the simple control panel that has your power features, screen brightness and fan options at just a click away. There's also an LG-branded video editor, though given the Gram's low voltage and integrated graphics, I doubt you'd want to compile any 4k footage on this laptop.There's only a handful of nitpicks bring it down to a 4/5. Main thing is, for whatever reason, I can't get it to save separate power usage/brightness settings depending on whether it's plugged in or not. This is quickly fixed by clicking the battery on the taskbar and using the hotkeys to change the screen's brightness, but it is irksome to do it EVERY single time. Secondly, if you use the Gram at a less than full charge while charging, the charger brick gets surprisingly warm. I'd say it's hot, even. Lastly, the screen is really glossy. As a cave-dwelling hermit this doesn't affect me, but I can imagine using this in an outdoor setting or coffee shop with a bunch of overhead lamps might not be the best experience.Can I recommend this absurdly expensive laptop to everyone? Well, no. It fits my niche of needing a super lightweight quiet writing device with a decent screen size, easily capable of some research googles or wasting time with very light gaming sessions. In this regard I am super satisfied. If you need something for gaming, media production or media consumption, there are cheaper, better options available.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2021
review.title: Working well
review.review: Mice are like shoes, so it's difficult to say what works well for everyone. I use a mouse 14+ h/day for long days at work and then what time I can have saving the universe. I've owned about every brand, both wired and wireless. My latest venture with the SteelSeries was based off a YT vid review that just happened to play. I'd been using a Razer Viper Mini for the past year and while it was a good mouse, it's just a bit too mini for me (average size hands).I've been pleased so far with this mouse. The weight is lighter than most, which I've increasingly grown to appreciate. I don't care much for wireless mice, so this wired one was my preference. The cable is ok - no kinks and with my setup, no drag/pull as I'm moving around. I already had a SteelSeries keyboard, so the software worked without issue picking up the mouse and adjusting settings. I've never had issue with SteelSeries software before, so that's been a non-issue as well.The mouse feels pretty good and has no plastic stuck on the sides like some of SteelSeries other mice. Those glued on pieces are nothing short of a mess over time as they goop out and get on your desk/hands/mouse. This mouse is all solid and is comfortable for long usage times. Clickers work well andthe wheel was surprisingly better than I feared - not exactly smoot, not horribly bumpy.Overall, I like this mouse and for the money, feel like I got a good product for the cost. I generally go through mice every 1 to 3 years, depending on how they hold up. I'm hoping this holds up to the task.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Aerox 3 Wireless - Super Light Gaming Mouse - 18,000 CPI TrueMove Air Optical Sensor - Ultra-li...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Rival 5 Gaming Mouse with PrismSync RGB Lighting and 9 Programmable Buttons – FPS, MOBA, MMO, B...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Unacceptable Battery Life
review.review: I would have thought battery life would be great considering how quickly the mouse goes to sleep, but what would otherwise be a solid mouse for the price is ruined by terrible battery life. I am having to replace the AAAs in my mouse what feels like every 1-2 weeks.There is a power saving setting in the Steelseries software, but it is locked at 150hz polling rate which makes even browsing the web clunky and unresponsive. I especially notice it in the scroll wheel, which feels like it drops roughly every other click.I would recommend this mouse only if you have a battery charging station within reach of your desk and can live with the inconvenience. I will be replacing mine with a Logitech G305, and I guess this will be a fine emergency backup as it is past the return period.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.

Since I could not install the SteelSeries software on my work computer, I was stuck with the distracting rainbow pattern.SteelSeries support was less than helpful and claimed the mouse should have onboard memory.Once I proved the Rival 5 was not working from onboard memory to maintain illumination settings, SteelSeries support stopped responding.I sent this mouse back to Amazon after noticing the computer would lose connection with the mouse multiple times a day.

review.title: you get exactly what you think you are
review.review: lightweight, yes.LED functionality, yes.change the colors, yes.USB-A to USB-C connection, yes.Steel Series gaming program functionality, yes.adjust the DPI, yes.in usual Steel Series fashion, you get a mouse that does what it says it will, lets you have colors that can breathe or stay solid in zones, and with adjustable sensitivity.i still find Steel Series to be a better deal than RAZR products and since my laptop automatically comes with a Steel Series keyboard, my devices can be synced together.i went with the wired because not only is it cheaper, i have a tendency to lose the mouse when it's wireless.this cable does disconnect from the mouse when you're transporting it.I'll likely leave it on otherwise because it's easier to keep track of. at $35, pretty happy.my only concern would be for the future.because if the design to make it lightweight by cutting out a geometric pattern, the inner circuitry is visible.it says water resistant which i'm guessing also applies to sweat resistant.i'm not a heavy hand sweater, but to anyone that is, i could see this being a problem in the future.i haven't had it long enough to determine for sure how much of a problem it would be.
