review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.

review.title: Do not use with a KVM Switch
review.review: I purchased this mouse to replace a Corsair gaming mouse I use both for my personal gaming computer and my work 3D modeling computer using a KVM switch.I quickly found the mouse does not save settings natively.After experimenting with 3 computers I found the mouse powers up with a extremely bright Rainbow light pattern, then polls the SteelSeries software installed on the computer for the correct settings. Since I could not install the SteelSeries software on my work computer, I was stuck with the distracting rainbow pattern.SteelSeries support was less than helpful and claimed the mouse should have onboard memory.Once I proved the Rival 5 was not working from onboard memory to maintain illumination settings, SteelSeries support stopped responding.I sent this mouse back to Amazon after noticing the computer would lose connection with the mouse multiple times a day.

review.title: Decent sound quality... Headband snapped. Cheap plastic.
review.review: The x800 or H wireless was a decent headset for wireless comfortably and sound. It wasn't good for footsteps, but for gunshots, hearing vehicles, etc. it was decent.I liked the swappable batteries and it made it easy to play on and on. But the fact of the matter is, this a cheaply made headset. I expect more out of a $200-300 headset.The headband snappedon the inner part of the band on the right ear cup side. Its entirely made out of plastic. Steelseries has terrible customer service and my warranty has expired. So I'm out $220-250 or whatever I spent on it a while back. For any headset over $200, I expect it to last at least 2 years. Very frustrated with SteelSeries. Shouldn't be that much for a cheaply made product.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2018
review.title: Works great, but not all the time.
review.review: So.. it's not a bad product.It works, but you will hear a constant "white noise" in the background of your games when it's silent.Not sure if this happens on all high-end headsets, but it was disappointing.While playing games, the sound from the game usually drowns out the white noise.Another issue I had was the headset causing my controller to randomly reset.I would be playing a game and my controller would just shut off. I use the Xbox elite controller, and have never had this issue until using this headset.I think it has something to do with the proprietary adapter that they use.Without the adapter, the controller never has the issue and the headset works fine..Recently, I was using my headset and it suddenly stopped working with the Xbox chat.I checked the cords, reset the receiver and did several other resets to it as well.Finally after setting the receiver back to factory defaults, I was able to get it working again.The product support on their website is very slow as well.They only email you, and it takes about 24 hours to hear back from them for each reply.That being said, they did offer to send me a new cord for my headset.. though I'd imagine that was not the cause of my issue..Overall, I've probably dumped at least 200-300 hours into this headset, the multiple batteries are very nice and the sound is great.Aside from the occasional bugs, it's not a bad headset.
product.title: SteelSeries Siberia X800 Wireless Gaming Headset with Dolby 7.1 Surround Sound for Xbox One, Xbox 360

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split ...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Unacceptable Battery Life
review.review: I would have thought battery life would be great considering how quickly the mouse goes to sleep, but what would otherwise be a solid mouse for the price is ruined by terrible battery life. I am having to replace the AAAs in my mouse what feels like every 1-2 weeks.There is a power saving setting in the Steelseries software, but it is locked at 150hz polling rate which makes even browsing the web clunky and unresponsive. I especially notice it in the scroll wheel, which feels like it drops roughly every other click.I would recommend this mouse only if you have a battery charging station within reach of your desk and can live with the inconvenience. I will be replacing mine with a Logitech G305, and I guess this will be a fine emergency backup as it is past the return period.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.

review.title: Best Mid-grade optical gaming mouse
review.review: Sometimes you don't want a mouse with a bazillion buttons. You want it for work and gaming without spending a stupid amount of money. Enter the Steelseries Prime FPS gaming mouse....not too fancy, built well and is a real delight to use. Sturdy, rugged and accurate for gaming. This mouse is a great buy for the money and proves you don't need to spend $ hundreds on a mouse with 42 buttons. If you like your mice, simple and sturdy/well built, this is the mouse for you. I replaced my razer mouse because it was starting to double-click in gaming.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Prime Wireless FPS Gaming Mouse with Magnetic Optical Switches and 5 Programmable Buttons – US...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2021
review.title: Working well
review.review: Mice are like shoes, so it's difficult to say what works well for everyone. I use a mouse 14+ h/day for long days at work and then what time I can have saving the universe. I've owned about every brand, both wired and wireless. My latest venture with the SteelSeries was based off a YT vid review that just happened to play. I'd been using a Razer Viper Mini for the past year and while it was a good mouse, it's just a bit too mini for me (average size hands).I've been pleased so far with this mouse. The weight is lighter than most, which I've increasingly grown to appreciate. I don't care much for wireless mice, so this wired one was my preference. The cable is ok - no kinks and with my setup, no drag/pull as I'm moving around. I already had a SteelSeries keyboard, so the software worked without issue picking up the mouse and adjusting settings. I've never had issue with SteelSeries software before, so that's been a non-issue as well.The mouse feels pretty good and has no plastic stuck on the sides like some of SteelSeries other mice. Those glued on pieces are nothing short of a mess over time as they goop out and get on your desk/hands/mouse. This mouse is all solid and is comfortable for long usage times. Clickers work well andthe wheel was surprisingly better than I feared - not exactly smoot, not horribly bumpy.Overall, I like this mouse and for the money, feel like I got a good product for the cost. I generally go through mice every 1 to 3 years, depending on how they hold up. I'm hoping this holds up to the task.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Prime Wireless FPS Gaming Mouse with Magnetic Optical Switches and 5 Programmable Buttons – US...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split ...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Unacceptable Battery Life
review.review: I would have thought battery life would be great considering how quickly the mouse goes to sleep, but what would otherwise be a solid mouse for the price is ruined by terrible battery life. I am having to replace the AAAs in my mouse what feels like every 1-2 weeks.There is a power saving setting in the Steelseries software, but it is locked at 150hz polling rate which makes even browsing the web clunky and unresponsive. I especially notice it in the scroll wheel, which feels like it drops roughly every other click.I would recommend this mouse only if you have a battery charging station within reach of your desk and can live with the inconvenience. I will be replacing mine with a Logitech G305, and I guess this will be a fine emergency backup as it is past the return period.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.

review.title: Great Replacements!
review.review: I found that the visibility of my keys on my Razer Huntsmen was lacking so I shopped around to find the perfect keycap replacements. I found them. The keys are feel great, and look great. This was my first time replacing keycaps, and although it took awhile (I did some cleaning too), it wasn't really that hard to put it together. SteelSeries did a great job of making these keycaps useable for quite a few RGB gaming keyboards.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries PRISMCAPS - Double Shot Pudding-Style Keycaps - Durable PBT Thermoplastic - Compatible with a W...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review.title: Great Looking Keycaps With Added Peace of Mind
review.review: I bought these for my Corsair K70 Mk. 2 SE because I wasn't completely satisfied with the amount of light coming through the stock keycaps. These pudding style keys allow the RGB lighting to come through much brighter than the stock ones and make the lighting effects more impactful, especially those effects which utilize many colors.The main reason I went with the SteelSeries caps as opposed to other pudding-style caps is the inclusion of multiple sets of bottom row keys in this set. Some keyboards (like my Corsair unit) come with different sized bottom row keys, which are not compatible with all sets of keycaps. While this set of keycaps may cost a bit more than other sets out there, the inclusion of multiple sets of bottom keys gives some peace of mind that this set will fit your particular keyboard.Additionally, I like the feel of these keycaps better than the stock ones that ship with the Corsair K70 and I don't think that these get marked up as much from general use.Overall, these SteelSeries Pudding Keycaps are a welcome upgrade to my set up and the added assurance that this set gives by including multiple sizes of bottom row shouldn't be dismissed.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries PRISMCAPS - Double Shot Pudding-Style Keycaps - Durable PBT Thermoplastic - Compatible with a W...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: Coarse keycaps surface, uneven height
review.review: After I got this product I was excited to put this keycaps on my current apex 7 TKL. Although the installation was easy and the lighting effect does look great on this keycap, there are some issues that really bring down the whole experience for this product.I notice the height of keycaps H, L, and 8 are slight taller than the rest the keycaps, and it feels weird whenever I have to press those keycaps. I don't know if Steelseries made those keycaps taller on purpose, or it could be some quality control issues.The factory Apex 7 TKL's keycapshave a really smooth surface without a grainy feeling, and I like it. So I assume they would make the same texture with their PBT pudding keycaps. However, their PBT pudding keycaps is way more "coarse" that it would make your fingers feel uncomfortable touching the keycaps.I won't be returning this one, but hopefully Steelseries would listen to customer's feedback and make some adjustment to their product.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2021
review.title: Almost perfect
review.review: These keys are great; non-standard keyboard owners rejoice! They were a little more expensive than the Hyper X pudding caps, but the font is better and there are included keys for standard and non-standard bottom rows. The feel is really nice, the home (F and J) keys have the raised bits, and the illumination factor is UNREAL. A picture can't really do justice to the diffusing factor in the white, bottom part of the keys - and yes, these keys still get plenty bright. The finish on the tops have a nice, slightly textured surface so your fingers don't slide. Nitpicking, if you look really closely, you can see a few dim spots in the traces (like the 8's and 0's), and the finish on the outside of the keys isn't perfect. For instance, on the space bar key there are some very small raised bumps on the top anterior of the black portion. These could probably be sanded off, and are most likely a product of how the black and white parts of the keys are molded. Overall, really nice, would buy again. Installed on a Corsair K70 (pictured).

review.review_data: Reviewed in Italy on October 13, 2021
review.title: Solido
review.review: Ho provato tanti mouse in vita mia sia sul lavoro che a casa e spesso ho avuto a che fare con prodotti "leggerini" ma non tanto per il poco peso quanto per la qualità dei materiali: plastichine sottili e fragili. Questo nonostante il prezzo economico (se teniamo conto che è nato per il gaming è uno dei più economici in circolazione) mi ha stupito. La costruzione è solidissima seppur di peso molto contenuto. Precisione e maneggevolezza ottimi. Non sono un gamer ma mi piaceva l'idea di avere anche un po' di colore sulla mia scrivania, così ho scelto questo e per ora ha superato le mie più rosee aspettative di qualità. Poi se uno ha volgia si può sbizzarrire scaricando il suo software che modifica colori e giochi di luce, assegna comandi diversi ai pulsanti, controlla la velocità del puntatore ecc....ecc...fra l'altro tutto in lingua italiana...Consiglio l'acquisto non solo ai giocatori di video games....

review.title: CPI/DPI not true fully customizable
review.review: I had to return the item because there is no full customization of the CPI. The software will only allow you to customize in increments of 250. So if you needed a DPI/CPI of 800 (like myself) this mouse will not work for you. Or you can just raise the CPI to 1000 and get used to it. I chose to return the item as it did not state this information in the listing. Otherwise this mouse is great.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
review.title: Really enjoying this mouse!
review.review: So I bought this item i think a month from today and have constantly used it since, and I'm really happy i bought it. I'm a big guy with a wide hand and I like how this mouse just fits perfectly when i use it. I previously used another gaming mouse but never really paid attention to its size until i felt some unease whenever i would use it, and so that's when i decided to look for a much bigger mouse.. I'll say one thing about this item that I would like to address to those who are seeking for a large size mouse, this is the item you probably would like to get. I mean this mouse is longer, a bit more wider and the depth i would say is just fitting for its built. My hand is able to cover the whole mouse giving me a much, much better grasp and hold when use it. Compared to my previous mouse, my fingers would have to sorta adjust to its size and it's just uncomfortable and strains my hand muscles..So, if you're looking for a big mouse to give you a better feel, this is the mouse to go for. Also, as I didn't mention anything about its mechanics and functions, that's because I have no problem with it whatsoever. Everything works as its suppose to. Overall really good and satisfying product for me.. :)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Super comfortable, great sound quality, relatively easy to set up.
review.review: I'm so glad I decided to just shell out the extra money for a good headset. Steelseries engine has preset equalizers. one is Flat, one is Voice, they sound like shit, as expected. but man, when you set the equalizer to Music? shiiiiiiiiiiit. these things sound incredible when you have some spotify blasting. just out of the box they sound good. but downloading the engine and trying different presets is nice.they're also super comfortable. the velcro makes it weird trying to find the right fit but it only takes 2 minutes of fidgeting around to find it. if that. the earpads are crazy soft and squishy, they feel great. I wear glasses too. no problem. they might feel weird at first, you just have to find the right fit with the velcro. they sit on your head and around your ears so seamlessly.the mic is basically what you would expect from a headset. it doesn't sound incredible but it's good for what you pay for. it's better than most i've heard.has a volume scroll wheel on the left ear to raise or lower your volume. very nice.its great,buy it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Mediocre pricey headset
review.review: I picked these up to replace a broken pair of Turtle beach Stealth 520s.The 520s were cheap <$100 and did the job as intended.Honestly I would prefer to go back with them,and not this Artis 7 headset.My biggest gripe is that I cannot use the headset to control Chat and Audio separately,You need to use the PlayStation console to do this,and its annoying as Heck!That feature alone makes the cheaper Turtle beach headset dominate these things.Another point of contention is how long you need to push the power button down to turn them on..Literally 4 Mississippi's before they beep and power up.The instructions say that you need to hold the power button down for 5 seconds to pair it,beware.... it has gone into that mode rather then turn on a few times.Sound quality is passable but not exceptional or worth noting and at this price point its disappointing.Positives..They fit better then the Stealth 520sbut are actually abit heavier,will need to see how they sit on the long term.Battery life so far is good on par with my old set,microphone is overly complicated and cannot be removed from the headset.Not a big deal,but worth noting.Summary...Mediocre pricey headset..They do nothing outstanding,and controlling audio is super annoying with these.Sound quality is good but not great,Noise cancelling is non existent.I use for gaming,would not recommend these for any audiophiles.Wired headsets on the cheap end perform better.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Arctis Prime - Competitive Gaming Headset - High Fidelity Audio Drivers - Multiplatform Compati...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2019
review.title: Scroll Wheel problem after less than 1 year
review.review: This mouse is fairly comfortable and performed well when it was purchased.I liked the DPI settings.The buttons on the left side got in the way sometimes, but I learned to hold the mouse a specific way to avoid accidentally clicking them all the time.I am leaving a 1 star review because after less than 1 year the scroll wheel is essentially unusable, jumping up or down randomly when I try to scroll.I did a search to see if this is a common problem, and other users suggested blowing into the scroll wheel area.I tried that, and found it provided a functional scroll capability for 10 or 15 seconds.Due to the problem with the scroll wheel I am buying another mouse, and probably a different brand.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review.title: Best wireless gaming mouse.
review.review: By far the best wireless gaming mouse I've used.It's light weight, feels great in my hands, performs exceptionally wirelessly, has a long battery life, has some cool looking RGB, and doesn't have a bad looking logo on it.The only thing that would make this mouse better is if it supported wireless charging, but given how long the battery life is, plugging it over night isn't that big of a deal.The included cable definitely is super flexible, but it looks a bit weird if you're into the aesthetics of your cables.I ended up getting a much shorter braided cable anyway.The charging port is so recessed into the mouse that it makes using magnetic cables not really an option either.I like how the profile switching button is on the bottom too.I've never needed to switch profiles on the fly like that so I like it being out of the way.The software is fine for my needs.I did disable the RGB mainly because they don't have a reactive RGB setting (turns on when you click), which is my preference.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Super comfortable, great sound quality, relatively easy to set up.
review.review: I'm so glad I decided to just shell out the extra money for a good headset. Steelseries engine has preset equalizers. one is Flat, one is Voice, they sound like shit, as expected. but man, when you set the equalizer to Music? shiiiiiiiiiiit. these things sound incredible when you have some spotify blasting. just out of the box they sound good. but downloading the engine and trying different presets is nice.they're also super comfortable. the velcro makes it weird trying to find the right fit but it only takes 2 minutes of fidgeting around to find it. if that. the earpads are crazy soft and squishy, they feel great. I wear glasses too. no problem. they might feel weird at first, you just have to find the right fit with the velcro. they sit on your head and around your ears so seamlessly.the mic is basically what you would expect from a headset. it doesn't sound incredible but it's good for what you pay for. it's better than most i've heard.has a volume scroll wheel on the left ear to raise or lower your volume. very nice.its great,buy it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Mediocre pricey headset
review.review: I picked these up to replace a broken pair of Turtle beach Stealth 520s.The 520s were cheap <$100 and did the job as intended.Honestly I would prefer to go back with them,and not this Artis 7 headset.My biggest gripe is that I cannot use the headset to control Chat and Audio separately,You need to use the PlayStation console to do this,and its annoying as Heck!That feature alone makes the cheaper Turtle beach headset dominate these things.Another point of contention is how long you need to push the power button down to turn them on..Literally 4 Mississippi's before they beep and power up.The instructions say that you need to hold the power button down for 5 seconds to pair it,beware.... it has gone into that mode rather then turn on a few times.Sound quality is passable but not exceptional or worth noting and at this price point its disappointing.Positives..They fit better then the Stealth 520sbut are actually abit heavier,will need to see how they sit on the long term.Battery life so far is good on par with my old set,microphone is overly complicated and cannot be removed from the headset.Not a big deal,but worth noting.Summary...Mediocre pricey headset..They do nothing outstanding,and controlling audio is super annoying with these.Sound quality is good but not great,Noise cancelling is non existent.I use for gaming,would not recommend these for any audiophiles.Wired headsets on the cheap end perform better.

review.review: I had multiple friends who use this headset recommend it to me. Seeing it was on sale I said why not. I almost instantly regretted this decision the moment I started using them. Even on sale, the audio qaulity is so bad, that it has given me a headache within minutes of use. All of the audio sounds like you're holding a metal pipe up to each ear. With no dedicated driver to download, and no program to balance the settings, this issue is just not possible to solve without just getting a different set entirely.Saying I was disappointed is an understatement. For something this expensive, I would expect something that sounds clear and crisp. But what I got was something that makes everything sound worse. Like its on a radio, or in a tunnel.If you are expecting High quality audio, get something else. If you don't care about quality, then I guess these work fine otherwise.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2021
review.title: Best headset for my money
review.review: To preface this review I should say that I have a fairly large cranium, so if you have a smaller head it might not fit as snuggly/ well. I had this headset for 3+ years and just recently ordered another one (the old one isn’t broken it’s just kinda gross from so much use - around 3+ hours a day)This headset has amazing sound localization, the frame and cord are both super durable, and comfort is superb from my experience. They don’t stay quite as cool around the ears as the Hyper X Cloud II, but I can wear them for hours without any heat discomfort. The way the frame works/adjusts around the head let’s it fit snuggly without putting too much pressure which is great for comfort. That also means that it doesn’t give as bad of headphone hairdo (though it still leaves a minor impression on the hair). If you are on PlayStation or PC you can connect it to your system through the USB which adds the nice option of being able to mute your mic and adjust the volume of yourself and of your game. When I play on Xbox I just connect the headphone jack directly to my controller through a headset adapter (which is no longer in production from Microsoft, but it is great and gives the option to mute)As far as mic quality, it’s pretty great, voice goes through nice and crisp and the noise gate on the mic is really effective at preventing unwanted sounds (AC, breathing, etc.) from being picked up.One of the best headsets I’ve ever had.

review.title: Super comfortable, great sound quality, relatively easy to set up.
review.review: I'm so glad I decided to just shell out the extra money for a good headset. Steelseries engine has preset equalizers. one is Flat, one is Voice, they sound like shit, as expected. but man, when you set the equalizer to Music? shiiiiiiiiiiit. these things sound incredible when you have some spotify blasting. just out of the box they sound good. but downloading the engine and trying different presets is nice.they're also super comfortable. the velcro makes it weird trying to find the right fit but it only takes 2 minutes of fidgeting around to find it. if that. the earpads are crazy soft and squishy, they feel great. I wear glasses too. no problem. they might feel weird at first, you just have to find the right fit with the velcro. they sit on your head and around your ears so seamlessly.the mic is basically what you would expect from a headset. it doesn't sound incredible but it's good for what you pay for. it's better than most i've heard.has a volume scroll wheel on the left ear to raise or lower your volume. very nice.its great,buy it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Mediocre pricey headset
review.review: I picked these up to replace a broken pair of Turtle beach Stealth 520s.The 520s were cheap <$100 and did the job as intended.Honestly I would prefer to go back with them,and not this Artis 7 headset.My biggest gripe is that I cannot use the headset to control Chat and Audio separately,You need to use the PlayStation console to do this,and its annoying as Heck!That feature alone makes the cheaper Turtle beach headset dominate these things.Another point of contention is how long you need to push the power button down to turn them on..Literally 4 Mississippi's before they beep and power up.The instructions say that you need to hold the power button down for 5 seconds to pair it,beware.... it has gone into that mode rather then turn on a few times.Sound quality is passable but not exceptional or worth noting and at this price point its disappointing.Positives..They fit better then the Stealth 520sbut are actually abit heavier,will need to see how they sit on the long term.Battery life so far is good on par with my old set,microphone is overly complicated and cannot be removed from the headset.Not a big deal,but worth noting.Summary...Mediocre pricey headset..They do nothing outstanding,and controlling audio is super annoying with these.Sound quality is good but not great,Noise cancelling is non existent.I use for gaming,would not recommend these for any audiophiles.Wired headsets on the cheap end perform better.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: Great...When it works....
review.review: Pros:- Great overall sound when using the speakers- Comfortable and adjusts nicely- Solid construction- Retractable Mic boom is nice and works- BluetoothCons:- Will randomly shut off without warning, or cut out before just turning off (tried with 2 different pairs)- Can only use EITHER the Speakers or Headset but not both- Constantly have to toggle which audio is being used by which device at which time- No batter indicator- Steelseries software is mostly just bloat and offers zero actual functionalityTL;DR; Speakers are great, "headset audio" is garbage (unless doing video/voice calls for work)If you are getting these to connect with your Macbook for work calls, great. The Bluetooth seems to work well with Macs. If you are planning on gaming with them then go pick up a cheaper pair of something because you cannot have nice audio (speakers) & voice-chat (headset) at the same time due to the way the codecs are setup for Bluetooth. Also Windows Bluetooth (tried multiple adapters and built-in BT) will randomly drop the connection. I just wanted a nice headset that just worked, and what I got was a nice headset that sometimes turns itself off, and having to choose between chatting with friends OR hearing my game. Works with Xbox (as it advertises) but I assume like with everything else it is using the headset so you can chat and hear audio which makes the audio garbage.

review.title: you get exactly what you think you are
review.review: lightweight, yes.LED functionality, yes.change the colors, yes.USB-A to USB-C connection, yes.Steel Series gaming program functionality, yes.adjust the DPI, yes.in usual Steel Series fashion, you get a mouse that does what it says it will, lets you have colors that can breathe or stay solid in zones, and with adjustable sensitivity.i still find Steel Series to be a better deal than RAZR products and since my laptop automatically comes with a Steel Series keyboard, my devices can be synced together.i went with the wired because not only is it cheaper, i have a tendency to lose the mouse when it's wireless.this cable does disconnect from the mouse when you're transporting it.I'll likely leave it on otherwise because it's easier to keep track of. at $35, pretty happy.my only concern would be for the future.because if the design to make it lightweight by cutting out a geometric pattern, the inner circuitry is visible.it says water resistant which i'm guessing also applies to sweat resistant.i'm not a heavy hand sweater, but to anyone that is, i could see this being a problem in the future.i haven't had it long enough to determine for sure how much of a problem it would be.

review.title: Best Mid-grade optical gaming mouse
review.review: Sometimes you don't want a mouse with a bazillion buttons. You want it for work and gaming without spending a stupid amount of money. Enter the Steelseries Prime FPS gaming mouse....not too fancy, built well and is a real delight to use. Sturdy, rugged and accurate for gaming. This mouse is a great buy for the money and proves you don't need to spend $ hundreds on a mouse with 42 buttons. If you like your mice, simple and sturdy/well built, this is the mouse for you. I replaced my razer mouse because it was starting to double-click in gaming.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Aerox 3 Wireless - Super Light Gaming Mouse - 18,000 CPI TrueMove Air Optical Sensor - Ultra-li...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2021
review.title: Working well
review.review: Mice are like shoes, so it's difficult to say what works well for everyone. I use a mouse 14+ h/day for long days at work and then what time I can have saving the universe. I've owned about every brand, both wired and wireless. My latest venture with the SteelSeries was based off a YT vid review that just happened to play. I'd been using a Razer Viper Mini for the past year and while it was a good mouse, it's just a bit too mini for me (average size hands).I've been pleased so far with this mouse. The weight is lighter than most, which I've increasingly grown to appreciate. I don't care much for wireless mice, so this wired one was my preference. The cable is ok - no kinks and with my setup, no drag/pull as I'm moving around. I already had a SteelSeries keyboard, so the software worked without issue picking up the mouse and adjusting settings. I've never had issue with SteelSeries software before, so that's been a non-issue as well.The mouse feels pretty good and has no plastic stuck on the sides like some of SteelSeries other mice. Those glued on pieces are nothing short of a mess over time as they goop out and get on your desk/hands/mouse. This mouse is all solid and is comfortable for long usage times. Clickers work well andthe wheel was surprisingly better than I feared - not exactly smoot, not horribly bumpy.Overall, I like this mouse and for the money, feel like I got a good product for the cost. I generally go through mice every 1 to 3 years, depending on how they hold up. I'm hoping this holds up to the task.
product.title: Sponsored Ad - SteelSeries Aerox 3 Wireless - Super Light Gaming Mouse - 18,000 CPI TrueMove Air Optical Sensor - Ultra-li...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split Trigger Buttons...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Unacceptable Battery Life
review.review: I would have thought battery life would be great considering how quickly the mouse goes to sleep, but what would otherwise be a solid mouse for the price is ruined by terrible battery life. I am having to replace the AAAs in my mouse what feels like every 1-2 weeks.There is a power saving setting in the Steelseries software, but it is locked at 150hz polling rate which makes even browsing the web clunky and unresponsive. I especially notice it in the scroll wheel, which feels like it drops roughly every other click.I would recommend this mouse only if you have a battery charging station within reach of your desk and can live with the inconvenience. I will be replacing mine with a Logitech G305, and I guess this will be a fine emergency backup as it is past the return period.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split Trigger Buttons...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split Trigger Buttons...

review.title: Do not use with a KVM Switch
review.review: I purchased this mouse to replace a Corsair gaming mouse I use both for my personal gaming computer and my work 3D modeling computer using a KVM switch.I quickly found the mouse does not save settings natively.After experimenting with 3 computers I found the mouse powers up with a extremely bright Rainbow light pattern, then polls the SteelSeries software installed on the computer for the correct settings. Since I could not install the SteelSeries software on my work computer, I was stuck with the distracting rainbow pattern.SteelSeries support was less than helpful and claimed the mouse should have onboard memory.Once I proved the Rival 5 was not working from onboard memory to maintain illumination settings, SteelSeries support stopped responding.I sent this mouse back to Amazon after noticing the computer would lose connection with the mouse multiple times a day.

review.review: I had multiple friends who use this headset recommend it to me. Seeing it was on sale I said why not. I almost instantly regretted this decision the moment I started using them. Even on sale, the audio qaulity is so bad, that it has given me a headache within minutes of use. All of the audio sounds like you're holding a metal pipe up to each ear. With no dedicated driver to download, and no program to balance the settings, this issue is just not possible to solve without just getting a different set entirely.Saying I was disappointed is an understatement. For something this expensive, I would expect something that sounds clear and crisp. But what I got was something that makes everything sound worse. Like its on a radio, or in a tunnel.If you are expecting High quality audio, get something else. If you don't care about quality, then I guess these work fine otherwise.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2021
review.title: Best headset for my money
review.review: To preface this review I should say that I have a fairly large cranium, so if you have a smaller head it might not fit as snuggly/ well. I had this headset for 3+ years and just recently ordered another one (the old one isn’t broken it’s just kinda gross from so much use - around 3+ hours a day)This headset has amazing sound localization, the frame and cord are both super durable, and comfort is superb from my experience. They don’t stay quite as cool around the ears as the Hyper X Cloud II, but I can wear them for hours without any heat discomfort. The way the frame works/adjusts around the head let’s it fit snuggly without putting too much pressure which is great for comfort. That also means that it doesn’t give as bad of headphone hairdo (though it still leaves a minor impression on the hair). If you are on PlayStation or PC you can connect it to your system through the USB which adds the nice option of being able to mute your mic and adjust the volume of yourself and of your game. When I play on Xbox I just connect the headphone jack directly to my controller through a headset adapter (which is no longer in production from Microsoft, but it is great and gives the option to mute)As far as mic quality, it’s pretty great, voice goes through nice and crisp and the noise gate on the mic is really effective at preventing unwanted sounds (AC, breathing, etc.) from being picked up.One of the best headsets I’ve ever had.
product.title: HyperX Cloud Revolver - Gaming Headset with HyperX 7.1 Surround Sound, Signature Memory Foam, Premium Leatherette, Steel F...

review.title: Decent sound quality... Headband snapped. Cheap plastic.
review.review: The x800 or H wireless was a decent headset for wireless comfortably and sound. It wasn't good for footsteps, but for gunshots, hearing vehicles, etc. it was decent.I liked the swappable batteries and it made it easy to play on and on. But the fact of the matter is, this a cheaply made headset. I expect more out of a $200-300 headset.The headband snappedon the inner part of the band on the right ear cup side. Its entirely made out of plastic. Steelseries has terrible customer service and my warranty has expired. So I'm out $220-250 or whatever I spent on it a while back. For any headset over $200, I expect it to last at least 2 years. Very frustrated with SteelSeries. Shouldn't be that much for a cheaply made product.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2018
review.title: Works great, but not all the time.
review.review: So.. it's not a bad product.It works, but you will hear a constant "white noise" in the background of your games when it's silent.Not sure if this happens on all high-end headsets, but it was disappointing.While playing games, the sound from the game usually drowns out the white noise.Another issue I had was the headset causing my controller to randomly reset.I would be playing a game and my controller would just shut off. I use the Xbox elite controller, and have never had this issue until using this headset.I think it has something to do with the proprietary adapter that they use.Without the adapter, the controller never has the issue and the headset works fine..Recently, I was using my headset and it suddenly stopped working with the Xbox chat.I checked the cords, reset the receiver and did several other resets to it as well.Finally after setting the receiver back to factory defaults, I was able to get it working again.The product support on their website is very slow as well.They only email you, and it takes about 24 hours to hear back from them for each reply.That being said, they did offer to send me a new cord for my headset.. though I'd imagine that was not the cause of my issue..Overall, I've probably dumped at least 200-300 hours into this headset, the multiple batteries are very nice and the sound is great.Aside from the occasional bugs, it's not a bad headset.
product.title: SteelSeries Siberia P100 Comfortable Gaming Headset for Playstation 4, PlayStation 3

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2021
review.title: Inconsistent
review.review: The mouse has a good feeling in the hand with texture and side grips. Software is not bloated. Software is intuitive for the most part and easy to setup. Software can be buggy sometimes when trying to launch the application but a simple fix for me was to end the services related to the app and re launch. Discord integration is a nice feature but could be improved upon with more option for specific notifications and a setting for longer display of said notifications. Also display is to narrow and at an angle for you to read. Notifications don’t seem to fully display only the beginning part of a message. The weight of the mouse is a turn off. I purchased this with the intent of capitalizing on the features but I was hugely disappointed. Tactical feedback is weak on highest setting making the build feel cheap especially considering the weight of this mouse. The on board memory is somewhat bugged. For example if I set button 4 to mouse button 1 and toggle repeat my clicks won’t register on button 1 or button 4 so I have to open the software reconfigure the settings. It might work for sometime but then the issue happens again and when I start the software it shows some my bindings have changed even though I have all of my profiles duplicated on board. So on board memory and software integration is a inconsistent at best. For example toggle hold works fine for me but repeat on hold does nothing. At this price point I was willing to compromise for a heavy mouse if the feature were worth the price but unfortunately they are not.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2021
review.title: A quality mouse without excessive extras
review.review: A great mouse for gaming if you have medium or large hands and don’t want a dozen extra buttons. I personally don’t like the average gaming mouse, most are either too small or oddly shaped, and many have far more buttons than I ever use that also take away from the comfortability of it. This mouse doesn’t fall into either cliche, it has 2 thumb buttons that are easy to reach and press, but they’re not within the grip area making it uncomfortable. It’s the perfect size for my hands (which are above average in size) and it also has a DPI switch button just below the primary Left and right click.The material feels good in the hand, it has a weighty, quality build but is not overly heavyIf you want a bunch of DPI options then this might not be the Mouse for you, it essentially has a high DPI mode and a low DPI mode. It’s perfect for my preferences but I could see how some people would want more optionsOverall I’d give this mouse a 9/10 only due to the aforementioned lack of DPI options, though it is perfect for what I like and I personally would not want an excessive amount of DPI settings to click through

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2021
review.title: Good mouse but lacking in important areas
review.review: I used this mouse for about a year for games of all sorts of genres, has a good weight without need of adjustment and good mouse buttons. An issue that I thought I would get used to but turns out it may have just been bad design, is there's a small corner where your thumb rests to your palm, and the subtle corner was causing my hand to cramp. Forced me to change mice in search of a better ergonomic shape. -1star for this.Other -1 star is because the screen on the mouse is very limited in its functionality. I was hoping to be able to set it up for whatever game I wanted and even do a little programming to make cool functionality with it, but its completely inaccessible, and can only accept gif images at low framerates. The coolest thing I made it do was display a shape that changed at the corners. Screens a cool idea but very much just novelty.Overall the mouse will do the job, but fans of better ergonomics may want to look elsewhere.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 710 Gaming Mouse - 16,000 CPI TrueMove3 Optical Sensor - OLED Display - Tactile Alerts - RGB Lighting, B...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2021
review.title: Cool concept but not translated well to use
review.review: I wanted to give this mouse a higher review than what I did for gaming. It's got a ton of awesome features that seem great on paper, but it's HEAVY. The position of the additional side button on the mouse is also slightly inconvenient, which is a shame because that's why I bought the mouse, for an extra button that I could use for keybinding in WoW as I didn't want a naga. Additionally, the side buttons occasionally squeak when depressed rapidly which is a nuisance.Those two things alone make me slightly disenchanted with it. That being said, it's slick, feels great in the hand, looks cool af and has amazing responsiveness.If you like the idea of haptic feedback and aren't playing a game that requires a lot of mouse button presses or keybinds this one could be for you.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 710 Gaming Mouse - 16,000 CPI TrueMove3 Optical Sensor - OLED Display - Tactile Alerts - RGB Lighting, B...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review.title: Cheap disappointment, could've been goated.
review.review: Ive never written a review and I'm not sure if I can rate 0 stars but just know I would. I bought this mouse months before I got my pc and let it sit, didn't even take it out of the box. When my I finally got my pc I got literally 3 days of play before the left click just stopped working, I did all of the troubleshooting the internet recommended, refreshing drivers, trying to use it on my laptop, etc, My friend advised me these things happen and he's on his third 710. The mouse felt great, truly, so I can understand his acceptance, but I am not the kind of consumer to overlook that sort of flaw. Pursuing a refend or even a replacement is near impossible through Amazon, I ordered the second option I was interested in, being the hyperx pulsefire haste, for half the price I recommend anyone that doesn't want to take the chance on a defective mouse to check that out, I haven't looked back except to mourn the disappointment that is the rival 710, it actually saddens my soul the absence of quality control.

review.title: @ doa's
review.review: TLDR: I ordered this mouse because it is a classic, and great mouse unlike most mice. I've owned one before at it was always reliable, never broke/died. It's my favorite for alot of reasons. However, weather it's the sellers fault, or the distributor, these mice may be fake. I've had 2 of them go bad on me within 2 weeks of use. Not kidding. A numpad button wentbad on the first one, and the 2nd one is very slow for a min or 2 on computer startup. This continued to happen, until today when it just was slow on startup, never went back to normal, and the rmb just completely stopped functioning. I don't know if I'd even want a replacement at this point. Just a refund.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Avoid.Build quality is not what it used to be.
review.review: My original g600 served me faithfully for 3 years without issue before the side buttons started wearing out...requiring progressively more force in order to register before dying completely.I was quite satisfied with the Logitech's performance in that time frame and decided to retire it in favor of a newer g600.I ordered the replacement g600 in September 2021, and it arrived with the middle mouse button broken, despite the packaging being pristine.After returning the second g600 through Amazon, I received a *third* g600, and the side buttons started wearing out in less than a month.Even without the broken buttons, the two replacements clearly exhibit a lower build quality from the previous generation, feeling poorly-put-together using cheaper components -- like using a rubber cord rather than a sturdy, braided one.Normally I don't take time to leave reviews, but I am going to leave this here for anyone looking at a g600 for gaming after October 2021.Go with another mouse.I'm not sure how the Razer Nagas are performing but I might look into Corsair instead.RIP Logitech...I just wish you cared about the quality of your products.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Great headset for PC. NOT FOR XBOX
review.review: I'll save you Xbox dudes a couple hours worth of looking online to see if this headset is compatible with xbox or not. Long story short, it is compatible but will not have volume control, a mute option, or the 7.1 surround sound option. These are made for PC.Gave it 5 stars because it looks really nice, is super comfortable, and would probably be a phenomenal headset for a PC (I don't have a gaming PC) however, due to the USB connection off the headset, it isn't compatible with an Xbox controller.The wire coming off the ear cup ends with a 3.5 mm aux cord designed for an Xbox controller. You then plug that aux output into the headsets in-line controller, and that controller then ends with a USB plug. That in-line controller controls the 7.1 surround sound, volume, and mute controls. So in theory, yes, you can plug this in to an Xbox controller via the 3.5 aux tip and use the headset. However, you will not have any volume controls, mute option, or 7.1 surround sound. Xbox doesn't even support 7.1 surround sound by the way.Save yourself some money, and buy a wired headset with in line controls that is designed for Xbox. I ended up getting the Razer Blackshark V2 X and have been extremely happy. Don't get hung up on the 7.1 surround sound, it means nothing for Xbox. It isn't real, Xbox doesn't support it.

review.title: Don't get much better than these.
review.review: Using on my PS5 and I've gotta say, I'm impressed.My my wife has Astro A40s and I found them to be quite heavy/bulky, rotating earcup feature is dumb/pointless and they're audio is annoyingly bassey.Needed an upgrade from my generic RIG $30-$40 gaming headphones from Walmart and settled on these.Got the black ones and damn do they look sexy.Sound quality is amazing. Tried plugging into the dualsense controller but there's no volume adjustment so everything was loud as hell. Used the USB adapter and WOW. The 7.1 audio button really makes a HUGE difference. Everything sounds sooo much cleaner and crisp with it on and the volume adjustments are nice too. They are very comfortable, though the clamp force feels a bit tight but I've got a damn big head. Hopefully they'll loosen up after a while. Noise cancelation is nice and these block out background noise pretty well too. The wife's "Harrier jet" of a PS4 isn't so obnoxious anymore. Definitely happy with my choice.
